parisspleen.title: Paris Spleen
parisspleen.author: Charles Baudelaire
parisspleen.review:
At last some poetry (albeit prose poetry) I can unabashedly get behind. It only took the French to do it. A massive credit goes to the translator, who manages to imbue a lot of these poems with actual clever and beautiful turns of phrase; unclear to this non-French speaker how much of that is from the original, but found myself liking the prose on its terms throughout. Maybe all it took was leaving behind the shackles of rhyming.
 The content of these is a bit of a strange mix that feels like it could only authentically come from the period that it does; reflections on urbanity and the city, as well as general horniness, that feels shockingly modern, all while having a religious and mythological slant to it that feels like it could not be borne out of the modern age. In general just a really fun energy and life to the poems; Baudelaire has a sense of humor that can be pretty caustic/cynical/sarcastic/nasty that still maintains good humor about itself and remain self-deprecating at the same time. In one of the poems he says to be drunk at all times, not necessarily of alcohol but of experience, and these poems feel like that at times, a ride through ideas with good humor and verve to them.

bleedingedge.title: Bleeding Edge
bleedingedge.author: Thomas Pynchon
bleedingedge.review:
Pynchon does 9/11 is about as good of a tagline as it gets for me to be interested, despite this being seen as maybe the least of his works. This falls in with Shadow Ticket and Inherent Vice as late career romps; inessential if you’re looking only for the apex, but pretty damn fun/interesting if you’re down for the ride. 
Conceptually he is trodding similar ground with the Internet to where he lands the plane in Inherent Vice, just advanced a little further into the future; in Inherent Vice, the good guys are able to leverage it for their own purposes, even as it is fundamentally a tool of the state; here, it’s already been bought and sold a million times over. Even if retains some of its fundamental weirdness (and its ghosts), it’s still liable to be sold off, ruined, disappeared, something anyone who’s been on the Internet for longer than 5 years knows. Try to use it for good, be ready for it to be corrupted and turned into ad space; you can either sell it the highest evil bidder or give it away for free and walk away with your hands clean. This pairs with the 9/11 angle- backdoors and security creating a web that makes it impossible to tell who knows what or what interest is actually in control, the addition of private contractors turning the intelligence apparatus into something truly impossible to get your arms around. The only victory is to uncover one piece of the puzzle.
The ending feels in line with those of these other late career dalliances, small personal victories with a twisted sense of hope- the children frolicking into an online and real life wilderness, with no way to monitor or ensure their safety, only the trust that you’ve prepared them for what the world has to offer and maybe done enough to make the world a safer place. 
Pynchon in NYC is also just fun as a fan, tackling more domestic characters (parents? with partners? and responsibilities?) and new subcultures, one more contemporary to our world. The foot job loving hacker, the left wing blogger mom, the bike delivery man- all the stars are here.

saving_time.title: Saving Time: Discovering a Life Beyond the Clock
saving_time.author: Jenny Odell
saving_time.review:
Happy to spend more time in Odell’s head after really loving How To Do Nothing but this one ultimately falls short of that work. I was fully in for about half of it- you start elaborating on birds, the origins of wage labor, quoting Southland Tales, I Think you Should Leave and Georges Perec and you got me nailed down to a T- but it feels like she didn’t quite stick the landing all the way (even if I liked the ending). Perhaps there’s no way to satisfying get to the bottom of time and our relationship to it, but it felt worse than that- it feels like she got lost in her own disparate connections, somewhat lost sight of the old goal. Perhaps the simple thesis of How To Do Nothing helped make all the navigating feel more guided. In some ways, this feels like the opposite of something I noted about Animal Vegetable Miracle, which was unapologetically a time capsule of some of the haughtiness of Bush-era liberalism- this one approaches some of its points timidly, seeking out possible criticisms before they can land, trying to cover every possible interest group before they can object to the book and losing the ability to make actual arguments and substance because of it.

That being said, I think this book has a lot to actually say, just as her last book did. The history of Taylorism and selling your time- the origins of wage labor and contemporary obsessions with workplace efficiencies, the subject of capital trying to account for the productivity of every moment (whether imposed by actual all-seeing systems or just an imagined panopticon). Her resistance to the idea of history as the result of inevitable forces, the engagement with the present as where change can occur, negating the bound to have happened past and the bound to happen future (even if I found some of her scholarship and reference work lacking that could’ve helped her build it out). The disconnection from the seasons (easy to say as a Bay Area writer) that leads to all time feeling the same. In the end, what she proposes is a sort of anti-productivity, or perhaps better worded an anti-efficiency; she’s not against work, but she is against the obsession with efficiency, with making sure every second reaches the maximum amount of efficiency. Instead, she searches to linger in moments, to watch the passing of the seasons, to make time for the differently abled and for work to be done in its own time rather than as quickly as possible. It’s a utopian vision, and not one I always feel like she does the best job showcasing here, but it’s a nice one to visit nonetheless.

the_loser.title: The Loser
the_loser.author: Thomas Bernhard
the_loser.review: Very compelling as a one paragraph, stream of consciousness telling (almost entirely in the past) of getting crushed by being in proximity to genius. There’s not a whole lot of plot or action besides, but Bernhard’s delve into the mind provides all the juice- all self-contradicting, elliptical, repeating, bitter movements of a mind looking back at its own life and those closest to it (and of course, there’s plenty here that can be interpreted as being truly 3 sides to the same coin; the shared lung diseases that Bernhard also had being the most obvious one). All self-justifying machinations in service of dodging that he in part drove his friend to suicide, that he wanted to gawk at his failure and demise, that he needed a loser to point at for his own construction of self. The invented Glenn Gould is pure artistic genius, a man who would chop a tree down with an axe if it meant it would make his piano sound better, who would applaud a Nazi statue if it made his work sound better, solely dedicated to his craft, a pure ideal. The narrator and his friend are lost before the ideal, all too human with their neuroses, cut down upon hearing his playing, burning any non musical artistic creations they muster; they can only escape, through solitude in the narrator’s case, or through possessing their sister until she leaves and suicide is the only answer, a final artistic act. In the end, all that’s left of the three will be Gould, the Goldberg Variations that knocked them down in their youth.

the_unbearable.title: The Unbearable Lightness of Being
the_unbearable.author: Milan Kundera
the_unbearable.review: As overwrought as it gets- every bit of actual novel (aka character, plot or scenery) has to be interrupted by 5 bits of Kundera’s philosophizing or theorizing. Not poetic enough to be poetry, not of real substance in actual thinking about politics, mostly aphoristic when it comes to philosophy, one wonders if Kundera picked up novel writing just because it was the easiest place to pull the wool over people’s eyes. End of History as novel- all it must be soes, the world as inevitable, all choices and actions predetermined, all attempts to change things self-martyring, attention seeking, or otherwise ill-founded. Occasionally strikes an interesting chord with one of the digressions but only because it play so many notes (and when it does, it usually stretches it far longer than warranted).

shadow_ticket.title: Shadow Ticket
shadow_ticket.author: Thomas Pynchon
shadow_ticket.review:
Old man Pynchon leans perhaps heaviest into his goofiness with this one- ever name more absurd than the last, a ton of songs (including a peanut butter jelly time reference), and all sorts of his usual absurdity, including teleporting Hungarians, acronyms that spell SMEGMA, a lamp so tasteless that it breaks cameras (and has been extolled in Tasteless Lamp Quarterly), and the central plot conceit of the book being that a PI is chasing down a cheese heiress, the daughter of the Al Capone of cheese..

Beyond the gags there’s plenty of the other typical Pynchonisms- intelligence agencies everywhere, corporate consolidation swallowing up everything in its wake (including, it turns out the Al Capone of cheese), and a world on the brink of something- in this case, fascism in Europe, and possibly in America. Hicks’ uncle admire Hitler from afar in Milwaukee and hangs with his boys at a pro-Nazi bowling alley where nobody really bowls, and fascist gangs are roving the countryside. A woman runs towards her fate as an anarchist saint in Spain, golems retrieve mistakenly identified as Jews from camps of fascists (Harley Davidson has to be a Jewish bike because Davidson, you see), and clarinetists scour the European countryside for safe places to shuttle Jews if it comes to it. In case you thought he meant this was a European problem, he throws in a half page dalliance at the end to bring you back to the States, towards our homegrown fascism. Pynchon takes a moment, also towards the end, to do a little aside, to look at the reader and bring you to your own present moment, to what you are doing: he asks, quite literally, will you bury your head in the sand, start a family, buy a house, keep your head down, ignoring what goes on around you, until the regret swallows you? And then he says no one is around to hear it anymore. It is a stunning bit of audience work, after he spends much of his time in Hungary/Europe doing his usual deluge of characters and setpieces, to bring it back to something direct and digestible and in such a gut punching way.

I also found the ending pretty stunning, as perhaps the final piece of writing (although hopefully not!) he puts out. In a letter from a teen informant of Hicks, he shows perhaps a glimmer of hope, or something similar- the youth in revival, in search of something golden at the end of the rainbow in California, where so many Pynchon books land, the innocence and hope always in spring somewhere even if you’re laden with the responsibility of having to fight, too world weary to go looking for it, or too old to do anything but look back on the past. “Maybe they’ll keep finding new ways to be innocent,” chasing sunsets in California, the dream lives on. If this is the end, then it’s about as good as a way to go out, but maybe we’ll see one more sunset and we can turn to Tommy P for advice (or at least a laugh) one last time.

the_greening.title: The Greening of America, 25th Anniversary Edition
the_greening.author: Charles A. Reich
the_greening.review:
Rare does a book send you with whiplash as much as this one. In my Nixon induced madness I picked this one up because Nixonland mentioned it a few times and I wanted a more at the time look and analysis at the youth movement of the age (plus it was on my girlfriend’s shelf and I was bookless at the time). I knew it would be wrong in many ways, but how wrong it was was somewhat shocking.

It’s easy to look at some analyses of the political situation and say “what no material analysis does to a mf,” and usually that’s directed at people that genuinely don’t know better. Reich knows better! He points at material analysis, hand waves it away, and then substitutes his consciousness based analysis which, while sociologically interesting, does not have a theory of change beyond “if enough people believe things it will change things” which he knows (and cites as part of his project) doesn’t work because Vietnam is happening as he writes. It feels like blind optimism, perhaps fear of what would have to happen (or attempt to happen) if systemic change were really to occur.

Part of a seemingly broad project of the 1960 and 1970s to realize that man himself needed to change in order to inaugurate a more just society- Lefebvre I think very smartly refrains from speculating too much, but this book launches into a full reveries about how the hippie consciousness is the wave of the revolution. I think his analysis of the culture is interesting, and to be honest in some cases feels like an aspirational consciousness that people on Instagram are trying to emulate. Of course, as the Instagramness implies, this consciousness is easily wielded by capital to market and funnel into the world that capital provides. If there was a revolutionary aspect to it, it was only as a self-interest, to try to avoid Vietnam service (or to get coed dormitories). The analysis of the more conservative, competitive consciousness is relatively rote, but I also found the analysis of the liberal meritocrat interesting, particularly in its assertion that they try to “dominate” their hobbies, or have control over them, rather than allow themselves to be open to surprise or vulnerability, and that they never let their passions eclipse their need to fit as a useful tool of society (he’s really obsessed with surfing and skiing for this one).

Felt like the people that watch Fight Club and Office Space and complain about “people in the 90s bitching about their soulless office jobs” but for a powerful administrative state that somewhat tried to bend business and society to the wills of the common good. You didn’t know how good you had it. Also, this dude is obsessed with types of peanut butter. Was that a thing in the 70s?

nixonland_the.title: Nixonland: The Rise of a President and the Fracturing of America
nixonland_the.author: Rick Perlstein
nixonland_the.review:
Big Dick Summer has come to its ultimate climax. It is finished. I have to come up with a new thing to tell people when they ask me what I am up to.

Whereas Before The Storm was somewhat work to get to its conclusion (albeit fascinating work) this one is pure fun. Perlstein mentions him getting access to the archive of cable TV for this book, and in many ways you can feel it- the cutting between the various news items of the day- in many instances the writing calls to and tries to evoke the feeling of the news- the news that incited many to follow Nixon and not just vote for him but idolize him. It is a torrent of information that can be overwhelming but very successfully mimes the tumultuous tenor of the age.

Nixon is such a definable character, so obvious in his flaws and foibles and also his assets. Maybe my favorite anecdote of the book is him spilling soup on himself at a White House dinner and then banning soup from being served at the White House again, because it wasn’t manly (soup heads in shambles). There’s countless cases where Nixon is on the outs, where it seems his career is over- both from people in his own party and from people outside it. But he was tenacious and he was power thirsty and he did have a sense of the prides and resentments of Americans, of the darkness inside them, and he was able to weaponize them in his favor. Some of the political maneuvering in here is awesome in its cynicism and guile- him sending fliers with inaccurate information on events for the candidate he didn’t want to face, all of the ratfucking of the DNC field in 72 really, and him constantly sabotaging Vietnam peace talks in order to win elections. His ability to turn a losing conflict in Vietnam into a winning political issue with voters in 72 against McGovern, who was consistently on the right side of it, is one of the most impressive feats of politicking one can imagine (and also the ultimate condemnation of American elections and the role of public relations politics). The legacy of the POW/MIA bit of PR is still present today in modern conflicts- think of Benghazi, think of Biden’s ultimate demise really coming after the pulling out of Afghanistan.

Perlstein argues quite successfully that Nixon defined the terms of American politics for decades and even to this day. The first cracks in American economic excellence, the first contractions of who was given access to American dream, the first raises denied- all lead to the formation of a politics that we still not have escaped. The liberals as the snobs, the elites who looked down at the little guy, or the idealist hippies with no respect for the hard work of the common man, as cowards too scared to attain military victory if they would just keep going. The conservatives as the silent majority, those too busy working hard to complain, defenders of American excellence and private property from roving hordes of immigrants, of minorities, of degenerates looking to corrupt your children. It was Nixon, it was Reagan, it was Bush, it was Trump. We keep on litigating 68 and 72, Nixon’s reality, again and again, over and over.

entangled_life.title: Entangled Life: How Fungi Make Our Worlds, Change Our Minds & Shape Our Futures
entangled_life.author: Merlin Sheldrake
entangled_life.review:
The interestingness of the subject does a lot to overcome the writing, as Sheldrake (what a name) frequently seems to lose track of what point he’s making, belabor a point for paragraphs, or just take pages to gas up his friends. I respect the last of the three but cannot abide the other two.

That being said, mushrooms are pretty sick, and it’s clear how much possibility lies in the field. There’s obligatory sections about cordyceps and psilocybin that don’t necessarily cover fresh ground for anybody but have to be in a book about mushrooms, but the real joy of the book is the other stuff. His description of the symbiotic relationships are different than many other conceptions of the naturla hierarchies, albeit he often lays it on a little thick with the way he emphasizes them. Found the lichen (particularly lichen in space) and the gardening soil possibilities the most interesting, along with the medicinal and waste absorption portions, as well the descriptions of how mycelium and hyphae function. Clearly points you towards alternate definitions of intelligence in ways I’ve only really seen done in science fiction (shout out Blindsight).

This book is clearly meant to drive interest towards mushrooms in part because of how underdeveloped the field is, to the point of it almost seeming like a shining advertisement trying to find a rich guy to throw money at mycologists. It’s amazing how late in the game scientifically speaking many of the discoveries featured here are relative to how we know the timelines of discovery for plants and animals, so I can’t find fault in it for doing so, but I also don’t need to know of every way someone is using mushrooms to make money.

I guess I can forgive the mushroom compost for destroying my first gardening adventure. Just this once though.

flower_wreath.title: Flower Wreath Hill: Later Poems
flower_wreath.author: Kenneth Rexroth
flower_wreath.review: The second book of Beat poetry I’ve read on the john this year, this one much more invested in the natural world than Ferlinghetti’s more urban settings. Rexroth is the OG white guy Buddhist (besides maybe Gary Snyder), and a lot of this is translation which is interesting but doesn’t necessarily translate into wonderful poetry on the page just due to the oddities of translation. His original work is solid but outside of a few highlights didn’t strike me as remarkable. This had the promise of possibly being a Sam Rockwell White Lotus situation (he inhabits a Japanese woman to write an extended love poem) but to the chagrin of drama seekers everywhere it’s actually pretty tastefully done and maybe the highlight of the collection.

diary_of.title: Diary of a Drug Fiend
diary_of.author: Aleister Crowley
diary_of.review:
You ever listened to a coked up guy rant at a party about all his crazy adventures and sex he’s having? My tolerance for them is higher than most, so you know when I say that this is annoying and mostly bad, it really is. The first third is basically that as unfiltered monologue with little to redeem it outside of our resident coke fiends getting scammed somewhat constantly. It is a beautiful thing to realize, though, that people over 120 years ago had to listen some of the same inane ramblings that I have, that I’m sure many of you have.

The second third’s perspective change is at least slightly more interesting, as there’s more going on with Lou’s perspective than “annoying cokehead,” but at the end of the day I just don’t need that much fiending for coke and heroin portrayed for me.

The third part is at last the most interesting part, as we get to Crowley’s alternate community of Thelema, an interesting precursor to the alternate living experiments that became much more prevalent post 1960s. The points are much the same- that modern society does not funnel human beings into what is existentially fruitful for the human, but for what is economically productive for the society. This book’s conception of drug use is that this dissonance is where the drug addiction comes from- that when day to day life is not in accordance with man’s natural desires, he will become addicted to the chemically induced one that is more in alignment with it, with no will to return to the old life because it not good for him. The capital W Will, what man is truly uniquely shaped for, is the way to handle drugs, the way they can be used for his betterment. The castle community is designed to provide a space free from economic constraints for people to do that.

It all sounds well and good. But then the main character discovers his only purpose in life is designing a helicopter and his wife’s one and only purpose in life is to support and help him accomplish his Will and then you start to squint your eyes a little bit. You start thinking about the various young women tailing around the old guy who runs the community. Maybe he was cooking at some points but this clearly isn’t fully up to snuff.

There’s also some funny double self insert where young self insert’s wife wants to fuck old self insert (who’s described as being like a 100 year “vampire”). That stuff’s kinda fun too. But it’s also just not that well written. Not saying Crowley’s not for me in totality (I’m curious!) but this one isn’t very good.

learning_from.title: Learning from Las Vegas: The Forgotten Symbolism of Architectural Form
learning_from.author: Robert Venturi
learning_from.review:
This level of kneejerk contrarianism in its field has to be admired by a Halverson, even if (perhaps because) some of the argumentation here is hideously sloppy and easy to see through. Are suburban aesthetics innately preferable to the middle class, white or black, left or right, or had they been endlessly marketed to that group and anyone below it as the culmination of the American dream? Are big business and marketing an equal level of manipulator and interest group as people that don’t want giant billboards enshrouding their neighborhood with corporate drivel? If you believe this book’s final arguments, the answer might not be what you think!

I found this to be insightful when it was analyzing the logic and symbolism of sprawl; understanding what the signifiers are and what is being signified by the sprawl and the strip is important, and there’s plenty of insights/ways of seeing the world that I will use. These include the concept of duck vs. decorated shed, the building that’s form is the advertisement for the building itself (the example being the duck building in New Jersey for a duck farm) against a more traditional shaped building with signage or signifiers on it that indicates what it is; the idea that the parking lot is the true advertisement of what a supermarket has to provide to the consumer; the difficulty of mapping the modern world with its array of lights and scale; a general re-emphasis on utilizing ornaments/known symbolism rather than “pure” architecture, form for the sake of from; and its overall love of signs in general (down to saying one casino had been subsumed by and become its sign). However, just because it is important to understand to them, does not mean they should be held up as peak architecture, or the ideal response to the modern age; and just because they are an ideal fit for a technological age does not mean they are good, generally. Should we design our buildings solely so they communicate and are understood by the speeding automobile? Perhaps in our gas station stops and our highways, but to say that the Las Vegas Strip is well-designed for that purpose and should be an example to others is to glorify the hideous, awful nature of the world, and give up any hope of designing a better one. The suburban tchotchke out front of the cookie cutter home is not an ideal but a cry for help, a last gasp of individuality in a sea of stifling architectural sameness. The Silent Majority’s world was clearly not one to be venerated, and neither, perhaps, is the one proposed or pointed to by the modernist architects. Maybe I’m irrevocably ruined by reading Nixonland, but perhaps this is best read as an elite institution being shocked by the state of the common electorate and their election of Nixon and using that to wildly and erratically attempt to course correct towards “common” values, similar to how the liberal elite responded to Trump’s first election (never forget Hillbilly Elegy).

the_department.title: The Department of Speculation
the_department.author: Jenny Offill
the_department.review:
Unfortunately do not see the hype with this one- think I might be allergic to to this type of writing, the one that quotes and references all the hip thinkers of the 20th century intertwined with domestic dramas and issues. I feel like it should be up my alley and maybe there’s an instance of it I’m forgetting that hit but too often it feels like window dressing behind what ends up being sort of vague or banal.

That’s a little harsher than I think I want to be with this book, but it definitely was a bit of a disappointment. For every bit of insight or nice bit of writing this provides (for some reason, the realization she has of the dilemma her philandering husband is in, of being with her who nags and resents or running to his mistress who is just overjoyed at being in his presence has stuck with me) there’s chapters that didn’t do much at all. Perhaps it’s the Brooklyn of it all, or the pretentiousness of looking down on yoga classes and “normalcy”, or the complaining about the lost life of the selfish artist in favor of partnership and parenthood that turned me away. It all goes down easy, but it just led to me forgetting much of this a week on from reading.

Goes down in an afternoon or evening, so I can’t complain too much. It’s fine.

conquerors_how.title: Conquerors: How Portugal Forged the First Global Empire
conquerors_how.author: Roger Crowley
conquerors_how.review:
A book club pick I was not expecting to like at all (sorry Connor, the book of Wood sullied your good name) that I ended up liking quite a bit! Turns out naval shenanigans and colonialism can be kind of a fun read- big shoutout to Crowley, who manages to keep this compelling for most of its runtime by writing really good breakdowns of the battle strategies and the larger tactical decisions at hand while also keeping an eye for period oddities and general quirks of the past. He’s able to encapsulate that in part by keeping his scope incredibly narrow- the forays to the European continent are very rare- the eye of the book is almost always on the Indian Ocean and what’s happening there. I could see this as being frustrating to some, but for me (a 15th century idiot) it was actually useful to keep it limited and reserve the context for Wikipedia deep dives after the fact.

Some of my favorite historical quirks: the Portuguese thinking they had rounded Africa when they reached its curve; thinking they could cross the continent via rivers and getting trapped; the belief in an African Christian king Prester John with gold tipped weaponry that would enable them to team up and take down the Muslims for good; the encounters with Hindus where they assume them to be slightly misguided Christians; the Portuguese winning a battle with 90 people because they were the first to understand how tides work and could be everywhere their enemy was as they tried to make their way to their stronghold; the Portuguese official sent to India who immediately trying to make a stab at glory gets himself killed in a quest for more booty, following in a line of powerful nobles dying in fights they could’ve easily won in the hopes of glory; the sailors building secret compartments in ships to have sex with the beautiful women under the guard of a eunuch.

Crowley can descend into a little history teacher voice, glossing over some of the atrocities in order to pump up the accomplishments, especially in the final chapter summarizing the aftermath and all that was accomplished. It’s a difficult tightrope to walk toeing that line, and it’s possible I’m overly sensitive to it- the majority of the actual book does a good job staying neutral, letting the reader make many of their own judgements. The Chinese fleet mentioned in the opening contextualize everything that follows- a similar voyage, with similar power, handled entirely different between the cultures- the Portuguese always looking for an edge, always looking to grab the blade.

Reminded me, perhaps strangely, perhaps not, of some of the stuff I saw in the Jakarta Method- of groups assuming the good faith of their opponents (or at least visitors), assuming them not to just be out for blood and power, which is then used to subjugate them until violent resistance is impossible, utilizing pre-existing prejudices to fan the flames in their favor. Colonialism of course naturally bled into imperialism and CIA playbooks, but interesting to see a parallel such a long time in the past prior.

carol_the.title: Carol: The Price of Salt
carol_the.author: Claire  Morgan
carol_the.review:
Really liked how this portrayed desire- mysterious, totally enrapturing, without being able to fully understand it. It does all this without lapsing into too long and too frequent of ecstatic raptures that feel overwrought, by remaining restrained except for select moments. Often the desire for Carol feels totally beyond the narrator’s ability to articulate, even as it is all-consuming and taking priority over her world. Love features as an escape for both of them, a road to self-definition- Carol dealing with the loss of her marriage, motherhood being taken from her, Therese dealing with a stultifying retail job, a boring relationship, and facing the realities of the real world. There’s plenty of psychoanalysis to be had here in regards to the relationship dynamic- Therese seeking to find a mother to replace the one that neglected (even as the relationship splinters re-enacting her being second to her half sister in childhood), Carol looking for a daughter to replace the one she’s losing in the divorce- but the book itself turns the tables in its final acts, almost a coming of age, as Therese finds empowerment without Carol (and Carol rediscovers her own life) that allows her to return to the table as equals, to see her partner not as the idealized figure she had built but a real, complicated person.

The thriller moments are the weakest here in my view- probably put together to somewhat get around the taboo of its existence (and also to materialize the societal discrimination around it). Excited to see the movie- even without seeing it, it’s hard to picture Carol without seeing Cate Blanchett.

the_interpretation.title: The Interpretation of Dreams
the_interpretation.author: Sigmund Freud
the_interpretation.review:
A sort of behemoth to get through- Freud takes about 100 pages to give any original ideas of his own, instead opting to summarize the history of dream interpretation and all the existing theories. There’s tons of in practice interpretations on dreams of both his patients and himself, along with developments of all sorts of concepts regarding dreams (that all previous theories he established fall into, save that dreams are totally meaningless) and ultimately coming up with an entire theory of the mind. It took me a few months to get through this and I’d be lying if I said I remembered all (or most of it).

First off, the good stuff- the dreams. Every dream is a wish fulfillment, says Freud, no matter how insignificant or small the dream may seem, no matter how grim or nightmarish its contents. The dreams consist of the manifest content, what is actually dreamed, and the latent content, which is what the unconscious is acting out, the fulfillment driving the manifest content. The manifest content is most often material from life in the last day (or two or three), but can also can include material that the dreamer’s conscious mind can’t recall itself. Here is where many of the more crank theories of Freud originate, from the idea that any anxiety dream is driven by a libidinal urge to the Oedipal complex (which is less sexual here than commonly presented, but more as a rivalry for the affection of the mother with the father than a desire for sex). Some of the highlights of the dreams are Freud interpreting a women putting books in a box as about sex because, well, box, c’mon, Freud not interpreting his dream of riding a horse between two pillars as being sexual in any way, and Freud’s guilt dream for accidentally killing his friend by prescribing him more cocaine for a condition that was caused by cocaine. One of the more instructive dreams, however, is one where a child close to the dreamer dies, but there is no emotion attached to it- Freud unravels that the last time she had seen a lost lover was at the funeral for another child that had died, and that the funeral was actually a disguised wish fulfillment to see her beloved again.

This also sees the initial development of Freud’s theory of the mind, the unconscious, the filtering mechanism, and the conscious that he would obviously go on to make much more expansive. Also appearing is the concept of transference- the idea of the unconscious applying greater significance upon something that the conscious has in view in that is not significant in order to make some disguised wish apparent.

In the end, I think he does make a compelling case that the unconscious is involved in the dream process, that there is latent content to what our mind cooks at night, that dreams are a way to outlet the repressed and unsatisfied wishes of the mind. While some of his specifics go askew, I think this represents a useful (although not true) method of interpreting dreams and of the mind. Some of those limitations become apparent as you look into Freud’s mind itself throughout- his mind is very language driven, rather than image driven- there’s very little in the form of visual symbolism here, but plenty in terms of word connections, puns and other language play. That constrains some of his work and its usefulness, but also makes it an interesting view into the mind of such an influential figure beyond just the ideas in the text.

I might need a break from psychoanalysis but I will return- this was interesting and I think useful, at least to let me interpret all of my friend’s dreams and their minds.

free_day.title: Free Day
free_day.author: Inès Cagnati
free_day.review:
This one grew on me as I read it- first as I grew to appreciate the voice of the young narrator, the self-assured, matter of fact, constantly self contradicting cynicism built out of the combo of youth and hard living that I think Cagnati nails note for note, and then the odd sense of dread it builds that in the moment isn’t clear whether it stems from the harsh circumstances of her life or something worse until the final chapters take place. The dread is really well accomplished- just out of place details, an accumulation of things slightly off noted by the character but not put together (or at least not acknowledged) until she’s told in a flashbulb moment.

The final symbol of the book- the bicycle sliding away into the icy river, just as her dreams of school, of buying better land do the same- is one that’s stuck with me, that I think stands out even in its simplicity. Part of that is the way the love of the bike is built up, the sturdy, reliable companion of the narrator, her source of independence and joy- her love of it is built up constantly.

Very impressed with just how well this is executed and pulled off, much of that coming from the prose which works so well on the levels of bringing out character where there is very little dialogue and setting down those signposts of dread.

civilwarland_in.title: CivilWarLand in Bad Decline
civilwarland_in.author: George Saunders
civilwarland_in.review:
A weird combination of Carver type characters in quiet states of desperation but replaces the dreary everyday Americana with futuristic theme parks. The tone can be harshly bleak and comedic, sometimes in the same sentence. It loves it little sci-fi details but also loves a well-sketched character trudging through life. It’s an interesting mix, but it’s one that I think works- often because the jobs/businesses he creates are where idealism meets the cold, hard reality of the world on one end or the other.

If there’s a theme I see throughout, it’s often about labor and agency, about the situations work often puts us into of ethical quandary and how we respond, often giving a piece of ourselves to keep the lights on and the bills paid. There is no reword for being the yes man; just the boss telling you he hated you for it as the company goes under. The water park won’t fire you for killing a kid with the wave pool, but you have to live with his ghost haunting you and your wife fucking your boss that you hate cause he’s cooler than you. You take the memories from the old lady until she only has the precious ones she can’t part with, then you take your own because you have nothing to life for yourself. The theme park dehumanizes you and possibly leaves you at the hands of hateful customers, but what else is out there in a world where you can be enslaved.

The highs are incredibly high- some of my favorite short stories I’ve ever read live in here. But there’s some whiffs too- the humor dial on the fat story is all off, sometimes sliding into fatphobia, sometimes sliding into just meanspirtedness in a way I don’t think fits with the collection. The hits are more than the whiffs though, and manages to capture bleakness, hope, and humor all at once (sometimes in the same paragraph) in a way that I don’t think a lot of writers are reaching. Tough to grade a short story collection like this (or any)- the highest highs are here so I'm gonna give it the 5 but I've gone back and forth on it.

portnoy’s_complaint.title: Portnoy’s Complaint
portnoy’s_complaint.author: Philip Roth
portnoy’s_complaint.review:
Nice to be reading Freud while reading this, as a lot of it is cribbed pretty straight from the source- some of the mommy/daddy issues in this feel like a straight conversion into fiction, in the unique Roth style voice of course which makes it far more self pitying and funny than it does the more clinical Freudian register. Feels contemporary in a lot of ways, the constant profanity and general comedie/ironic/self deprecating tone, the way it talks about sex and dating, or maybe it’s an eternal truth of men finding it hard to commit, loathing themselves for that lack of commitment, and loathing women for their lack of commitment.

Also is just funny and lively as a piece of writing, constantly crackling with energy and vulgarity that never wears out its welcome, manages to feel fresh consistently even as it hits a lot of the same beats, delving into them deeper or hitting them from fresh angles.

All-time punchline of an ending, and has maybe the most extended piece of work I’ve read about masturbation that stays funny the whole time. Poor papa Portnoy and his prunes, man.

tokyo_year.title: Tokyo Year Zero (Tokyo Trilogy, #1)
tokyo_year.author: David Peace
tokyo_year.review:
Works mostly as a piece of atmosphere and a time and place, a portrait of post-war Tokyo. And boy, is post-war Tokyo sickening and depressing: lice in hair, rotting sardines and rotting rice, grubs crawling around everywhere, the violence of an occupying force, and the constant thudding of construction in the background. Guilt and paranoia are everywhere, a country full of war criminals experiencing comeuppance and looking behind their backs constantly for the punishment to land directly upon their head, the American occupiers and sheer poverty already surrounding the day to day. There’s some excess here in terms of the noir darkness, but that has more to do with character and monologue than it does in sheer atmosphere. There’s some scenes here that will stick with me: the prostitution hotel set up for Americans, the first person POV of being killed, the rotting of humans on trains, of food on the streets, the bloated, disgusting corpse from the book’s opening chapter.

Peace’s style perhaps contributes to that excess, constant line breaks and repetitions and normal font/italicized font bouncing off each other constantly. When it’s firing on all cylinders it makes this a really special experience; when it misses, it grows tiresome and feels indulgent.

the_stammering.title: The Stammering Century (New York Review Books Classics)
the_stammering.author: Gilbert Seldes
the_stammering.review:
My expectations based on the byline- the tale of wacky 19th century cults- may have been set too high, but there’s still plenty to love here, plenty of characters and ideas floating around that are hard to come by 100 years from its writing and 200 years from the events in it.

One of the central ideas of this is the transitioning of 19th century alt-communities from “radicals” to “reformers”- quotations because the way Seldes uses these terms is very different from the way they would be used today. Radicals hoped to change the world by creating their own slice of heaven, by creating their own world through their community isolated from broader society. Reformers instead sought to change the world through the changing of laws; this is as broad as abolitionists to prohibitionists to woman suffragettes. Seldes’ tends to see the radicals as beatific saints, even in their failures, beautiful and shining in their purity of thought and action even as they failed time after time. The reformers he tends to see more as imposers, seeking to force their will upon society through force of law.

Speaking of the will, if there’s a central idea to this book that he traces, it’s that of the will. His framing for the whole book is Jonathan Edwards, certainly a crank but not an eccentric- but through Edwards inventing the idea of the will, namely God’s will, that man could be saved only through God’s smiling upon him or not and through no good deed or faith could man be saved, this opened the can of worms for all sorts of heresy and crankery. For if God could have the will to save man, couldn’t man have the will to save himself? The tracing of the idea is a little sketchy; he tends to avoid it for chapters at a time and then return it, so obsessed with historical cataloging he is; but it’s a compelling one that I struggled to follow at times his logic.

All sorts of funny details in here due to the time period, both from the cranks themselves to Seldes writing. At one point, he tries to reference the pull out method because a cult “invented it”; however he says he cannot because he’ll get sued for it (a real concern at the time of his writing). Seldes’ description of the revival meetings and the seizing takes a tack that makes it all seem understandable, by starting with the conditions of the American frontier; lonely, isolated, hard living, with seeing people outside of your immediate family rare, when all of a sudden tents roll into town and you’re surrounded by a crowd, all set to an emotional fever pitch. There’s the cults started mainly so a leader could have sex with his friend’s wife, the cults that banned sex and thus died off gracefully from old age despite economic prosperity and community cohesion, the cults that believed man could achieve perfection on Earth and to prove it would lay naked with a beautiful woman (to predictable results and scandal). And then there’s of course, the ultimate legend, the prohibitionist Carry A Nation, who would go to bars and (ineffectively) sing 12 verses of a song to try to get the drinkers to stop, started throwing rocks at bars when that didn’t work, started bringing a hatchet for when she ran out out of rocks, who once drove a young unwed couple to suicide after catching them having sex (and was proud of having done so).

This book is pretty long, and Seldes’ can get caught up in minutia. I think it’s probably best as a pick up once every two weeks or so book rather than a read continuously one. But it’s all fascinating, and he does a good job of diving into detail and not coming to too many conclusions- he mostly ends up shrugging his shoulders and saying he’s just as confused at the modern and ancient condition as any. This includes the ending, which starts with him exalting and claiming to aim at a normal life, then pointing the finger at scientists, Roman Catholics, and classicists as salvation hunters in the line of the cranks in the book, then quotes Proust saying that all great works of art, all religions, all human achievements comes from the neurotic, obsessed, eccentric, and then, as a final shrug of the shoulders, just says “And yet-” as if to point at the shenanigans that the previous 400 pages consisted of as evidence enough that eccentricity is a dark path. There’s a crank in all of us, I guess.

the_book.title: The Book of Elsewhere
the_book.author: Keanu Reeves
the_book.review:
The Keanu gimmick and the excitement of a new fiction work from Mieville after his dalliances with whatever he’s been up to the last few years made me buy this one/read it as a post Goldwater/Proust brain balm, and for that it worked. I don’t think this is the finest example of his work, mostly cause I’m not sure a dumb guy concept (said flatteringly) such as this benefits as much from Mieville’s touch as the other concepts/ideas he’s tackled. He tends to work by increasingly escalating and complicating the sci-fi concepts at the same times as he does the plot machinations but there’s just slightly less fertile ground for him to dig into here in the confines of this Keanu comic book franchise than there is when he’s off on his own. He’s mostly probing at territory similar to Martin Hagglund’s This Life: that death is what gives our lives meaning and shape, that without a time ticking clock there cannot be meaning, although in a way the ending finds meaning in the endless procession of lives the Keanu character has. The real enemy, then is stillness, is the loss of the cycle, a perpetual cycleless stasis, and life’s quest to overcome death feeding into that possibility of stasis.

There’s a lot of cool imagery in here and well-developed sci-fi concepts, which makes the ending being lightning bolts shooting a tad disappointing/muddled but the road up to there makes the sci-fi elements interesting and compelling to both ideas and imagery.

In the end, this finds a middle ground between Conan style Keanuism and Mieville cerebral sci-fi that works somewhat but ultimately doesn’t tickle the itch as hard as I would’ve liked in either direction. An interesting collaboration but I don’t think it’s a must read for anyone except for devotees of the two.

animal,_vegetable,.title: Animal, Vegetable, Miracle: A Year of Food Life
animal,_vegetable,.author: Barbara Kingsolver
animal,_vegetable,.review:
Pre crash Bush era liberalism was a trip man. The tone of this at times is so smarmy and self-satisfied that I can get why people could hate it (and I could see how she wrote something as bad as Demon Copperhead). I don’t think she intends to come across as shaming but the amount of holier than thou lines she throws around about normal American eating habits is truly uncountable ('the only American food export worth mentioning starts with a McD”). She rants about vegans being naive and basically calls them stupid. Maybe once is a possible policy change actually mentioned; instead it’s blaming consumer choices all the way down. Maybe once does she mention the privilege of working a job that doesn’t require her to leave the home, of owning a farm. In some ways, this does it a service; it keeps it on message, which is the benefits and the how of eating local, and lord knows there’s been too many hand wringing books and thinkpieces in the last post-Trump era that spend more time apologizing than they do making their points. But still, reading it in the modern age was a tad shocking, a register we don’t really see out in the wild anymore.

With all those criticisms out of the way, I loved this book! The facts about big agriculture and lack of diversity in grocery store produce were all interesting, albeit stuff I’d heard in bits and pieces from other places. But Kingsolver has a gift for communicating what brings her joy, for describing the satisfaction in preparing a home cooked meal from scratch, of what food can do to bring people together, of the rewarding nature of growing something with your own hands and then putting it on your table as a meal, of just the day to day reality and seasonal changes of working to produce your own food for a year. She also communicates well the alienated and unnatural nature of our lives- how disconnected we are from food production, how everything is anonymized and plopped in the grocery store, the concept of a season in food consumption is totally eliminated, how produce from local farms go to rot while the same vegetable is shipped across borders using countless fossil fuels and put in the grocery store. Everything related to food is distanced from its production, its reality, and has in many ways gotten worse since this publication- now DoorDash alienates you from even having to interact with a single person responsible for the preparation of the meal, let alone how the component pieces of it came into being.

It really comes together in the final chapter, an emotional core centered around turkey reproduction. I didn’t think turkeys having kids could get me misty eyed, but here we are.

Given that I built a garden bed and tomatoes and peppers to put in the ground after this, I think I have to give it 5 stars (but I also think it earns it otherwise).

the_fawn.title: The Fawn
the_fawn.author: Magda Szabó
the_fawn.review:
A hater’s delight- a woman so obsessed with hating her childhood friend that she starts sobbing and screaming because she doesn’t look sad enough when she has to leave town, that she steals her fawn and gets it killed, she takes her husband for a lover and refuses to let him leave the friend for her so that instead she can make her suffer more, even down to stealing moments with him on his death bed. You will never be this level of hater (and I sure hope you won’t).

Sadly, the haterness starts to grow tiresome past a certain point, and while occasionally a new slant on the hate provides fresh joy for the most part it felt like it dragged a little. The moments where sunlight cracks the blinds of her haterness and she feels sincere emotion are some of the highlights of the book (reminds me somewhat of the moments of sincerity cracking through in Anna Burns’ Milkman). There’s some elements of Soviet critique/satire that hit some humor, like her background of being poor and impoverished growing up being converted to being a rich class traitor because it sells better, but those moments aren’t common enough.

Also, this is the first book I’ve read that mentions my favorite soup so it gets points for that. Shoutout chicken paprikash.

moise_and.title: Moise and the World of Reason
moise_and.author: Tennessee Williams
moise_and.review: This probably has more interest as a curio for real Tennessee Williams heads (which I am not, at least not yet) than it does as a standalone piece of literature. The writing, at least when it goes to interiority, trends a little sloppy, including an obsession with cutting sentences off midstream (and then mentioning that he cut the sentence off midstream). The novel is told by the narrator who’s supposed to be a bad writer so some of that could hypothetically work but in this case it ended up making this feel a little repetitive and drag. Williams being a playwright aspect really shines when he does set a scene, as swimming in the narrator’s memories of times with his dead ex lover and his childhood in Alabama are the finest aspects of this one, but for every page of that you end up with two or three of poorly done interiority. The most interesting aspect is his encounter with his (unknown to the narrator younger) self: the aging gay writer (being Williams in this case), seeing himself as undesirable, having lost the love of his life, writes his younger self on the verge of closing out his physical prime, with that same loss, abandoned by an even younger lover, looking at his future self with disgust and disdain. That in itself is a very interesting concept, just one that I wished was better developed. For a fan of the guy interested in his life, though, I can imagine it as catnip.

panopticon_a.title: PANOPTICON: A Tale of Doom (The Dithyramb of Destiny & Tales of Doom)
panopticon_a.author: Lucky Wilder
panopticon_a.review: I love my friend Connor (I mean Lucky) and I love the very fun book he wrote

how_to.title: How to Blow Up a Pipeline
how_to.author: Andreas Malm
how_to.review: My first ever audiobook completed on my lonesome, which is partially an accomplishment but also maybe why I’m more mixed on this. I think Malm has a lot of good points here, only enhanced by the years since its release- Extinction Rebellion seems to have moved totally into their PETA phase, mostly doing stunts that might garner rage filled media attention but have very little actual efficacy, and climate advocacy seems to have fallen totally by the wayside (at least in the USA) in a post-Covid, post George Floyd world. The example of the white protestors stopping a train in a working class neighborhood during rush hour and fighting a black man going to work is the perfect example of this shortsightedness and stupidity- attacking the wrong targets both in economic class and in transportation type.  The overarching point of the book- that the climate movement needs a radical, property damaging, flank, as every successful protest movement before it has had, is one that seems self-evident to serious observers, but he does a good job of building up the case and tearing down the American history book fetishization (and the one XR uses) of the peaceful protestors who changes the world on their lonesome. Malm’s use case of deflating SUV tires is I think a curious parallel (at least in a different context) of the Tesla vandalisms, which drew far more backlash and had more effectiveness than the thousands marching in the streets for the Hands Off protests. Particularly interesting is his history of pipeline sabotage, from anti-Israel actions to those in Africa and South America- in some cases net unsuccessful, in others successful at expelling the oil companies by making the costs greater than the gains. Less compelling is his need to compare this to slavery and other historical injustices; feels like a forced own goal, especially in a movement which he acknowledges himself has a problem with being white. Also found it lacking in looking at radical flanks that failed- thinking of the Weather Underground amongst countless others that followed his principles and ended up losing in the battles of history. As a manifesto and pure polemic I still think it’s effective, which at its length is all it needs to be, but found it lacking in some aspects and laborious in its point making in others, hence the 3.

cosmicomics.title: Cosmicomics
cosmicomics.author: Italo Calvino
cosmicomics.review: Was very hyped for this based off of my love for Invisible Cities but ended up a little let down by it- I was never unamused or bored but it didn’t quite reach the heights of my other experience with him. Reminded me a lot of Ted Chiang in its take on outdated scientific concepts with a humanist, emotion first approach, but I think the writing itself (possibly an issue of translation!) let it down, lingering where it should’ve moved on, switching gears when it should’ve stuck around. There’s a few stories here that’ll stick with me: the moon one, the fish uncle - but it was a little too uneven to be a full recommend. Could see myself buying this to read to my kids some day though- it fits that kind of writing style and ideas.

short_cuts.title: Short Cuts: Selected Stories
short_cuts.author: Raymond Carver
short_cuts.review:
Ashamed that I have waited this long to read Carver- this was absolutely phenomenal. Minimalist prose is not usually my cup of tea but this is something else- every word perfectly cut and realized, telling what it needs to and not an inch word, implicating whole emotional landscapes with simple sentences. Had to parcel this one out to make it to a book club, but I could have read this in a day easily.

“A Small, Good Thing” is maybe my favorite short story ever- simultaneously emotional crushing yet affirming of shared humanity. So many small details and scenes, all perfectly honed together. Will be returning to the Carververse sooner rather than later.

before_the.title: Before the Storm: Barry Goldwater and the Unmaking of the American Consensus
before_the.author: Rick Perlstein
before_the.review:
Feels a bit like an upside down version of our present political reality; a two party system, one Liberal and one Diet Liberal; an insurgent wing, carried by youth enthusiasm, accused of radicalism and extremism, held to account for all types of political violence, taking over one of them to unleash a new vision for the world, the good word of conservatism. When the votes are cast, it’s a landslide in the opposite direction, and conservatism is vanquished, surely to slink into the shadows for an eternity, only to be seen in fringe circles and nutjob pamphlets forever.

That is where this story leaves off, the failed Goldwater campaign which despite its failure ultimately transforms America forever from liberal undisputed hegemony to its current state of conservative dominance over both parties. The contradictions of post World War II society are starting to simmer; a middle class, lifted by the post war boom and government policy, begins to resent those looking to climb up onto even terms, especially as they start to look different from them. A civil rights movement emerges that seems unmoved by legislation, demanding real, expensive change that cannot be granted, at least not by one stroke of the pen. An electorate moves rightward in everything but the names it puts down for the presidential ballot box. Barry was just a touch too early, a touch too (I hate to say it) principled to cater to where he needed to, a touch too independent and shoot from the hip to land where he needed to be to be more than a prophet who never got to see the promised land.

It may be grim to see the roots of the shitty political situation we’re in, to see that the root of the conservative movement (at least at the grassroots, voter level; Barry himself is portrayed more sympathetically) is not in some principled ideological conservatism, but in left hating and segregation, in that middle class resentment and backlash to movements for equal rights and desegregation. But also there is in it a glimmer of hope for the future; that political parties can be overturned, that contradictions in the electorate between what they vote for in a politician and what they vote for in policies (see minimum wage increases/Medicare bumps in most states) can be channeled into a movement that actually seizes power and changs the world.

Aside from the overarching details of the political situation, also found this fascinating for all sorts of details of the past. A presidential campaign totally ruined by a candidate getting remarried after a divorce; LBJ running as the peace candidate, claiming no wars are incoming, all the while planning the war in Vietnam the whole time; a write-in candidate winning a primary, then basically cast into irrelevancy immediately after; a man with known Communist affiliations killing the President but it somehow gets blamed on conservative extremism; conservatives taking over Republican organizations by stealing parliamentary procedures from Communists; the emergence of morality as a political concept separating the parties rather than a bipartisan issue. All sorts of interesting characters with connections you wouldn’t imagine too; the founder of Knott’s Berry Farm, major conservative backer with a freedom center on the grounds, the Welch’s grape snacks guy the founder of the John Birch Society. The details of the past are far more interesting and contradictory than the simplistic, propagandized versions sold in high schools and popular conceptions and to go this deep on the not so distant past reveals a lot of that.

There’s been precious little Goldwater in what I’ve written so far, and in a sense, there’s not actually all that much of him in the book (or at least not as much as you would expect). He was reluctant to run from the start, pushed by groups and figures who made his ascendency inevitable behind his back. Those groups made him into a figure far beyond his actual appeal or charisma; crowds would chant his name, treat him like Jesus, and then be bored by his speeches. This was in part because he distrusted anyone outside of his Arizona circle, particularly in the groups that made him into the figure he was, and in part because he thought it was disingenuous to pander (down to the point of giving speeches decrying government programs that gave everyone in his audience benefits). He was, in some ways, one side of the ideal that Republicans pretend to be, a guy who liked flying his plane and cussed on TV and didn’t care for backlash or really anything else.

Perlstein weaves all this history, of major and minor figures, of party reps and fringe groups, in a pretty remarkably compelling fashion. He can get at times bogged down with youth activists and fringe small groups that don’t end up tying all the way back into the main narrative, but very rarely was I bored and most of the time I was fascinated. Highly, highly recommend reading, and excited to have a Dick summer (reading his Nixon book) soon.

a_coney.title: A Coney Island of the Mind
a_coney.author: Lawrence Ferlinghetti
a_coney.review: Remembered reading “Dog” in a university class and enjoying it so figured I would return to Ferlinghetti and see if I liked him in a larger dose. Plain-spoken poetry doesn’t have a lot to fall back on if it doesn’t immediately land, if the meanings and images don’t inspire anything from the reader. All poetry is a tightrope, but at lease denser and flowerier language can rely on turn of phrase or a beautifully conveyed image don’t land; this style can feel banal, shallow, like Instagram platitudes if it doesn’t hit. That’s all a way to say that I found this about half profound/interesting and about half landing on the boring side. Along with Mary Oliver I feel like this is about as gentle a landing into poetry as you can get, and I find some of his countercultural insights to be witty/cunning/insightful, but I couldn’t quite dig this collection as a whole.

swann’s_way.title: Swann’s Way (In Search of Lost Time, #1)
swann’s_way.author: Marcel Proust
swann’s_way.review:
Big Book to open 2025 completed in record time (although this one was shorter than I thought going in and may be invalidated; 463 pages in my version), and this to be honest maybe my favorite of the year opening mission so far. A long, French, winding sentence filled, stream of consciousness novel is about as up my alley as it gets, and this met (and exceeded) every expectation.

Incredibly readable, despite its long, flowing sentences and general circling of the same ideas- I found this to be around the comprehensibility of like a Mrs Dalloway. And god, do these sentences rock, hitting every note of metaphor, description, and raw human feeling that feels like one is traveling the throughways of memory and emotion. I think this is my favorite version of this modernist comma filled style yet, which is hard to say as the world’s biggest Virginia Woolf fan. If I stopped to record or highlight every sentence that impressed me, that blew me away, I would never have finished this. So many scenes stand out, digging at those raw feelings and memories of the reader’s own; the cattleyas that lead to Swann and Odette making love for the first time, Swann’s discovery of music’s ability to move him again, the mother’s kiss before bed and all it provokes, the sight of the chrysanthemums leading to the first sight of Swann’s daughter and provoking the feelings in Marcel. And just as well, Proust partially dismantles his own myth-making in an incredible ending- the past is never exactly as we remember it, but shrouded in romanticism and self delusion, a fiction we created for itself.

Can’t think of a book so connected to and devoted to the human emotional experience, of sensory and social delights. It feels impossible for someone living today to write something like this, so in touch with the senses the experience at hand, as inundated and overloaded as our human minds are. There is plenty of propriety and overthinking and societal pressures that keep the characters from their happiness, but all of it is so deeply felt, heartwrenching, that feels hard to get at in today’s emotional landscape. And when Proust leans into societal humor, of buffoons and idiots and sanctimonious pricks, he hits a mark much deeper than simple satire, encompassing of the inner lives of those fools and also of the experience of making friends with them and reconfiguring your inner life so as to make peace with them to impress your girl. All of the chapter Swann in Love is just so, so good, the ups of falling in love, those beginning miracles, those attempts to hide the extent for propriety, the irrationality of it, the change of personality, and the fall, of jealousy and possession, of every denied affection, every moment spent obsessing over what is far away.

Can’t say enough about this book! One of those that makes you want to see the world in a different way, that makes you look back into your own memory and life with renewed appreciation and emotion, that makes you face your day to day experience with a human face rather than some abstracted layer of detachment/boredom. Easy 5 stars, and time will tell where this lands in the favorites list but it will be on there.

the_glass.title: The Glass Key
the_glass.author: Dashiell Hammett
the_glass.review: Hits all the hallmarks you’re looking for from a classic noir, moral and political corruption, tough guy protagonist, hysterical dames, snappy dialogue and a protagonist that’s always one step ahead. Going from reading Proust to reading this gave me whiplash in terms of where they sit on the prose spectrum; Hammett, as always, is sparse, to the point, letting dialogue, the plot and the few descriptions he allows give the story its color. Some of the descriptions are funny; loved hungover, beat down Beaumont turning varying degrees of yellow and green, and his ability to scheme even as his color degrades. Very little in the way of character motivation, which adds up to some extent; Beaumont is a man that at the end seems to be driven by little more than some strange obligation, not to a job, not to a man, not to some ideal, but to a task set in front of him that he can’t let go of until it’s done. Despite involving a Senator’s re-election, there’s no politics; everybody’s on the take, everyone is chasing money and power, it’s just a matter of who seizes it. Doesn’t quite hit the highest of highs of the genre but is a fine example of it.

the_fury.title: The Fury Out of Time
the_fury.author: Lloyd Biggle Jr.
the_fury.review:
The last book of my 2024, which means I reached my goal of 35 for the first time since 2021 (coming a very shameful 3 books short last year and one book short in 2022). For the first time since then, I can look back on a year and say it was a success instead of an embarrassing failure.

This was a pickup from the book store because I like the 60s/70s paperback sci fi aesthetic and it had a picture of a bug man on the cover. It delivered on both accounts- for the 60s aesthetic, the main character is said to be a misogynist by page 8 or 9, it involves a bit about the French being scared of rolling backpacks, and has some fun time travel paradoxes involving both past and future misaligning in the present, and on the bug men it concludes with a set of telepathic insects who travel the stars, are kind of lazy, and stick food directly into their stomachs rather than inefficiently chewing them. What more can you ask for from this sort of thing?

tarka_the.title: Tarka the Otter
tarka_the.author: Henry Williamson
tarka_the.review: Beautiful cover/book design by NYRB, and a really special piece of nature writing from the 1920s. Very matter of fact in the sense that it does not editorialize, or attempt to make you feel through histrionics or overly flowery writing about the otters themselves- it trusts that in immersing the reader in their lives, giving them a glimpse into their environment and how they live and interact with each other that those sympathies will arise organically. Humans are present only peripherally, as a threat to the otters- the “I” narrator arises maybe 2 or 3 times, and humans are mostly a generator of noise and fear, for the hunt is an ever present danger to the lives of these otters. This distance gives sight into what an unnatural force (particularly because the otters seem to have few other natural threats) humanity is, commanding land and instilling fear into all other creatures, leaving dead animals in their wake for little reason other than their finding satisfaction in cruelty. When humanity isn’t present, this gives a beautiful view of the countryside, the ecosystem and all the herons, cormorants, otters, fish, rodents, and others that make it up, and also of the lives of otters, their mating competitions and rituals, their play, their hunting, their child rearing.

there's_always.title: There's Always This Year: On Basketball and Ascension
there's_always.author: Hanif Abdurraqib
there's_always.review:
A poetic prose book about Ohio, leaving Ohio, basketball, and LeBron James is about as up as my alley as a thing can be, and I’m excited to say that this one lived up to my high hype of it. Have heard good things about the author but hadn’t picked up until he nailed the perfect confluence of my interests (and recorded a sweet hypeup video for the Timberwolves playoff run)

This book is about leaving and staying- about watching the planes fly leaving your city with your dad growing up, a city he would never leave and you wouldn’t leave until you were an adult, about Dan Gilbert’s Comic Sans letter, about the player from your neighborhood who was good enough to go to Kansas for college ball, about the hyped up player who was supposed to leave and flame out but never could, about finally getting out and driving 9 hours just so you can go back, about the songs pleading for someone to stay even if you know it’s best for them to stay. It’s about loving and respecting where you’re from, finding and writing the poetry that’s all your own, the court you played on, the block you grew up on, the local legends forgotten elsewhere, the hometown team that is a national laughingstock. Basketball is obviously a character, but this is far more about Ohio, about Columbus, about the parts of the country that the rest mock if they remember it exists and the parts in those states that are the ones even locals sneer at, call dangerous, overpoliced and underfed, the forgotten residents of the forgotten cities in the forgotten state.

The final chapter (the fourth quarter, as he calls it) is one of the most audacious things I read all year- at one point contrasting the iconic LeBron James Game 7 chasedown block with Columbus PD doing plainclothes drive by shootings on unarmed residents. The juxtaposition is stark (and dark) but ultimately effective, at least to me. Basketball is a community, basketball is beautiful, but it is ultimately a salve, the circus because there is no bread, a distraction from day to day life a country that will take your friend’s, your neighbor’s, a child with a toy gun’s life with impunity, that creates and maintains a race of second class citizen that only can achieve glory through athletic achievement and are otherwise demonized.

city_of.title: City of Quartz: Excavating the Future in Los Angeles
city_of.author: Mike  Davis
city_of.review:
Expansive and unorganized but pretty undeniable as an incredible history of Los Angeles- the a being important, as this by no means presents a cohesive narrative or a definitive history of LA, but rather a bunch of different histories of the sprawling, expansive city.

Davis’ main interest is in the image and power structures of the city, spending the first chapter detailing the competing visions of the city, from the earliest salesmen pitching a Spanish style oasis to yokel Midwesterners, to the noirs rifling through its seedy underbelly of crime and corruption, to European expats driven insane by the sunshine and the sprawl. A thread throughout is that Los Angeles is not a city built on industry, on manufacturing, but almost always purely on the backs of selling real estate.

The consequence of real estate as industry is evident- explaining the way homeowners fought tooth and nail to “protect” their investments from the “scourge” of apartments and anything to alleviate housing crises or traffic congestion, rejecting train lines and leading to the sprawl we all know and love in Los Angeles. Davis chronicles the rise of the home owner association as a political force, their odd merger with conservation agencies that ultimately score temporary wins over the developers, made politicians cater to their demands, and lead to long-term downstream effects for the whole state (i.e., frozen property taxes, the incorporation of small neighborhoods as separate cities to freeze the downtown out of tax revenue).

Part of the protection of real estate and property values is to keep neighborhoods segregated, to keep white separated from non-white, poor from rich. The dreams of a city where people of different neighborhoods and backgrounds and socioeconomic status all meet meets its end in Los Angeles, particularly in the hostile Downtown, where neighboring Skid Row homeless (or anyone not employed or shopping) are denied water, bathrooms, and subject to police harassment. Architecture is hostile, full of surveillance, uninviting to outsiders; even the libraries look like fortresses. When the factory jobs that had floated the black middle class went off-shore, Davis details how money went to police enforcement (and chronicles the rampant police overreach, pulling over something like 75% of black teenagers in South Central at various points in a campaign of terror, doing drug busts that turn up no drugs for PR for Nancy Reagan, prosecuting and demonizing parents for the drug use and gang affiliations of their children) instead of social programs, how little effort went to education or jobs for the impoverished inner city, and the rise of gangs as neighborhood protection in the stead of any other outlet for the poor.

The Catholic church is also a focus; its primarily poor Latino base, and the ways they are alienated from the centers of power and their goals are sidelined. Maybe the most interesting character of the book is Luis Olivares, a Catholic priest who opens up his pews to house the homeless and fights battles with the city over the unhoused before the Irish Catholic power base shuttles him off. The balance between the Latino rank and file and the richer, whiter money donators rarely goes the way of the common Catholic.

He ends in Fontana, his hometown and perhaps a microcosm of the nature of Los Angeles. First, sold as a dream away from the city, yet close enough to the city for jobs, where one could have chickens and grow vegetables; then, as steel town, where the toxic fumes from the mill killed all the chickens and vegetables; then, after selling the city’s financial future off to developers, as a commuter town for those looking to escape big city life while still working the big city job. It is an encapsulation of the Los Angeles project as a whole; endlessly adaptable, ultimately only hinging on real estate, no promise made to its citizens kept the second there’s a profit to be made out of it.

All of it ends up feeling connected, even if the threads as they’re flying by can feel separated from the pack. Davis’ prose is alive, cutting with cynicism yet also a very real understanding of the material conditions and characters making the decisions along the way. For a lengthy book of history, I found myself never bored, constantly wanting to return to it and talk about it more. Have been reading more and more history of late and this is my favorite one yet.

rejection.title: Rejection
rejection.author: Tony Tulathimutte
rejection.review:
This book inspired the most hate I’ve ever experienced for something that I ended up sort of liking. There was portions of this that inspired Ready Player One types of vitriol from me; partially, because I knew this author was capable of so much better from the other two stories in the collection.

First, the bad; there’s a middle section of short stories here that I found to be actively bad. One, the Ahegao one, actually starts out reasonably promising, and I think in its early stages has some interesting ideas about brains and sexualitys curdling when only exposed to pornography and the internet and being totally unable to be fulfilled in the real world. Tulathimutte then escalates this to an absurd degree, and then keeps escalating and escalating; usually, this is my favorite kind of bit, but at a certain point the bit ran its way into tedium that lasted for several pages as the shock factor and ideas felt like they had been achieved already but the story kept on running and running.
