The next story then follows with a white guy tech CEO talking in intentionally bad used Internet/young people slang, which is a bit that can work well in a very small dose but far too long for an long short story. Again, there’s interesting ideas in that, power using youth and slang (poorly) in order to try to cover up their old money machinations to the point of self-delusion on their ownbehavior but again, the bit escalates into tedium rather than further absurdity (for me at least), which is a very bad sign and left me wondering whether I could finish this book. These two were clearly meant to exhaust the reader to some extent, but the purpose they served did not pay off in my opinion.

Now for the good; a decent chunk of these I enjoyed! “The Feminist” I read ages ago in n+1 but has been a modern classic for me for a number of years. Tulathimutte has a rare gift of capturing contemporary self-delusion, as mixed as it is with faux self-awareness, therapy speak, trying to align the personal with some abstract political goal (and using it as a weapon against those who don’t work in your favor), trying to match the real messy reactions of life with some idealized chill reaction to them. His characters are stuck in these fascinating mind mazes as they try to navigate and contort around the world not bending their whims, and watching the mental gymnastics and neuroses play out is wonderful when it’s firing on all cylinders. The second to last full short story, while immensely Twitter brained, is perhaps the most interesting of the bunch, one I think I’ll be turning in my head quite a bit- the nullification of identity, giving into the blob of the Internet, itself a spectacle of fake arguments, fake discourse, fake ideas all colliding, leaving you breathless reading it and totally detached from any sense of material reality. Not sure exactly when it was written, but scrolling through the replies of any post on Twitter at this post will make you feel it more acutely. He of course then plays more sort of annoying meta-fictional games after that, writing a rejection letter to his own novel where he psychoanalyzes himself, because he can’t end on a purely good note. Tulathimutte is a talent, one to follow, but for now he’s maybe a little too enmeshed in the cultures/ideas he’s critiquing to fully escape their reach into his own brain and writing.

the_plot.title: The Plot (The Book Series, #1)
the_plot.author: Jean Hanff Korelitz
the_plot.review: Listened to the last half on audiobook on the way back from Thanksgiving, so feel free to take my opinion with a grain of salt. This one has some fun elements, although possibly against its will; the Bond villain-esque final monologue of the antagonist, the Southern lawyer written in the most stereotypical way, the constant repeated references to the word plot. But god does it take its facile thoughts on who “owns” stories seriously, and god does the author think they cooked coming up with the plot to the fictional story within the story that kind of sucks. More time on trashy thriller stuff please, far less time trying to give this a pretense to literaryness.

the_recognitions.title: The Recognitions
the_recognitions.author: William Gaddis
the_recognitions.review:
Mike’s Big Book to start 2024 is finally complete, the second longest one to date at 956 pages (Ducks, Newburyport still takes the cake at 1022). Took me almost 3 whole months but it is officially done and dusted (and reviewed almost 9 months later as the year closes- embarrassing!).

The Recognitions is obviously branching and wide in scope, tackling a massive amount of time and parts of the world, topics going from Mithratic sun worship to How To Win Friends and Influence People. Its main character, if there can be said to be one, is an art counterfeiter, a tortured Puritan who can only make excellent fakes in both style and material, miming both the substance of the art style and the long degraded paints. It features one of the most self-loathing self inserts I’ve seen in a long time, an evil man named Recktall Brown, counterfeiters, rubes, and a Puritan preacher who becomes obsessed becomes a Mithriast yet retains his post, spewing his beliefs to a crowd who nods along in compliance even as he strays further and further from their truth.

At its core is a crisis of originality and authenticity, of characters striving for and being crushed by the need to feel as if they are fresh, their own creation, a unique snowflake that stands out to all in the midst of the torrential downpour of humanity (if it sounds like a New York novel, it is). Mommy and daddy issues abound, crying out for recognition (ha!) from an absent figure to validate their meaning and existence. In place of authenticity, as characters grapple with their own emptiness, they turn to fraud, to lies, to gross exaggerations in order to bridge the gap between their own existence and the one they wish for themselves.

Gaddis as a stylist is obviously a highlight for much of it, with my favorite portions of this being any scene of heavy dialogue/the party scenes. The winding nature of conversations, repeated lines to different parties, what amounts to basically meaningless and mindless chatter upon chatter, makes those scenes feel alive and real (and miserable). As with any 900 page novel that is as good as this is, I was crushed by my stupidity, my own bad memory, my inability to understand references (and my own inability to write this in time to actually remember things about it), but also awestruck by the scope and nerve of this thing. As with all big books, I can’t say I recommend it but I’m glad I read it.

the_secret.title: The Secret Agent
the_secret.author: Joseph Conrad
the_secret.review:
Been a minute since I read The Man Who Was Thursday, but very interesting that that and this come out a year apart when they are at least very superficially similar- regarded British authors tackling infiltration and espionage on anarchists. What was happening in England in 1906/07? Sure to be fuel for a Wikipedia deep dive, as I always think of that as an American specialty, and one deeper into the 1900s than this time period.

Have mixed feelings about this one I’d say- some of it related to Conrad’s prose, which is elegant when it works but at times in this one (perhaps more due to what’s happening on the page than the fault of the sentences themselves) feels verbose and elongated. There’s a lot of bloviating in this one, both external and internal, and not all of it feels necessary or intriguing even if it is well-written. That being said, the moments where it does land are some of the best chapters I’ve read this year- the Mister Verloc/Winnie chapter, where Verloc’s monologue of self-regard, paternalistic misogyny, and laziness boils over to farcical levels and she slowly comes to grips with the monster in front of her and the depths of despair she has been plunged into by her so-called protector simultaneously is really phenomenal.

The stereotypes for left-wing organizations haven’t changed a lot in 100 or so years (and neither has their relative harmlessness). That’s always fun to see.

the_word.title: The Word for World Is Forest
the_word.author: Ursula K. Le Guin
the_word.review: A little light on complication/depth from what I’m used to from LeGuin, although Vietnam and anti-colonialism is about as good an excuse as there is to be direct and on the nose with it. Second half picks up a little in its thoughts on the changes resisting the human occupation will bring to the society and the uncertain future they hold, and yet still the necessity of resisting anyway. Love seeing evil Space Vietnam corporal betrayed by his own men.

the_hour.title: The Hour of the Star
the_hour.author: Clarice Lispector
the_hour.review:
Lispector manages to pack so much into this under 100 page work; it works simultaneously as a takedown of upper class fetishization and noble savageization of the poor and as at least a partial romanticization of the humble simple life of her own upbringing in the lower class, although I think layered in are plenty of complex feelings on that as well. And the upper class narrator/writer is not merely a one sided source of critique, either; even if Lispector is clearly critical of his methods/intention in telling the story within the story, it’s also clear that by the experience of writing the story of Macabea he is learning something, about himself, about his life, about death.

Filled with all sorts of symbolism and meaning that’s beyond me to some extent- Macabea as a typist, writing out the whims of other people (poorly), while the writer struggles to find or commit to his own words; moments before death, the greatest encounter with life; her inability to vomit, until the climatic moment of joy, car crash, and death all collide- every word feels purposeful yet mysterious, suggestive of abstract meaning and symbolism so characteristic of her work.

Found some of the meta fictional stuff at the beginning a little tiresome on first read but once this gets rolling this fires on all cylinders like few things I’ve read before it.

collapse_the.title: Collapse: The Fall of the Soviet Union
collapse_the.author: Vladislav M. Zubok
collapse_the.review:
Pretty immaculately laid out history of the fall of the Soviet Union; coming to it from not knowing it a ton about the fall, found it compelling to read through and didn’t present at least too skewed or slanted a viewpoint in one direction or another (although I suspect the USA is painted a tad too innocently in the way they influenced things here).

The man at the heart is Mikhail Gorbachev, who this book gently lays out as a man who really wants to be smart but is actually quite dumb. The project of resurrecting the Soviet economy, of keeping the disparate collection of states together, of opening the Union up and not maintaining the iron fist of the past, was certainly not one that was easy, but at every turn Gorbachev seems to take the step most likely to accelerate the Union’s (and his own) downfall. From banning liquor sales and in so doing tanking the nation’s tax base, to giving the states power that encourages separatist movements and that they use to make operating the Union basically impossible, to making concessions to the West on foreign policy without extracting anything but a set of empty promises, his every move is one in the wrong direction. Reading Lenin will only get you so far if the reader is a dummy, it turns out. The “comedy” of this book is often in Gorbachev’s arrogance, his disbelief that he could be wrong or bamboozled in any way; I don’t have the book anymore (shoutout San Diego Public Library), but perhaps my favorite moment is when Gorbachev gives a quote along the lines of “Gorbachev’s final act has not yet arrived” right before he is unseated permanently and banished to the dust bin of history.

If there’s a perfect foil to Gorbachev, it is Boris Yeltsin, the alcoholic nationalist (who just really wants American love) with no real plans other than unseating the Union and a Russian state all of its own. He is able to grandstand his way to the top because of the weakness of conviction of the existing state, both in ideas (the constant waffling economy, the unclear vision for a federalist or confederacy of states) and in willingness to wield power (the coup that unseats Gorbachev originally allowing him to grand stand in the capital and earn popular support shows the fear to wield force in any way that permeated the state at the time due to the horrors of Stalinism and the 60s).

He hints at an interesting alternate history of the 1990s/21st century; one where Russia takes over China’s place as a manufacturer of consumer goods for the West- this is, of course, where the two countries diverge, Russia going with the Chilean/University of Chicago method of “shocking” the economy by jumping straight to the free market, China doing an easing that protected both its citizens and the production of the country. When the USA went looking, Russia was too much in disarray, its economy in shambles, unable to produce even if asked; meanwhile, China was ready, and in doing so became a world superpower. If the Union had stayed together, it’s hard to say what would have happened; but this book at least points to what led to its collapse, and what current conflicts stemmed from this moment (crazy to see every single origin of the Russian-Ukrainian war coming from agreements made at the collapse, mostly because Yeltsin was just in a hurry to seize power and take over the Union), as well as what disasters were averted in the process (nukes running amok). The USSR’s eagerness to join wit the West is another fascinating divergence in history, one that can only lead to speculation and alternate histories, one of countless ones this book lays out.

they_a.title: They: A Sequence of Unease
they_a.author: Kay Dick
they_a.review: Doesn’t go for more direct, applicable metaphors, which is why it’s probably largely forgotten, but also why I think it’s much better than something like Fahrenheit 451. The shape of the mobs of they aren’t defined clearly, their exact operation and shape murky, the only thing known the people they institutionalize, the arms they take, the books they steal- at brief times it feels like a metaphor for political suppression, but mostly for the suppression of creative force and life of beauty, of being alienated from the world and by beauty by a society and a people that doesn’t value it, that recoils at the sight of what they deny themselves. Certain shorts here resonate for their enigmaticness- particularly the one at the miller, but the long meandering visit to a friend also sticks with me a tad. Absolutely worth a read if you’re into the dystopian science fiction heavy hitters.

a_complicated.title: A Complicated Kindness
a_complicated.author: Miriam Toews
a_complicated.review:
Have complicated feelings about this one- there are parts I really enjoyed, and parts that fell a bit flat to me. I think the strongest, most realized parts are inside the familial unit, particularly of the main character Nomi and her father after they’ve been left by both her sister and her mother. This dynamic, of daughter bound by obligation to not leaving him alone to live in a place she hates, scared of what a life that she doesn’t hate could look like, and of defeated father, too committed to his faith to ever leave the church or the town, too broken and withdrawn to try to find a way to fully engage with his daughter, felt realized to me. The relationship between her and her boyfriend is a tad cliche, all frolicking in fields and rolling through hills with puppy love, but the moments of teenage awkwardness and inability to communicate make it feel slightly more realized than a few well-worn images, and it fits some of what it’s going for- without religion, she only knows to look for an idealized image- as represented by her repeated vision of hanging out with Lou Reed in New York.

My issue with it is how the town feels- for a town that is defined both internally and externally by the conservative, over the top religion, it doesn’t actually feel all that religious? There are mentions, to be sure- husbands can’t sit with their excommunicated wives, the school has restrictive dress codes, etc., but Nomi basically goes on months long bender and there is little backlash from the community leading up to her eventual excommunication. There appears to be a thriving party scene, sexual promiscuity, cool haircuts- all things that could certainly exist, for sure, but also ones that would drive much more widespread judgement and notice from the community (at least in my experience/view). There’s definitely an aspect of the town, so rundown and hopeless, that isn’t actively practicing their faith the way they present, but in my experience that makes the judgement stronger.

That said, there’s parts of this that really resonated. The ending of Nomi leaving behind the church felt very real- so free, yet so ill equipped to deal with it, the terrifying notion of starting your life and your mind anew, your previous rebellion just a lashing out and way of observing the religion in its own way. The narration is pretty funny and I liked her as a character generally, even if parts of this lulled for me/didn't fully connect.

city_of.title: City of Saints and Madmen (Ambergris, #1)
city_of.author: Jeff Vandermeer
city_of.review:
After being thrown head first (because I read the third book of the trilogy first) into the world of Ambergris and really loving it, I figured I’d go back to the start, and, man, it turns out there’s a reason they ordered the books the way they did. This one is more than just world building, the book, but if I were to describe it to someone it would be as a vibe collage of a crazy science fiction city/world (which the third book does not really slow down much to explain; to be clear, I loved that too).

There’s aspects that I didn’t love of this; perhaps I was ready to move on by the time it arose, but the meta in text “Jeff Vandermeer” element didn’t do a lot for me (although I don’t think it was without value, and could see a reread bearing dividends). But basically everything else hit for me; I loved the mixed text style, from histories to tracts to in universe fiction, all of it coalescing into a vision of Ambergris that feels like the version in your head that you get from reading about a place and never actually visiting; flitting vibes, contradictory ideas, wisps of an image forming in your head that reality simultaneously could never live up to but also could not be captured by. It is rare I think to see a world this fully realized by an author who also understands that the world building has to be in service of something other than cool theoretical world on the page, and Vandermeer really excels here at that, with stylistic flourishes and ideas all over the page. Favorites are the history of the gray caps, the mannequin in the window story, the squid tales, but all of it (with the exception of the meta closing) rally landed with me. Excited for the second book of the trilogy!

the_yiddish.title: The Yiddish Policemen's Union
the_yiddish.author: Michael Chabon
the_yiddish.review:
More detectives in vaguely science fictional worlds, more five stars, what can I say I like what I like. This one eschews mushroom people for an alternate history where the USA allocates a portion of Alaska as a Jewish homeland; the Middle Eastern one we know today is under Arab control.

I will say that the world of this alternate history is what really sold me on it (and isn’t that what one of the things a detective story is really good for, a tour of every element of a world, a mystery that comprises a society itself); the huge amounts of Yiddish slang throughout, the religious fundamentalist black hats and their mafia-like organization and messianic ambitions, the casual historical asides (Berlin getting nuked in 1948 is thrown in as casually and with less detail than a description of a really good pie shop), the stabilized but simmering conflicts between indigenous and Jewish peoples, the scramble of the government to keep the lights on as the once autonomous homeland now prepares to be reverted back to the state of Alaska. Throw some COINTELPRO and CIA tampering in there, and you have an all-time combination of Mike-core elements here, but beyond the elements sounding intriguing it’s really quite impressive how well thought out and constructed this world feels.

The main character is an amalgamation of detective tropes, hard drinking, sad about his ex wife, having a more reliable muscle for a partner, depressed about the world, bad at his job now but god he used to be the best…we all know the type at this point. I didn’t find a ton about him compelling, but the side characters are the squeeze here- our murder victim, the lost messiah, is I think the real best portion of it, and much of the action is chasing his shadow.

Reads definitely like a literary author taking on the detective genre (positive), all grimness and grime dressed up in plenty of literary flourishes. Perhaps the closest it comes to The City and The City in the way it builds a world around the keepings of the detective novel and style that I’ve read to date, which is about as high a praise as it comes from me.

“These are strange times to be a Jew,” is the oft-repeated line of the book, and maybe what is revolves around- an alternate homeland, one at the very least less politically sensitive and defined by outside threats than the current one, still sits on the precipice of dissolving, flinging a once-united Jewish people all across the globe, as far as Madagascar. Chabon is a critic of the existing state of Israel, but he also lays out a literal chess board in this novel where there is no good move left to play, which applies to plenty of the characters but also the nation itself; no way to build a homeland without displacing someone else; no way to come onto the global stage at that time without being at the mercy of powers beyond your own. Strange times to be a Jew indeed (and I’m sure there’s plenty of other stuff on Jewish identity that this dumb goy missed).

modern_love.title: Modern Love
modern_love.author: Constance DeJong
modern_love.review: This one has slipped from memory almost entirely- the connection to Kathy Acker (and sick book design) is what drew me in, but from what I remember it does fragmented/disparate narratives tying things across centuries (past and future) but without the prose style/transgressiveness to really lock me in like Acker has done in the past. Still, some beautiful sentences in here, and captures modern (and past and possible future) anxieties and heartbreaks and power struggles pretty well. I probably need to revisit this one when I’m not traveling as it’s pretty distant at this point.

masters_of.title: Masters of Atlantis
masters_of.author: Charles Portis
masters_of.review: Behind every conspiracy theorist lies a lonely weirdo just looking to wear funny hats, be special, and make some friends. A meandering tale of a cult, from dumbass being conned by a homeless guy into starting a cult, to Joel Osteenification, to calcification into a small group of committed, lazy nuts, to playing dominos in a trailer to play out the string of life with little care for the beliefs that defined their life. Typically out on comedy as literature but this is jam packed with scenes of absurdity and genuine funny stuff- Popper stamping Golescu’s cards is maybe the highlight, but there’s so many good moments milked from this collection of dumbasses that it’s hard to pick out a favorite. Love the court scene towards the end that basically recaps decades of their buffoonery while also making those actually worried about them (which probably includes the readers) look stupid for ever taking them seriously in any form or fashion. Didn’t get too much out of it other than the laughs, the style is pretty to the point, but still a great time.

simple_passion.title: Simple Passion
simple_passion.author: Annie Ernaux
simple_passion.review:
An interesting little 60 pages (and of course, very French)- 60 pages of a married man having an affair with the author, with precious little of the actual man (or of the actual woman)- she even calls it a book not about him, nor about her, but about the feeling itself, an all-consuming passion that overrides all else, a longing in their separation that replaces all other passions. An interesting little project, to make about book about loving the other with precious little of the other or of the self in it- love almost as an all-consuming, destructive force, not controllable by the party afflicted by its sting. And then, all of the sudden, the storm breaks, and normal life comes rolling back in.

“When I was a child, luxury was fur coats, evening dresses, and villas by the sea. Later on, I thought it meant leading the life of an intellectual. Now I feel that it is also being able to live out a passion for a man or a woman.”

the_winter.title: The Winter of Our Discontent
the_winter.author: John Steinbeck
the_winter.review: The overarching plots of this one (and basically every Steinbeck I’ve read) are blunt, to the point; man is happy despite humble circumstances, man seeks to gain power/money/influence, in doing so man is undone. But the tangles are always what make it, the details, and this one has it in spades; the incredible dialogue (how many pet names does our main character have for his wife), building out a very distinct character, so charming and full of bluster that you start rooting for him even as he moves into bad moral waters. The ambiguity of the telling, leaving out character plans and motivations, as if the impact of his actions and his own plans are a mystery to himself until the very last, guided by a hand outside himself on a purely unconscious, fate plane. His end is not announced, but felt, making even as its obvious the direction this is heading the reader still thinks it can’t be, wishes against it. The beauty of it evokes of a tranquil Eastern coastline, even as it is corrupted by the ghosts of the past and the clawing threat of the money soon to barge in, used to devastating effect in an ending that I won’t shake easily. Great stuff!

chronosis.title: Chronosis
chronosis.author: Reza Negarestani
chronosis.review: Have never read a comic book before, so this is the first! Astute observers of Mike’s GoodReads have seen him derailed by the book Cyclonopedia, a philosofictional tale of big words and oil as Cthulhian elder gods that has entire chapters that he can’t make any sense of. This was an attempt to take another stab at Iranian philosopher Reza Negarestani in a medium that might make his insights more friendly to Mike’s small brain. Sadly, this one, centered on time, also proved confusing, but the art here is sick and mind bending and reading through philosophical madness about time while looking at cool pictures of lizard people, space travel, conspiracy wackjobs, and a world-consuming manifestation of time is about as cool of an experience as you can have with a book in your hands.

middlesex.title: Middlesex
middlesex.author: Jeffrey Eugenides
middlesex.review:
One Hundred Years Of Spanakopita. A book I found totally infuriating and also pretty captivating at times- Eugenides can write, for sure, and plenty of this I found stirring on both a prose level and on character setup/narrative progression/historical narrative level. The voice of Cal is super compelling and entertaining to read, and it got me through this book despite some of the ways it made me want to put it down.

Now the ways it made me cringe. I’m all for historical fiction, something that teaches you about history as it traverses its narrative- I’d say most of the things I like are doing some version of that. However, this one has some of the most eyerolling instances of shoehorning history with narrative I’ve ever seen- the reveal of Zizmo has the founder of the Nation of Islam made me put the book down wholesale with how just generally lazy and inconsiderate of the history it was working with was. Everything in Detroit can’t just happen around them, but has to be deeply rooted in the characters already placed in the story. It feels lazy, which is another complaint- some of the lines, some of the arcs here, just feel lazy. I think Eugenides generally does a good job handling gender in this, especially given it was written 20 years ago, and even felt some of the elements of Cal’s transition and experience of it are interesting. But god, do you really need to put lines about how men’s bathrooms are stinky and women’s bathrooms smell like flowers? Of course Cal’s brother goes away to college and comes back a hippie who despises the small business owner father; that’s fine and good, but do I need his girlfriend moaning during sex about tearing down dad’s private property? There’s a few elements also where Eugenides sneaks in political commentary that feels like Twitter commentators putting it in their children’s mouths- 8 year old Cal calling the Detroit riots “the Second American Revolution” feels like Ruthkanda Forever in novel form, even if it’s a take I find interesting and probably agree with. I can go on with more examples, but at the end of the day Eugenides feels like he lost faith in the story he’s telling being compelling on its own terms and felt the need to both spice up the history and embellish on the details to appeal to some mythical normal reading.

With that long paragraph of hate aside, I did like lots of this! Its ending swept me away in the way it tied together years of history both personal and cultural, of tragedies passed down (quite literally, in terms of the chromosome in Cal’s body) from generation to generation! It’s a good book! I’m just a hater and I have to live with it.

underground_the.title: Underground: The Tokyo Gas Attack and the Japanese Psyche
underground_the.author: Haruki Murakami
underground_the.review:
Has very little relation to anything I’ve read or heard of in Murakami’s repetoire; for a writer so distinctive, with such a singular voice, to melt into the page is a very interesting choice and feat. There are moments where he allows himself to let loose with his writing, but only when the moment calls for it; his handling and writing of the disabled victim, hardly able to communicate for herself, is one of the most emotionally devastating things put to the page, full of grace and respect and dignity for someone fighting to recover to be themself again. It’s all filled with such respect for humanity, of what is to be human, the things that sparked her joy, the choices and sacrifice and commitments and love she gave to her family, the choices that define a life, it’s really quite inspiring. That the family allowed it and Murakami dealt with it in such a sensitive manner is such a remarkable combination; those two chapters absolutely ruined me, and would make this a special book even if I didn’t like the rest as much as I did. It’s a shame that this book seems to be filed under minor Murakami because I sincerely doubt he ever wrote anything better.

Murakami says at some point that he wrote this in part to try to understand Japan better; and I think this does a good job of establishing the everyday before the devastation, mundanity crossed with terror, the socioeconomic climate of Japan at the time in the wake of bubbles bursting and prosperity for its citizens in serious doubt in the wake of a recession, as well as the mundanity continuing around them, people foaming at the mouth as people push by to get to work. One wants to draw lines between that mundane everyday and the second half, of the cult arising and eventually turning to terrorism, but the interviewees don’t draw that connection for you- at most, one can infer a lack of spirituality in the culture at large, pushing those with a natural predilection, who feel something missing, to the fringes of society. I found this second section of cult members much less interesting, even if it’s superficially more fascinating; perhaps the lack of answer, how and why this could happen, could never satisfy, or perhaps Murakami was more inspired and qualified to comment on the everyday rather than the extraordinary nature of the cult.

out_stealing.title: Out Stealing Horses
out_stealing.author: Per Petterson
out_stealing.review: Didn’t love this necessarily, a little cinematic in the writing for me, but has a very defined mood/register that I think it pulls off pretty phenomenally (and I don’t think it’s an easy one to hit). The whole thing is suffocated with dread, the idea that something horrible and traumatic is going to happen, it feels almost like a horror experience at times- the knee injury while they’re transporting the lumber feels almost like a director holding the camera in place while the audience waits for a jump scare, yet nothing bad actually happens. The real horror is a life spent watching other people live their lives while you just kind of pass through mindlessly, staring in the mirror at the back of your own head, unable to know yourself (a painting it directly references), leading to a final chapter of escape to the woods to work on a cabin so that you can die alone. Enough of this has stuck with me a few months from reading it that I have to respect it even if I didn’t come out of it thinking of it as a favorite.

the_castle.title: The Castle
the_castle.author: Franz Kafka
the_castle.review:
Can understand after reading this how it stayed unfinished- there’s a lot here that’s evocative, meaningful, affecting, but also the lines of a narrative that ends in any way that is satisfying or completes are tough to piece together. As is, a sentence that cuts off midway, the main character leaning in to listen to something that will bring him no closer to any answer, is probably the most fitting ending that this could have.

When this clicks, I found this super evocative- the weirdness and paranoia of a society and social conventions that seem backwards, the reaching at an authority that the world is designed to keep you from, that may not exist at all, or at least not in a form that you are expecting it. This book put me in strange, alienated moods. When it’s off, it can feel like a chore- there’s a few conversations in here that feel like they take an eternity, this book is just page after page of people talking for the most part and when it doesn’t hit right it really doesn’t hit right.

Some really wonderful imagery and humor here- loved all the shuffling of papers, be it in the house of the village mayor or with the high ranking officials at the village inn. Bureaucratic competence, the idea of power and authority with intention and meaning, is an illusion we all co-create, from those in it all the way to the low ranking villager. The descriptions of goofball assistants acting like puppy dogs and scorned pets before revealing it all to be an act is a great gag too.

blindsight_(firefall,.title: Blindsight (Firefall, #1)
blindsight_(firefall,.author: Peter Watts
blindsight_(firefall,.review:
I'm a sucker for anything vaguely horror related in space, so willing to overlook some nitpicks about prose to give this one the highest honor. Watts is a PhD in a science field, and it shows for ways both good and bad- a little too much nerdy hard sci fi stuff in here, but also a wide range of knowledge that allows him to delve deeper into the possibilities presented by evolution and the nature of consciousness.

There's plenty of interesting angles on consciousness in here, but they can all go in a textbook if the imagery and the vibes of this don't come together. Luckily, they do- the ever expanding crown of thorns of the alien spaceship, the hallucinations lurking in the shadows of the crew's explorations, the tentacled aliens stalking them and experimented on- they all, along with the slow trickle of discoveries, create an atmosphere of horrified curiosity that carries the reader through and becomes even more effective when that atmosphere turns inward on the crew and their motivations.

The future of Blindsight is one of increased technology, humans literally getting brain surgery to make them less human, to remove unpleasant memories, turn their processing into a supercomputer and in the process remove their capacity for human emotions, sex had solely online and never in the flesh, humans going to the 'Heaven' of an online server and leaving their body and their friends and lovers behind. Vampires are real, and have been tamed to serve human needs- but their consciousness is not like ours, having no sense of past or future, no real sense of self. Despite their attempts to remove it, humans have their consciousness, are still trapped to the almighty 'I', even in light of their efforts to distance themselves surgically- and this proves to be a weakness against the alien crawlers, who have no consciousness but are remarkably intelligent, all the brain power devoted to maintaining a self-image loosened to cultivate collective intelligence, to problem solve at levels we cannot comprehend. The humans have no hope to overwhelm the intelligence once forced to come into conflict with it- the end is only them suicide bombing the alien ship, mutually assured destruction by two types of brain that cannot make sense of the others- the human attempt at language and communication a hostile attack for the aliens, the alien layout totally incomprehensible to the human brain.

Of course, the end has our protagonist making his way back to Earth, his humanity restored in hostile fashion by the crew, only to discover that humanity has been overtaken by the vampires, their consciousness remaining their undoing as the higher evolved vampires overtake them on the planet, leaving Siri (yes, that's the protagonist's name) the lone human, the last conscious being floating along in space alone. It creates an emotional moment, the last being feeling the end for human connection alone in space, and an interesting juxtaposition: our protagonist, who imploded relationships and desired to return to what he was before surgery triumphantly understanding what it was to be human again, feeling again and regaining a purer form of consciousness all while humanity as a whole has seemingly gone extinct due to that same consciousness. It's a swirl of mixed emotions, one that evokes how I imagine Watts feels about consciousness: a horror, a beauty, the possibilities for beauty and connection and cruelty and pain all colliding. Doing so evocatively at the close of a novel that is compelling on a storytelling basis as well is an impressive feat.

the_doors.title: The Doors of Perception
the_doors.author: Aldous Huxley
the_doors.review: Interesting, especially from a historical perspective, but if I'm going to read a trip report I'm still going to use my tried and true method (searching the word 'salvia' on /r/drugs). Huxley's prose really shines in some of the descriptions that visit him on mescaline, and his philosophical digressions about Buddhist concepts, the inner vs. the outer world, and the interaction between the psychedelic and the religious are worth it for a read that can be done in an afternoon.

finch_(ambergris,.title: Finch (Ambergris, #3)
finch_(ambergris,.author: Jeff Vandermeer
finch_(ambergris,.review:
This made me realize that if you put a detective in a science fiction setting I’m probably gonna love it no matter what- this is maybe (don’t quote me on it) my favorite book I’ve read this year. I decided for whatever reason to read this one first despite it being third in the trilogy- I think that added to the experience, of being thrown in to a case and a world that the context and details of are slowly revealed as I go along. I’ll go back to read the others, but I recommend this one on its own terms.

As far what I loved about, it’s the type of gonzo sci-fi I tend to go, mushroom men taking over the world and trying to build a tower in the middle of the city, spewing mushroom drugs to a sedated populace, having the ability to turn men into mushroom hybrids with the memories of other humans. A case with two bodies unidentifiable, possibly from other dimensions- the ability to take a mushroom that will transport you to moments of their life, possibly last moments. A dark, gritty, wet, sopping city with a great deal of thought into its history, its character, the backdrop of its past running into the actions of the characters of the present to the unwritten future of it. Some crazy collapsing of time twists going on throughout. Police for an occupying regime, caught in the middle of making a living and what they believe, the reclamation of the city- the struggle for the city’s freedom not the only force fighting to be free, an indigenous population who believes both competing ideals are illegitimate.

Definitely falls into some detectivey hardass tropes, but 1.) I love those tropes and 2.) the sci fi world and the way it expands with the case/plot is really phenomenal. This one turned me from a pretty hardcore Vandermeer skeptic (I like but don’t love Annihilation; the other two books of the trilogy I found middling; his twitter when it isn’t animals is annoying) into a fan almost instantly.

what_is.title: What IS Sex?
what_is.author: Alenka Zupančič
what_is.review:
Plenty of psychoanalytic mumbo jumbo here to make me squint my eyes and say “what?” at for chapters at a time, but also, found plenty of interesting ideas at play here and when this became lucid I found it to be a pretty good exploration of sexuality as a concept. I’m still no closer to being able to answer the question in the title, though. Some concepts I found interesting that I recall, a few months on:

- the idea that there is no “sexual relation;” that what we think of it is merely comprised of different drives and needs that we flatten down into one area
- in a section about the “animal” vs the human, there’s a lot of blurring and tearing down of the lines; however, really enjoyed the thoughts on how it feels good to hunger, and that an animal may not understand that- that feeling desire and need and longing can be a good feeling
- that shame around sexuality comes around due to feeling of embarrassment around lacking knowledge; that somewhere out there there is knowledge you don’t have access to, and it’s shameful to ask/experiences happen to you in negative ways because you lack that knowledge and thus you feel shame.
- A digression about the inclusion of belly buttons in paintings of the Garden of Eden to discuss how most everything ties back into sexuality
- A really well-written portion, about how romance and attraction and sexuality does not arise around well-ordered, logical reasoning of a match that “makes sense,” but around mysteries, around someone finding new ways to surprise you
- Some good stuff around Christianity in relation to the body and pain and fetishizing that pain, but not celebrating sexuality
- There was some good explanations of Freud's pleasure principle that has already left my brain (I may revisit the second I finish this one up)

the_electric.title: The Electric State
the_electric.author: Simon Stålenhag
the_electric.review: Had never really picked up an art book before and this one turned out to be a pretty good intro as the art is right up my alley. The movie The Creator cribs a lot of visual elements from this/Stalenhag in general, which was at first a draw to this book until I saw the movie (which is very bad, albeit with some cool visual elements). The combination of rusted out American detritus/decay and futuristic almost cyberpunk robots/signage/aesthetics is a super fruitful contrast/combination. I got it from the library, so I was taking pictures all over the place of the images I found most evocative and really in cases haunting. The writing is fine as window dressing/context for the art but not worth writing home about or seeking out on its own.

the_age.title: The Age of Wood: Our Most Useful Material and the Construction of Civilization
the_age.author: Roland Ennos
the_age.review: Rare DNF- on point for the first bit where it’s describing evolution into humans and early tooling, but when it gets too deep into boat descriptions and sawing techniques is where it lost me. Could use more diagrams and the like to make it clearer to the visually challenged (aka me). The joys of book club picks (can say I learned things here I wouldn’t have otherwise, but not a book I would have picked on my own)

chinatown.title: Chinatown
chinatown.author: Thuận
chinatown.review: Is a very much up my alley premise- stream of consciousness, all one paragraph, big beautiful flowing sentences, plenty of repetition, set in a train station with a mother floating the in the miasma of her memories- but for whatever reason this one just didn’t click all the way for me. There’s some lovely things happening- the universality of heartbreak despite the intricate cultural and individual specificities of each one, the fractures and prejudices and experiences of life as the socialist states began to split off from each other, and plenty of the specificities of Vietnamese life as diaspora and in their home country (particularly centered on anti-Chinese prejudice after the war). But on the whole, found myself maybe a little overwhelmed by the repetition and lacking maybe a little abstractness from what I hoped from the premise- entirely possible it’s a lost in translation thing. This one ended up being just good instead of great.

the_city.title: The City of Unspeakable Fear
the_city.author: Jean Ray
the_city.review: Has a hell of a back cover hook of “mystery or horror story, you decide”, and does a lot of interesting things at once- small town where nothing is at it seems, detective chasing down inexplicable seemingly supernatural deaths and disappearances, guys telling spooky stories in rainy rooms, bumbling detective stumbling his way into clues, Flemish author who’s never been to England writing a loving ode to Dickens and England- but somehow this never seemed to click into focus for me, I think in part because it never allowed itself to commit to one vibe, one atmosphere, or even really to its procedural elements. Parts of this dazzled me- the final chapter is a beautiful evocation of the indifference of the supernatural, some of the ghost tales were good, some of the detective stuff was genuinely funny to me- but it never grabbed me as a whole at any point. A shame, but was enough here and it’s short enough that I can’t begrudge it too much.

a_man's.title: A Man's Place
a_man's.author: Annie Ernaux
a_man's.review: French autofiction about a woman surpassing her father’s class position and ensuing disconnect/affection between them might put the bourgeois in bourgeois literature, but this still managed to hit the spot for me. Ernaux fills with such intimate, telling detail- I saw one review call her writing like dissecting of insects, several others of how unemotional to me, but to me, it reads as genuine affection, achieved through attention, through genuinely grapping with and working towards an understanding of the drives of her father’s life. When the moments of emotion between father and daughter actually come in, it feels like a flood of emotion, a breaking of a dam. The reflections on lower class masculinity are particularly insightful here- Ernaux’s father has pride, sure, but pride at mostly not embarrassing himself, shame (and avoidance of it) the driving factor of how he conducts himself, how he sees himself. It is a sad prison, but one that Ernaux finds the dignity in, the joy in- in that he provided a life, that she was able to achieve everything he wanted for her, that he was able to find the joys he did find.

the_three-body.title: The Three-Body Problem (Remembrance of Earth’s Past, #1)
the_three-body.author: Liu Cixin
the_three-body.review:
Think this one works almost entirely by virtue of its mystery/detective style framing, bread crumbing the reader along with enough hints and misdirections to scoot them past the paper thin characters. There’s two close to compelling characters (Ye Wenjie and Da Shi), but the rest of the cast is almost nonexistent in terms of any sort of compelling traits or personality.

Every piece of hard science fiction has to involve plenty of explaining, but this one does a good job of being simultaneously digestible and not totally theoretical/uninteresting to the audience. The game (the human computer!) in particular I think is a pretty exceptional case of laying out the science of it, why it’s interesting in a theoretical sense, and why it’s important to the narrative itself all in one go. Some of the higher dimensional stuff towards the end with the creation of the Sophons was a little lost on me, but the end result was still legible to me.

Maybe it’s because I’m less versed on Chinese culture, but also found this interesting in terms of how China sees itself and the fallout to its Cultural Revolution. The scene of Ye Wenjie meeting the Red Guards who killed her father, victims of history just as much as she is, and their refusal to apologize for the tides that brought them up and tore them down, I found really interesting; and Wenjie’s lost in faith that humanity can be redeemed, that they transcend those tides, surprisingly all worked on both a theoretical and somewhat (for this type of book) emotional level.

Also distinctly Chinese in its faith that humanity could band together as a whole through government agencies and cooperation to take down an existential threat. That kind of faith and almost naivety is one that I haven’t seen out of American science fiction writers.

if_we.title: If We Burn: The Mass Protest Decade and the Missing Revolution
if_we.author: Vincent Bevins
if_we.review:
History is much easier to write decades after the fact. The legacy of Indonesia, and of American meddling in the Third World in the 60s, is all but settled. Which makes Bevins work here, to try to figure out the legacy of protest movements of the 2010s in roughly real time, all the more challenging and all the more impressive that he manages to pull it off.

Protest is the language of the 2010s (the subtitle calls it the “protest decade”), and much of the discussion here. Bevins covers a wide swath of countries (Egypt, Bahrain, Ukraine, Turkey, Brazil, Tunisia, South Korea, Chile Hong Kong, amongst others- the US is briefly touched on but not a primary focus), all united in form of protest, all united in galvanizing the masses far beyond the typical protests, all for the most part united in unsatisfying outcomes. Some were able to overthrow the existing state, only to find opposing forces fill the power vacuum; others were co-opted to empower right wing organizations, or had their message go so broad so as to become meaningless/diluted.

Common to all these is the tool they use (mass protest) and the distrust of hierarchy or organization. Bevins spends a short time tracing this back, to the New Left and to anti-Soviet sentiments discrediting traditional forms of hierarchy, as well as to Dave Graeber and prefigurative living- the only way to build a world that has no hierarchies is to not have any for your social justice organizing. It is a compelling argument in theory, but in practice it led to disaster- organizations striving to reach consensus voting spending hours on minutia, the media’s search for a voice for the protest (which Bevins describes accurately as a media action first and foremost) being left to the non-ideological crowd rather than the organizations responsible for starting the movement in the first place.

A lot of time is spent on the influence of social media, how it influenced the movement and how it was covered. The movements listed all took tactics, imagery, ideas from each other, for better or worse, referencing each other directly, partially for media coverage, partially in inspiration, and partially in a very real display of international solidarity. The influence is not all positive, even if the media’s view of it was unquestioning worship, that technology would spread democracy (where have I heard that before?) and justice to the world- it frequently contributed to the diffuse nature of these events, led to their underlying ideologies being undermined and hijacked, led to the participants being trackable and findable in the immediate aftermath. The inspiration can be good- but also, as he points out, what works in the first world for drawing attention can get you killed in Bahrain or Egypt. These movements should be inspired by each other in ways, but each context demands its own set of tactics and approaches, and the flattening power of social media does not reveal that, leading to very real consequences for those users.

Bevins spends his last chapter reflecting on protest with his interviewees- at one point, he asks one of the Brazilian protestors if they could’ve accomplished their goal through backroom politicking rather than mass action, would they have taken it and the protestor tellingly, despite the aftermath in part leading to Bolsonaro, says no. At the very least, he seeks to define the use of a protest as a tool in the toolkit, as a media action, as a way of grabbing attention, rather than as the main and only recourse and method of enacting change. The book seems to be far more focused on ends based politics, noting the Chilean protestors taking up positions in government (despite being called sellouts or traitors) as a success story of enacting positive change from events such as these. He closes on a haunting question- is it possible that these actions, these moments when the masses of humanity take to the street and rise up, where the participants feel they are making history, connected despite their alienation, as one society fighting for justice- could those moments be just those feelings, dangerous privileged adventurism, a drug as harmful as any other- “If you want the feeling of mass ecstasy, you should go to a music festival instead of encouraging vulnerable young people to go out and get killed,” as he puts it up. Or are they reflective of something real, of something to come, of a world where citizens cocreate their own reality rather than living alienated, distanced, injust lives? Bevins and his interviewees are split- he gives no answer, and that answer is likely for the decades to come to decide.

exquisite_corpse.title: Exquisite Corpse
exquisite_corpse.author: Poppy Z. Brite
exquisite_corpse.review: Exquisite Corpse is extremely 90s, for better or worse- Nine Inch Nails references, lots of cursing and edginess (who knew the term breeders for kid havers was around back then and not just a Reddit invention?), and leaning in extremely hard on violence and gore. Is far more of a grotesque imagery/gross out book in terms of what it evokes than one that works on an atmospheric or vibe level. Beyond that, I found this most interesting as commentary/evocation of AIDS crisis gay life, people abandoned and thrust into vulnerability by their families, by society at large, and the accompanying feelings of anger and loneliness. That loneliness and isolation all makes them ripe for the pickings for the novel’s cannabilistic serial killers, who cherish the flesh they were told was sinful and unsalvageable, who exploit that connection to lead them to their final, horrific doom. It all makes sense in a very 90s style metaphor way that I don't think you could ever get away with writing today, for better or worse. This taking a 30 page detour to be a wholesome love story between two serial killers earn some points for how straight it plays it and how absurd it actually is.

pilgrim_at.title: Pilgrim at Tinker Creek
pilgrim_at.author: Annie Dillard
pilgrim_at.review:
My 100th GoodReads review is not wasted on something bad, but a new favorite, which is cool how it turned out. Not sure if 100 makes me happy at my commitment to this bit or depressed at the sheer amount of words I’ve spilled on this website but I’ll bask in the accomplishment instead of worrying about it too much. This was one I didn’t want to end so it’s about as good as you can get for a celebration book.

Feels most like spending hours in Dillard’s head, an introduction to her pet interests and seeing the world rather than constructing any sort of clear throughline from chapter to chapter, outside of the passage of time throughout the year. The joy is that Dillard’s way of thinking is one dominated first and foremost by curiosity and wonder and detail, where everything she sees holds beauty, or at least fascination. It is a book first and foremost about detail, sometimes directly talking about it, sometimes showing it, and is proof that intimate knowledge does not preclude joy or wonder but enhances it.

Has some religious undertones (and overtones) to it, which usually I find hugely alienating but this one gets away it for the sheer reverence that it lives out for the world and the many quirks of the creatures within it (and because it doesn’t do much evangelizing). In a way, made explicit in its conclusion, this becomes a manifesto for how to live life, how to experience the world as a human in a world filled with so many inhuman elements.

Stylistically is very young person writing their first novel, which all the more benefits its core aspirations, full of stretches at beauty and long, flowy sentences that capture natural beauty and the continuous experience of focus and flow in harmony with the world incredibly well. The section with the dog in the gas station, mountains (that I’ve hiked!) in the background, a moment of pure conscious (but not self-conscious) pleasure, is one that’ll stick with me for a long time.

Most closely evokes that feeling of catching a deer in a clearing and making eye contact, both of you still, waiting for the other to make a move, trying to discern the secret intentions of the other. That’s pretty special to evoke through words alone.

how_should.title: How Should a Person Be?
how_should.author: Sheila Heti
how_should.review:
People complain about this being narcissistic- what do you expect of a book with this title in this genre? Sure, it’s got its head up its own ass (or someone else’s), but that’s it doing it what it says in the tin.

Much like Lauren Oyler’s much more recent Fake Accounts, the line between author and narrator is thin, the narrator being a Jewish women from Toronto named Sheila who’s a writer struggling with writer’s block. Perhaps because spawned a fair amount of imitators and similar books (including Oyler, who’s reviewed Heti) since it dropped in 2010, I did not find this one to be as enduring as the more contemporary. However, I think it does do a good job of capturing 21st century urban solipsism in a way that I think has only grown more prescient with time, the desire for fame and the world’s eyes without the work put in, the preoccupation with moral framings and meaning and some abstract pure sense of authenticity, the overconsidered yet careless way of going through lives. In a way some of its depiction feels quaint, as social media has only intensified and brought out more of what she’s talking about.

While I didn’t find the critiques as satisfying as Oyler, I did find parts of this really shined which saved it. I actually really loved some of the sex writing in here, crude power dynamics and ideas of servitude, shame, and desire all playing out. She’s too smart to dole out an actual answer to her own framing question, leaving some vignettes and thoughts, the image of players slamming a squash ball with joy and no idea the rules of the game a beautiful counterpoint to the neurotic handwringing the novel had done to that point. The preoccupations about how to be are all a way of nullifying the way that you are, hiding from the impact and identity you have, the personal touch brought out in everything you touch, as when Sheila’s friend tries to make an ugly painting and ends up creating something beautiful. In the end it ends in a really sincere place of valuing humanity and each other in all its messiness and ugliness that I can’t help but to admire for a book that is endowed with plenty of detachment and irony.

fake_accounts.title: Fake Accounts
fake_accounts.author: Lauren Oyler
fake_accounts.review:
Have tossed and turned on how much I really liked this one, but it’s stuck in my head long enough that I’m inclined to veer into the positive direction. Can’t say I’d recommend to anyone who isn’t extremely Online or Twitter brained, but for that subset I think this has the potential to land.

The line between artist and narrator is blurred, as the narrator has a Twitter avatar identical to the author’s, lives in Berlin as the author does, and retains the same voice that you would expect from a Twitter user. Oyler, in her critique of Jia Tolentino’s Trick Mirror, accuses Tolentino of using the world as a mirror to get insight into herself, whereas a more refined artist uses their experience as an entry point to make points about the world, as well as that Tolentino’s vulnerability and authenticity and messiness is actually carefully crafted to present herself in the best light. I mention this because this is an interesting counterpoint; if Oyler is crafting an image of herself, it’s certainly not a flattering one. And while the narrator is plenty self-obsessed, I do think Oyler is branching to the world with her own experience, although much of it is critiquing insular Online detachment from one’s own experiences and events, irony poisioning to the nth degree. There was multiple times reading this and straightened up in my chair and said “Do I sound like this?” which is probably a good sign that she’s hitting her marks. If one were to read the narrator with the slightest bit of sympathy, I could see the total disdain which the rest of the world seems to have for this book.

Given the subject matter, wish this one had a tiny bit more to say about conspiracy, although there’s some amusing bits of humor in here about it. SPOILERS The twist ending really does serve as a triple-pronged evisceration of this style poisoning and its impact on our relationships, one where both players can be checked out entirely and carry out, one where a romantic partner can be faked a death upon as a funny prank, and one where one does not bother to check upon the actual details of the death of a boyfriend. It’s all an absurd farce, of ironic detachment directed at the world bleeding into and subsuming your most intimate relationships. The many, many dating app dates presented here (I can feel the readers groaning) and even her interactions with other Berliners play into this- at no point does she allow herself to be herself to anyone, always lying, farming for stories and laughs, to the point where the only self that is herself lives in her head.

Overall, a lot of this comes down to how you feel about the voice, which I find compelling but then again I’ve been on Twitter for a decade so your mileage may vary. Has a funny critique of fragmentary writing that actually kind of works in the middle of it, which I’m sure can and has been interpreted as obnoxious.

life_a.title: Life: A User's Manual
life_a.author: Georges Perec
life_a.review:
Another literary experiment by Perec, this time him going room by room through a Parisian apartment building, chronicling the inhabitants, their decorations, the history of both tenants and the room itself. Time is frozen, 8 PM- there is only what has happened in the past, and the scene at that time. He traverses the 10x10 building as a knight on a chess board, traversing every room without repeating once, dedicating a chapter to each room in the building. This means characters slide in and out quickly, although the connections between tenants help retain a sense of continuity.

A book covering this much space clearly has a lot on its mind, themes sliding in and out of frame. However, the framing itself serves as a theme, the apartment building (and rooms) as a character, one subject to changing tides, styles gaining and losing prominence, neighborhoods changing in character around them, landlords and managers swapping hands. Perec is dedicated to the history of the building as much as anything, a room meaning one thing for one tenant and another, that tenant’s character and story being very different to the one before them. As ***********An Attempt*********** made us perceive the ordinary things happening at that moment, *****Life***** makes us perceive the hidden histories before us in the rooms of any building that we enter. The quality of the rooms themselves is also in frame, a high attention to the details of adornments that tenants have decided to put in, each telling its own small tale of who the tenant is and what the place stands for.

The one connecting much of the building together is Bartlebooth, a rich financier who goes on a quest to learn to paint, then travels the world painting sunsets, sends the paintings to a puzzle maker in the building, solves the puzzle, and then immediately has it destroyed, hoping to leave no trace of his quest. There is, of course, much to say about this quest, its meaning being total self-erasure, the idea that human achievement is futility, existence disappearing completely upon one’s expiration as if they had never been there before. Of course, Bartlebooth can’t succeed in even this, going blind and then dying in his quest, plenty of puzzles left to complete, the final puzzle he worked on with one piece missing, the piece in his hand not matching the missing square in front of him. A piece of us always remains in every space we vacate, no matter if we like it or not. The quest for a solution to life, treating it as a puzzle, is a futile one, one we’re doomed to fail and leave incomplete.

Futility pervades, judge’s failing in their marriage till they commit to a life of crime that disgraces them, cyclists injuring themselves and recommiting themselves to aiding other cyclists only to injure them too, painters on quests they never complete. Every character, every room, has a story, one that fascinates in a different direction, in absurd and novel ways, but commonalities in the stories tie them together. Living in a country that actively hates its neighbors, that fetishizes the isolated homestead, this perhaps hits a little different.

There’s plenty on the folly of modernity, iterating on kitchens, on hotels in new directions, the building and its inhabitants a witness to a shifting world, one moving in a consumerist and increasingly commodity fetishized direction- some tenants are able to profit from it, some are attempting to isolate from it, some are left behind by it. But still, the building stands, only increasing in the amount of people it houses, the stories it holds, the meanings present. An enigmatic classic. A self-help book only in the most abstract sense, despite what its title suggests to curious passer-by.

an_attempt.title: An Attempt at Exhausting a Place in Paris
an_attempt.author: Georges Perec
an_attempt.review: A man sits in different locations around a square in Paris, cataloguing only what he sees in front of him, the passing of commuter and tourist buses, of people walking to and fro, of pigeons making their senseless migrations. Time and attention work against him, not able to hold a moment in amber (in a way, this is the flipside of his Life: A User’s Manual, which chronicles a single moment in time but from all angles), occasionally interrupted by his own eating of sandwich. That's all this is. It is mostly an exercise in attention, both for reader and writer, to be able to focus on the small minute details, eliminate the pre-processing your brain does at every opportunity and view the world as it is. At a certain point, he questions why he’s doing it, what he came to the square to accomplish. I’m sure every reader of this has done the same. Eventually, despite Perec’s flat styling to emphasize the mundanity, poetry seeps in, small moments of human beauty or absurdity, the hum of a city in motion, in the midst of these small, extra-sensory happenings.

last_evenings.title: Last Evenings on Earth
last_evenings.author: Roberto Bolaño
last_evenings.review:
In classic Bolano fashion, has a sledgehammer ending, one that clarifies and expands upon everything that’s been written before. Just an absolute stunning section:

“54. The children of the Spanish lion, said Ruben Dario, a born optimist. The children of Walt Whitman, Jose Marti, and Violeta Parra; torn apart, forgotten, in mass graves, at the bottom of the sea, the Trojan destiny of their mingled bones terrifying the survivors.
55. I think of them this week as the veterans of the Internal Brigades visit Spain: little old men climbing down from the buses, brandishing their fists. They were 40,000 of them, and 350 or so have come back to Spain.
56. I think of Beltran Morales, I think of Rodrigo Lira, I think of Maria Santiago, I think of Reinaldo Arenas. I think of the poets who died under torture, who died of AIDS, or overdose, all those who believe in a Latin American paradise and died in a Latin American hell. I think of their works, which may, perhaps, show the Left a way out of the pit of shame and futility.”

From there, he closes the book talking of Paulo Neruda, how every Chilean poet will toil in anonymity, his name above them and representing them all in eternity, while the contemporary poets will be in jail or asylums. It is, of course, cruelly ironic that Bolano’s name could replace Neruda’s, the one star from Chile that represents the entire country, the one that Westerners can read and cross Chile off their list of countries they understand, the countries who’s art they’ve drank from.

But Bolano’s tale in this (and throughout his work) is that of the minor artists, the survivors terrified of mingled bones, those brandishing their fists, those who toiled in anonymity, who fought and lived as if they were a star but whose work and life are erased the second they’re extinguished. The children of the failed dreams of the 20th century, wandering North America and Europe, far from home, drifting without a place to call their own, their battle already lost. The short stories ache with melancholy, sadness, lost dreams, senseless conflict and violence. That of course is not the full sum of the stories, and neither is of those lives, but even in the more upbeat of the stories there is a tinge of that hanging over every story, beauty existing in spite of circumstance.

Maybe my favorite Bolano? Just purchased 2666 so we shall see soon.

the_marigold.title: The Marigold
the_marigold.author: Andrew F. Sullivan
the_marigold.review: Winner of Mike’s goopiest novel read in 2023, the most prestigious award we have. Does a good job of making its central metaphor of The Wet, a fungus swallowing high rises and people in Toronto, elastic, not standing in for the just the rot that get rich quick luxury high rise housing bring to their cities,  crumbling empty units as placeholders for real estate value with no corresponding societal value, but for the alienation that swallows the rank and file inhabitants, the loneliness and lack of community a society that allows the commodified rot instills in its citizens. Does a good job sprinkling in some less straightforward aspects that aren’t easy political selling points- thinking specifically of the Wet as being sort of a community, a unified organism, and the gardener who plants bodies in construction, seemingly implying with his thoughts that the problem with new development is the lack of respect for tradition, the real estate developer looking to sell The Wet as some form of a bioweapon, slightly thornier, less obvious aspects than could be implied from a one sentence summary of the book. A lot of the character work didn’t work that much for me and wish it had skewed a little darker/graphic, like Sullivan’s previous novel Waste, but it’s a page turner and the core concepts/imagery are good here. Need to read High Rise/some of the more recent fungal horror to have a better idea what this is in conversation with.

beyond_a.title: Beyond a Boundary
beyond_a.author: C.L.R. James
beyond_a.review:
Wanted to read something by this guy and had heard his book on Haitian revolution was a bit dry, so figured I’d try him writing about sports. Turned out to be a bit dry as well, but found some stuff of interest here, primarily because I know nothing about cricket.

James is most interesting when he’s evaluating the importance and meaning of the sport in its different contexts. He ties cricket’s rise in England to the transition of feudalism to capitalism and industrialization, the stars of the sport and its nature a tie for the people back to their roots, a way of connecting to some lost past. The rise of sports generally in the 20th century coincides with this; and he notes in particular that the way the people interact with sports is changing, that they are more focused on the individuals rather than teams and cities comprising them, and that for cricket to retain relevance it needs to transition in that direction. For the Trinidadians, the sport is handed to them by their colonizers, and for the colonizers it is a tool to instill certain values, values that help keep the colonized subjects in control and compliant with the occupying regime. Of course, it also presents the subjects an opportunity to prove their worth, that they are the equals of them on the field, a scoreboard to show what they know to be true.

The information about the different clubs in Trinidad is interesting, the teams representing an array of interests, both in class and color. The history of the Trinidad captaincy, that only white players were allowed to be selected even as black players far surpassed them, and the struggle to fix that and the negative impact that had on the team’s credibility with the nation and its ability to perform on the field, is chronicled throughout and in much depth. Beyond the politics of it, also found James to be at some of his most compelling when he lifts and elevates cricket to artform, his chronicles and admiration of swings and bowls attempting to lift the great sportsmen of his age to the level of poets and novelists (and made me seek out cricket highlights on Youtube)

Can’t say I’d recommend it to a non-cricket fan, and there were some sections I contemplated not completing, but there was also a lot of beauty and interesting detail to be found here as well.

the_beginning.title: The Beginning of the End: France, May 1968
the_beginning.author: Angelo Quattrocchi
the_beginning.review:
An interesting literary experiment around the student protests/general strike in France of 68, the first half being a poetic recounting of events from someone on the ground, the second a more academic theoretical take on the events.

The first is definitely the highlight of the book, Quattrochi’s prose poem carrying the fervor and passion of revolution as if he wrote it as the events were occurring. The rise of the movement is intoxicating, students protesting over gendered dormitories and better learning conditions in mass confrontation with the power of the state, the rest of the country watching in horror before joining in, the demands and aims of the movement spiraling into a countrywide transformation of life, all rising up to bring an economy, a president, the existing power structure (literally turning off the power!) to its knees, perhaps the greatest show of force by a working class movement ever in the Western world, before being brutally beaten back by the state. The potential is felt, both in ideas, of a movement finding itself as it grows, finding that the old revolutionary concepts are not fit for their moment and working to find new ones, a total transformation of life, and in action, as what starts small grows and grows until it can bring a country to its knees and bring the possibility of real power to the table. If there’s a critique of this section, it’s that the fall is abbreviated, the exact events abstracted, while there’s a real clarity to how the rise occurs. Would imagine any history of 2020 would probably have a similar arc and lack of clarity, so perhaps it’s not truly the fault of the author here.

The second I’m a little more mixed on it, and I find more interesting as an account of grappling with the events than really analysis. Nairn identifies the students as the new force with the revolutionary potential, disregarding the old traditional working class and political parties and unions with them. For a moment, around the world, USA, France, and elsewhere, he was right- students reliably being the force that resisted and tried to build new structures. However, in hindsight, it’s clear that that was a blip, the last outcry of the youth against the turning of the university from a place of learning and human growth to job training, a servant to the needs and demands of the economy rather than a refuge from it. When was the last time a student movement made any sort of wave? The students have internalized the logic of the market, scared to compromise academic standing and job prospects. Still, this analysis is interesting, as Nairn is trying to find a new center of political potential since the traditional working class structures of union and party have not delivered substantial change and the basic needs of (most) everyone are being met, leading to a complacency and lack of fervor that might have been once necessary and core to the movements.

Has some of my favorite quotes around working class revolt I’ve ever read, particularly:

“The astronomers at Meudon are on strike, not for money, for more stars.”

filthy_animals.title: Filthy Animals
filthy_animals.author: Brandon  Taylor
filthy_animals.review: Read this one awhile ago, so don’t have a ton of in-depth thoughts remaining in my head. Did a really good job capturing power dynamics and struggles in both lovers of many different relationship types and in artistic community, as well as when those two collide. Taylor is really skilled at capturing the conflicting thoughts and opinions of every head in a room, really wonderful to see a contemporary writer be able to pull that off.

lights_out.title: Lights Out for the Territory: 9 Excursions in the Secret History of London
lights_out.author: Iain Sinclair
lights_out.review:
Another one of Sinclair’s psychogeographical journeys through London put to prose, this one an interesting contract from The Last London in how almost cherry it feels? There’s still plenty of trademark English cynicism and biting wit, and it probably didn’t read as such at the time, but Sinclair sees London as a place with abundant mystery and mysticism to tap into, whereas his later impressions feels like a mourning for the London of Lights Out in light of post Olympics development and commercialism.

Other than that, there’s plenty of trademark Sinclair, walking journeys to meet obscure artists, lengthy descriptions of the works of other writers/directors/visual artists and their ties to place and space, plenty of history of neighborhoods and shops, and just really an overwhelming sense of Britishness to the whole thing. Some of my fav sections were his tour of Tory victory and Lord Archer’s estate and his (of course cynical) views of commercial fiction, his overviews of the directors of London and his history with the scrappy upstart scene, and his Graffiti describing and reflections upon it as artistic expression and city dressing. The feeling of place is as strong as ever, even as he drifts more I feel to describe personal histories and artists than he has in the past.

I liked it, but feel like what I experienced the first time I read him may have been a singular experience that can’t be matched fully (and it may have been just because it was my first exposure to this style of writing?)

bartleby_&.title: Bartleby & Co.
bartleby_&.author: Enrique Vila-Matas
bartleby_&.review: A rare DNF from me. Never at any point compelled me or hooked me, even as a fan of the original short story and a lot of the authors talked about here. Never could find an angle into seeing the work itself as compelling or interesting.

the_incendiaries.title: The Incendiaries
the_incendiaries.author: R.O. Kwon
the_incendiaries.review:
#

Found myself just whelmed by this one- did nothing to really stand out, just kind of an adequate read.
