Despite the fact that large portions of this are drawing from similar experiences in the author’s own life, I couldn’t really feel the specificity of that experience in the writing, even in parts where I draw pretty significant overlap as well. The prose stretched at times and occasionally landed but for the most part was just kind of there (despite everyone on this website claiming it’s overly ornate, actually wished it was more willing to go that direction!). Think its thoughts on lapsed Christianity and what draws people into cults are fine but not particular visceral or did a ton to land with me, the North Korean angle never really lands anywhere interesting. Perhaps the most interesting thought it generated in me was this idea of Phoebe as a mirror, as someone swept entirely in the directions that people set her on, and how that leads her into the arms of the cult (and really, into the arms of Will), but that’s not enough to make this one I find worth recommending. Kind of a disappointed meh from me given the content lands in a lot of areas I’m interested in.

mrs._dalloway.title: Mrs. Dalloway
mrs._dalloway.author: Virginia Woolf
mrs._dalloway.review:
Was my first introduction to maybe my favorite author in college, and my estimation of it has only increased with time. It’s not my favorite of hers, but it’s up there and it’s packed into a size that can be read in a week or so rather than some of her far more demanding work.

What struck me more on this read through was the nature of the doubling and the contrast between Septimus and Clarissa, two beings unstuck from time and their surroundings yet intimately connected to those surroundings, seemingly the two poles of Woolf herself, one mentally ill, unable to meet society’s standards and ultimately suicidial, and the side that can maintain the house and what her husband and polite society demand of her, as well as the two sides of British society, the one that suffers and gives their life so that the other can host fancy dinner parties where that suffering is merely an interruption and small talk conversation. The dichotomy builds and builds until it reaches its zenith, with Septimus leaping out the window in a moment of freedom and despair and Clarissa hosting the prime minister, stirring terror and awe at the woman that she is from her oldest friend and jilted lover, yet requiring a moment amidst her hosting duties to ponder the death of the (unknown to her) Septimus.

Other things that stuck out to me on this read through is how she depicts the city as a living, breathing, flowing organism, jumping from head to head, location to location, every location and every head a fountain of its own beauty and chaos all combining to form the tapestry of London. How aging is used against the characters both by themselves and by each other, feeling the winnowing of possibilities, the end drawing nearer, accomplishments not yet and never to be made held as a shortfall, the years accumulating to form memories of loves lost and flashing back to the time where choice was something they had and living in the obligations they posses now. The love between Clarissa and Sally, never allowed to mean anything, perhaps purer because it never could mean anything- the way their husband’s names take precedence over there’s in any formal setting, only their first names when in the comfort of each other’s company, their worth to society at large defined far more by the last name than the first now that they are of age. The moment of flowers between Richard and Clarissa, the knitting between Septimus and Rezia, tiny imperfect moments of love and affection in imperfect marriages- all that is left unsaid, that we cannot say, but is still understood.

There’s a million other things I could write paragraphs on, because this book and Woolf are that good, but I don’t need to go back to writing seven paragraphs for these again. Rest assured, Woolf is the god, and this is probably the best book for the uninitiated to read, the perfect combination of her experimentation and wondrous flowing prose while still maintaining legibility.

last_words.title: Last Words from Montmartre
last_words.author: Qiu Miaojin
last_words.review: Definitely has its moments but felt myself a little underwhelmed by this one? Possibly an issue with prose in translation because there’s a lot I really liked in here, but also parts that I thought sort of plodded along/were repetitive. Probably works better taken as individual pieces out of order (as the author suggests) than the linear narrative I read it as. Does a really beautiful job of conveying depression and heartbreak and the funneling of feelings of the former into the latter, and does some interesting stuff with gender but not enough for me to latch on completely. Definitely interested in her more conventional work but this one didn’t quite do it for me.

darryl.title: Darryl
darryl.author: Jackie Ess
darryl.review:
Fiction about a cuck in weirdo Eugene, Oregon- with a hook like that, how could I not read it?

Found certain elements of this pretty inessential to what it was accomplishing, namely the tacking of a thriller type angle at the very end. Felt at least to me like conceding towards publishing/marketability, although I could be wrong.

However, the stuff that it seemed particularly interested in exploring was really well executed. Starts off as almost an evaluation of masculine hierarchy, the way that men see each other and the world, our narrator at the bottom of the totem pole looking up at the jockeying above him and happy to (quite literally) watch them impose their dominance and masculinity upon him and his wife. With the introduction of a trans character, you begin to feel as if you know the direction it’s heading, that his position at the bottom of the pole is because he doesn’t really belong on it at all, but where this book shines in my opinion is by subverting and interrogating that assumption to find points that I think are much deeper; that gender and sexuality are intimately tied together and can not be separated, that landing places of those identities are not binary paths (or set paths with some concrete destination at all) that people are doomed/destined to fall down but rather approximations of some true self- two people can have the same feelings but because of context end up in radically different places that can not simply be dismissed as self denial for either one .

Lot of good humor in this as well, plenty of funny observations about the cuckosphere. Think cuck fiction has a lot of promise as a genre of literary merit.

valis.title: VALIS
valis.author: Philip K. Dick
valis.review:
Is 100% Dick two or three steps further down the schizophrenia rabbit hole from Three Stigmata, involving a main character that he tells you is actually him (aka Phillip K Dick, who is also a “character” in the story), then treats him as if he’s a wholly separate entity, having conversations and moving independently of him, has a mental breakdown and the identities unify again. The second identity is named Horselover Fat. It’s about a satellite from outer space beaming mind control into politican’s and everyone’s head and telling Dick that his kid has a tumor. Previously undiscovered levels of schizo-writing going on here it’s remarkable. It’s also like 45% an insane Gnostic/Zoroastrian/kind of incoherent philosophy text before jumping into crazy identity splitting/merging and alien mind control. Like I said, previously undiscovered levels of schizo-writing here.

Beyond that, found this to be a compelling tale of post hippiedom spirituality, the era of free drugs and love curdled into divorce, mental illness, and institutionalization. Searching for purpose and meaning in media and conspiracy, cultish tendencies that go south leading to dead kids and fractured families, only to return to the comfort of the couch, waiting on a savior that will never come, parsing the signs beamed through your television screen and ignoring the reality outside it. Can’t say I’d recommend to anyone not on a very particular wavelength but if you’re on it it’s also pretty singular and one of a kind.

the_jakarta.title: The Jakarta Method: Washington's Anticommunist Crusade and the Mass Murder Program that Shaped Our World
the_jakarta.author: Vincent Bevins
the_jakarta.review:
One of the most crushingly depressing books I’ve ever read, an exhausting but by no means exhaustive compilation of injustices committed by the CIA and the United States during the Cold War in pursuit of control over the Third World. The world we live in, of the Third World living as serf states to the West, as hubs for resources to be extracted from and places for tourists to frolic and surf on top of buried mass graves, was one created and executed by the CIA in collaboration with far right wing forces in those countries, who worked to exterminate and drive out their enemies who wanted to fight for free countries to truly be free.

Bevins does a really wonderful job here of balancing the local and worldwide politics with the personal, that those left wingers and minorities killed were not merely numbers and pawns in a game for global supremacy but people with families, loves, and dreams, while also keeping in sight the forces and powers at play that led to the atrocities that wiped them from the Earth. Inspiring to read the hope and unity these countries had in light of their recent (at the time) freedom, which makes the ending of subjugation all the more heartbreaking. Some of the conclusions Bevins (and the interviewees) are forced to draw are grim- that they had too much faith in the decency of their countrymen and the world, that they should’ve drawn arms and were wrong to believe they could achieve power and equality through peaceful means rather than at the end of the barrel of a gun. Chile, Indonesia, Guatemala, the list goes on and on of countries that thought they. “The major losers of the twentieth century were those who believe too sincerely in the existence of a liberal international order, those who trusted too much in democracy, or too much in what the United States says it supported, rather than what it really supported- what the rich countries said, rather than what they did. That group was annihilated.” The questions he asks his interviewees at the end- what world did you believe you were building? Does that match the world you live in now? and their answers, their eyes lighting up still with the hope they had in those days (and still maintain), and the laughability of the second one, dismissed without a second thought.

Should be essential reading for any person growing up in the US. So much of this is completely unknown and so essential to understanding both the US, the world, and the relationship between the two, and yet no one knows hardly any of this stuff. No one even knows Indonesia is the 4th most populated country in the world.

the_culture.title: The Culture Code: The Secrets of Highly Successful Groups
the_culture.author: Daniel Coyle

the_society.title: The Society of the Spectacle
the_society.author: Guy Debord
the_society.review:
Finished this one awhile ago, so impressions are a little out of date, but liked this one quite a bit despite falling victim to some theory book trappings of repetition and falling in love with fancy phrasings over comprehensibility. You learn to love it.

The spectacle, as Debord defines it, is the separation of people from their actual lived reality- that everything around them has ceased to be real and has been replaced by a representation of reality, every desire, interaction, part of life mediated by the logic of capital, by images beamed into your head from the day you were born to the day you die. The image is the tool of the spectacle, endlessly manipulatable- 'an identification of all human social life with appearances.' You can imagine Debord in his grave spinning over Instagram. The spectacle exists to justify existing reality, to subsume any critique into its web (watch the new Black Mirror! It critiques Netflix- on Netflix!), to manufacture isolation and alienation, separating neighbor from neighbor, worker from production, individual from society. Our cities don't exist for the inhabitants- they exist for tourists to pass through, for cars to drive through on highways built on top of the rubble of neighborhoods and communities not deemed valuable. Commodities have lost all tie to their use value or price to produce, fetishized to the point of total abstraction, prices rising and falling on the whims of CEOs, with no one capable of understanding the steps it took to bring a strawberry into your refrigerator (and it having no tie to the seasonal element of life that used to define reality). Divisions between political parties are real in a sense, but offer no way out of the existing way of life. What is true becomes a matter of what feed you are plugged into.

Debord's way out in anti-ideology, a belief that to escape one must be present in the moment, adapting to the existing situation rather than holding on to old ideas not built for the present moment. The re-integration of the people into historical events, to having your actions impact the world around you, is the way through, in Debord's estimation, through the classic idea of the worker council, is the only way out of his idea of the mental turning against itself (he terms it 'schizophrenia') that accepting the spectacle on its own terms creates. He, of course, spends more time diagnosing problems than he does offering solutions, but that fits into the project of allowing the moment to dictate action rather than old (even his too shall become old, as they are now) ideas.

The thing it reminded most was this quote from Iran after the US assassinated Suleimani:

'[In the situation] that we take one of theirs now that they've got one of ours — who should we consider to take out in the context of America? Think about it. Are we supposed to take out Spider-Man and SpongeBob? They don't have any heroes. We have a country in front of us with a large population and a large landmass, but it doesn't have any heroes. All of their heroes are cartoon characters — they're all fictional.'

october_the.title: October: The Story of the Russian Revolution
october_the.author: China Miéville

one_hundred.title: One Hundred Years of Solitude
one_hundred.author: Gabriel García Márquez
one_hundred.review:
One of those classics I’m far too stupid to put words down for justice but have to try anyway.

The fate of everyone you ever knew and loved written in front of you, only you can only read it when they’re all dead and gone and the town your family helped found is being quite literally swept away into the dustbin of history. That is the concluding image of novel, but in a way, that is the entirety of it, the fates of each individual character written in their names and the stars, traveling like pieces down an assembly line, straining against and leaning into the fate that they were always going to reach in the end. The town, doomed from the start, the desire to reach and connect to the ocean following down the family lines until it brings about the train that brings the colonizers that devastate the people and ultimately the land completely until neither of them exist. They were all doomed from the start; but does that make their fate any less tragic?

The constant through the generations are the names (confusingly) and the traits that come with them, but also the titular solitude, a source of comfort in some, a source of pain in others, a way of leaving the world and each other out in all. They escape each other through labor, be it knitting, keeping the house, making treats, various other lovers, sewing gold fishes, but all of them escape companionship, be it explicitly rejecting rejecting romantic suitors or an implicit hardening of the heart against the others in the family who are in fact doing the same thing to them too. Only the last of the family can find love in each other, and in incestual form that ultimately dooms the family to its eradication (and to the long foreseen pig tail child), a twisted reminder that the escape from solitude was always in that house with that family but none could grasp it in any lasting way.

Beautifully written, stylistically invigorating, just an awesome book on every level. Will revisit when I’m older and likely end up with a wholly new take on it.

the_day.title: The Day of the Locust
the_day.author: Nathanael West
the_day.review:
The origin of the name Homer Simpson (shockingly)- found the beginning stages of this one a tad underwhelming (outside of the chapter of Homer sitting everyday on the outside of his house, holding a book but never reading it, watching a lizard try to eat flies) but crescendos with a bang, the party gone wrong and riot all striking imagery and writing that forms one of the most convincing literary depictions of how LA is a horrible place you should never visit or go to. An exceptional depiction of the type of resentment that LA breeds in both its outsiders and its middle class inhabitants, close to stardom and beauty but never able to grasp it, all repressed libidinal violence both sexual and physical waiting to be released at an opportune moment but that violence only ever releasing on each other or through movies or celebrities. There's no Christ figure to save anyone, just the masses, sitting in their homes, waiting to die.

My favorite quote from that final chapter:

'All their lives they had slaved at some kind of dull, heavy labor, behind desks and counters, in the fields and at tedious machines of all sorts, saving their pennies and dreaming of the leisure that would be theirs when they had enough. Finally that day came. They could draw a weekly income of ten or fifteen dollars. Where else should they go but California, the land of sunshine and oranges?

Once there, they discover that sunshine isn't enough. They get tired of oranges, even of avocado pears and passion fruit. Nothing happens. They don't know what to do with their time. They haven't the mental equipment for leisure, the money nor the physical equipment for pleasure. Did they slave so long just to go to an occasional Iowa picnic? What else is there? They watch the waves come in at Venice. There wasn't any ocean where most of them came from, but after you've seen one wave, you've seen them all. The same is true of the airplanes at Glendale. If only a plane would crash once in awhile so that they could watch the passengers being consumed in a 'holocaust of flame,' as the newspapers put it. But the planes never crash.

Their boredom becomes more and more terrible. They realize that they've been tricked and burn with resentment. Every day of their lives they read the newspapers and went to the movies. Both fed them on lynchings, murder, sex crimes, explosions, wrecks, love nests, fires, miracles, revolutions, wars. This daily diet made sophisticates of them. The sun is a joke. Oranges can't titillate their jaded palates. Nothing can ever be violent enough to make taut their slack minds and bodies. They have been cheated and betrayed. They have slaved and saved for nothing.'

miss_lonelyhearts.title: Miss Lonelyhearts
miss_lonelyhearts.author: Nathanael West
miss_lonelyhearts.review: Human suffering as spectacle to be gawked and laughed at; human suffering as an unbearable burden to carry when cursed with the knowledge and responsibility of. You can escape to the farm upstate for a weekend and feel the relief of your own life experienced in isolation, but eventually you return to the city, filled with abuse and loss and dreams left to rot. Turning an advice columnist into a modern day Christ figure is a helluva move. The letters themselves are the best part; the rest can lean a touch too far into middle class ennui for my taste.

hanging_out.title: Hanging Out: The Radical Power of Killing Time
hanging_out.author: Sheila Liming
hanging_out.review:
Read about this one out in a Slate article and was really excited about it but found ultimately a little lacking in the depth I’d hope I find. Perhaps that’s intentional, as it is a “manifesto” rather than a true academic or theory text, but felt myself constantly wanting more from her as she skipped from surface sub tangent to surface sub tangent. If you’re gonna namedrop Adorno and Jameson and Benjamin, I just expect a little more. The balance of personal anecdotes to analysis skews a tad too far in the direction of personal anecdotes for my taste.

That being said, as a manifesto for how cool hanging out is (it’s one of my favorite things), it could do far less and be far less deep and as a primer on subjects like alienation and communal dissolution it works! There are even some interesting directions that I didn’t expect for a work like this, such as citing Kant’s idea of the sublime as something awe-inspiring outside human invention and creation as an explanation for why hanging out online can’t replicate in person living, a human invention only capable of delivering human pleasures, as well as expanding on reality television as an uncanny simulacrum of hanging out that we experience vicariously, the heightened and over the top dramas giving the easy drama and pleasure and interesting friends and places that the often more banal, drama free hard work of maintaining friendships and relationships in the normal places we live do not. There’s some obligatory citations (third places! How to Do Nothing!) That felt obligatory too, but that may be just my overexposure to literature around the subject. For the genre of hip contemporary book diagnosing our current problems, it’s pretty good! I just wanted a little more.

tapping_the.title: Tapping the Source
tapping_the.author: Kem Nunn
tapping_the.review:
Young men get their initiation into the hip world by bringing young women like lambs to the slaughter to older men; young women get theirs by giving their bodies to older men and then get tossed aside, forgotten, a footnote. Thought most of the prose/writing here was sturdy but unspectacular but Ike bringing the first set of teenaged girls to party with the older surf crew, imagining a young man just like him, taking his sister to the party that leads to her disappearance, realizing he’s doing what was done to her, is one of the best written pieces of fiction (if a tad on the nose) I think I’ve read about masculine initiations rituals and rites of passage buttressing the same patriarchal systems of violence that terrorize our mothers, daughters, sisters, and wives yet feeling stuck on the course of preserving them, their hold inescapable on the imagination of 18 year old boys.

The other portion I found compelling (beyond some cool surf writing) was the corruption of the pure surfing mysticism, the idea that money had come in and ruined Preston and Hound’s relationship with each other and their sport as the sport itself exploded into an iconic figure of culture and a multi-million dollar industry, the naivety and beauty and purity of sport and of being in the ocean corrupted by outside forces looking to make a buck or capitalize on the status symbol until one has no choice but to either give it up or give into it entirely.

Don’t think the ending was shocking direction for it head in but was left wishing it had been a little more visceral, a little more leaning into its sick impulses, rather than using implication and the narrator’s state of mind to leave it in a hazy fog that the reader can’t really fill in gruesome details into.

moby-dick_or,.title: Moby-Dick or, The Whale
moby-dick_or,.author: Herman Melville
moby-dick_or,.review: It's the greatest American novel that I've read. Transparently ripped by most every prominent American author to follow (my god does Pynchon take a lot from Melville). Primarily about being bored on a ship for months and doing the 19th century equivalent of a Wikipedia rabbit hole on whales and making things up to fill the gaps, and about being gay with your homies, but also about the gaping void at the heart of man that can't be filled, man's brutal conquering and conquest of the natural world and beauty for profit, and Melville flexing that he can write basically any type of thing, put it all in one novel, and all of it whips ass. A work so grand in scale and range that I feel really stupid trying to write anything about it, but also one that takes the time to include an entire chapter calling Dutch people virgins. So sick.

nazi_literature.title: Nazi Literature in the Americas
nazi_literature.author: Roberto Bolaño
nazi_literature.review: Sort of the (far more extreme, graphic and real, since it's by a Chilean who actually suffered under fascism) literary equivalent at laughing at dumbass online fascists and conspiracy theorists for years and then watching Charlottesville and an (incredibly goofy) attempted coup happen by all those same folks. Never would guess by its title how funny it is!

play_it.title: Play It As It Lays
play_it.author: Joan Didion
play_it.review: Clearly massively influential on the way basically everyone writes now. Not always sold on emotional flatness and emptiness or detachment as the baseline emotional tenor of a novel but this does it about as well as it can be executed, with enough saddening details of the past and an ending that crashes and hits the way it needs to to justify that mode. Didion's moments of searching for beauty and longing really work in contrast with the normally restrained, detached, emotionless style. The ultimate encapsulation of what living in LA does to an mf.

the_wretched.title: The Wretched of the Earth
the_wretched.author: Frantz Fanon
the_wretched.review:
Don’t think I can add anything that hasn’t been said a million times about this classic but will echo that this is about as good as it gets from both quality of analysis and ability to impart it with clarity and accessibility. Reading much of Fanon’s warnings to leaders at the time reads like a prediction of how colonial countries were successfully able to transition out of colonialism into a still extractive, dominant relationship with their ex-colonies. Fanon’s insistence on the need for reparations, for the colonizers to provide the tools (soil studies, outside capital) for the colonized to survive on their own, was the least heeded for this reason: the transition state were either beholden to the parasitic outsider or to starve on their own. Fanon’s assessment of the necessity of violence, both for the psyche of the people and to make the necessary break from the colonizing country, his detailing of how the native bourgeoise of the colonized are insufficient for African countries to reach first world standards of living, his assessment of the pacification of the post revolutionary natives by the popular revolutionary, the need for the resistance to go outside the city and into the rural areas to find broad power and the heart of the nation, his reframing of nationalism outside of a Western, reactionary context, the need for the masses to be educated on not just the evil of the colonized but of the nation they are trying to build: all incredibly laid out, all compelling, all understandable to someone without a university degree in this sort of thing.
The psychological profiles at the end feel like a footnote to the broader, far reaching societal ideas, but found that to be perhaps the most compelling portion of the text: the mentality and injustice that Fanon spent pages detailing and describing its impact localized to single individuals, colonizer and colonized, suffering the symptoms of the injustices they suffered under or helped impose. Will absolutely be returning to this and his other work in the future.

the_weird.title: The Weird and the Eerie
the_weird.author: Mark Fisher
the_weird.review:
First book of 2023 in the books! Nothing can compare to the psychic damage of Ready Player One being 2021's first book and this wasn't even trying to chase that high.

Fisher is probably the 21st century's finest critic, and the analysis here is of the wide range of books and movies is insightful in the works I've read/watch and convincing me to want to watch/read where I hadn't. He is slotting works into his own taxonomy of the weird and the eerie; the weird being a presence there that feels like it does not belong- whether it actually does not or it is outside the realm of the knowledge of the perceiver, the eerie being the absence of a presence that should be there (in two categories, the failure of absence (the feeling that there is something where there shouldn't be, i.e. a call of a bird that sounds like it has intent not characteristic of a bird), and the failure of presence (i.e., cityscapes overtaken by foliage and totally absent of human life)).

Fisher is far better when he's defining and analyzing the weird in fiction, analyzing it from different angles and eras. With the eerie he tends to drift away from it and return to it as he wraps up his thoughts on a work, which is perhaps a testament to how slippery the concept can be. He brings up capital as perhaps the ultimate eerie force- a failure of presence, the machinations that guide our lives and the world lacking a man behind the curtain pulling the strings, nothing human to latch onto to blame for the way things are. Perhaps, as he mentions repeatedly throughout Capitalist Realism, that is why it is hard for him to wrap his arms around it, as it is the water he is swimming in each day.

Particularly loved the Picnic at Hanging Rock, Lynch, Under The Skin, Lovecraft, and Phillip K Dick portions.

unto_the.title: Unto the Godless What Little Remains
unto_the.author: Mário Coelho
unto_the.review: Last book of 2022, written by an online friend. Wonderfully fast paced and focused on its premise of extended the rough ways we erase our pasts and regrets currently with technology to very literal and extreme extents in the future. The internet just wants someone with an original thought.

already_dead.title: Already Dead: A California Gothic
already_dead.author: Denis Johnson
already_dead.review: Frustrating in many ways but the good stuff in here is good enough to make it a solid read. Captures the fogginess and murkiness of true Northern California in a way I haven't seen anyone really attempt (the only thing that has ever evoked a vibe of the area for me is Thomas Ligotti's The Frolic), the windy roads and dense forests and commodified coastline, the rednecks and weed burnouts and small business tyrants and new age mystics. The weird timeline shenanigans and epistolary portions and changing perspectives add to this, the idea of never getting your head around what's happening around you, of only vague feelings of dread, doom, and uncertainty. If there's a sort of unifying thought, it's of the men throughout the narrative being already dead, both spiritually and in a fatalistic way, all their schemes and attempted loves an attempt to put off the inevitable and grasp at fleeting pleasure where no lasting stability or happiness is possible for them due to their condition. The women are a bit of cranks (it's Northern California after all), channeling spirits, doing mysticism, having Christian ecstasies, but they are far more in control of their fate and their desires than the men, even without the pretensions and plots. Have my critiques, namely that it's a bit too long, a tad too focused on the men, but there is payoff in the end, the death at the coastline and the ghost's all washed into shore waiting to welcome their newest member, another in the line of sinners and degenerates to haunt it forever, the psychosexual possession and psychedelic trip.

critique_of.title: Critique of Everyday Life, Volume 1
critique_of.author: Henri Lefebvre
critique_of.review:
Not typically a huge leftist theory nerd, but got a strong enough recommendation on this one and really loved it. Wish I'd reviewed sooner after reading because would have had more to say. Writing isn't what I would call accessible but for a text of this type it's surprisingly readable and does a good job defining its terms and repeating itself.

Has a clear vision of what is important, that being everyday , day to day existence, both in terms of what's wrong with the current system and what is important when implementing the economies of the future- what good is a revolution if it does not impact the daily lives of the people that it claimed to be fighting for? To the end of the failings of the current system, Lefebvre zooms in on alienation, of people being disconnected from their work because they have no control over what they do or how their employer operates, as well as being disconnected from the facts of everyday life outside the home because of it- the idea of a total disconnect from work and life rather than them being integrated. Lefebvre forsees the future anti-work movements and strongly repudiates them- recognizing the importance of work to both the functioning of society and the spirit of man, while acknowledging the current mode of production has made it so that work does not properly fulfill either of those needs. Much of this is an acknowledgement of incomplete information- one, on the existing knowledge of everyday life, and there are many thoughts on how to properly study and capture that, and two, of what the future 'total man' would like, a man unburdened by alienation- he theorizes, but acknowledges that is impossible to know until man reaches that point.

There's plenty of other stuff I'm neglecting, including a wholesale critique of religion taken from the French countryside, where all alienation in life is funneled into the church and totally captured, but there's a lot here and I read it a month ago. Found this one overall to be both interesting and life-affirming, taking the small moments and tedium and elevating to the level of political importance in a way I hadn't really seen.

a_thousand.title: A Thousand Mornings: Poems
a_thousand.author: Mary Oliver
a_thousand.review: Inspired by an emo song (of course) to read some of Mary Oliver, found myself really liking what she goes for. Very plain-spoken, to the point, not trying to impress the reader with artistic flourishes or complicated rhyme schemes or pretension but shooting for conveying emotional feeling and nearly always succeeding. The style fits what she's writing about, the beauty of the simplicity of nature, of taking life slow and observing the world around you, enjoying each cycle the world and life goes through, of appreciating life on its own terms rather than thrashing about looking for your ideal version of it. This is realistically like two or three layers above Rupi Kaur or Insta poetry but it's actually good so I'm willing to forgive those sins.

the_midrange.title: The Midrange Theory
the_midrange.author: Seth Partnow
the_midrange.review: Describes my job as the 'offensive line' of sports front offices. Good intro to a lot of basketball analytics, had some interesting insight/data that I hadn't seen elsewhere, but is also written to be accessible to beginners, to its advantage but also to its detriment in terms of digging deep on stuff.

farewell,_my.title: Farewell, My Lovely (Philip Marlowe, #2)
farewell,_my.author: Raymond Chandler
farewell,_my.review: Chandler gets his grip around what's interesting about Marlowe a little better here- it's the tough guy antics, sure, but it's also some of the melancholy, the inability to settle down and be in relations with other people or to value his own life. It's not quite on par with The Long Goodbye (what is?), where he faces down basically all of his own insecurities and neurosis and anxieties in one go, but this one allows the tough guy veneer to slip enough to keep it fascinating. Chandler of course keeps the prose flowing well, an onslaught of incisive descriptions about people and places and keep the twists and turns of the mysteries rolling fast enough to keep one locked in. Thankfully less convinced of his need to describe everything than The Big Sleep. And of course, the ending twist is one that's often been copied, and for good reason.

the_palm-wine.title: The Palm-Wine Drinkard
the_palm-wine.author: Amos Tutuola
the_palm-wine.review: Pretty entertaining, finds itself into a nice folkloric/magical realism groove that it never falls out of, constantly adding new fantastical elements filled with meaning. How far would you go to see your homie who hooked you up with the good wine if he passed on? No distance is too far. If I knew more about the traditions this was pulling from I probably would have gotten more out of it. All time chapter titles.

the_decapitated.title: The Decapitated Chicken and Other Stories
the_decapitated.author: Horacio Quiroga
the_decapitated.review: Read this one awhile back and forgot to log it. Tales from the Central American frontier, suffocated with death and encounters with the natural state of the world that cannot hope to be understood or tamed.

american_smoke.title: American Smoke
american_smoke.author: Iain Sinclair
american_smoke.review:
“‘You are not an American,’ Cal said. ‘You will never understand Americans. You want to see Olson and Dorn from their trips to England. Forget it, man. You’ll never begin.’ And I knew now that he was right. I was cured of my interests and obsessions. Cured by confrontation. Cured by the light on the sea. Their intensities would never be mine.”

That line, placed conveniently on the final page of the book, basically does the job of summarizing it for me. Perhaps its the attempted scope of all of North America, perhaps it’s the unfamiliar terrain, but whatever the case Sinclair struggles to make his sense impressions and interviews coalesce into something coherent in the way that he surveyed London in the other one I read, The Last London. He goes around interviewing his favorite authors and those that remember them, but the memories are fading, the insights gone- he can never get much out of anyone, it all feeling unsatisfying to both him and you. In the hands of a worse author this would be pretty terrible but Sinclair is good enough to make this a good bad roadtrip, leaving you with plenty on the futility of chasing around the dead/trying to understand what makes anyone, let alone private famous authors, tick and plenty of beautiful lines about the psychogeography of America. Definitely picks up when he hits the West Coast, or at least it does for someone with more experience in the locales he's spending time in.

wuthering_heights.title: Wuthering Heights
wuthering_heights.author: Emily Brontë
wuthering_heights.review: Didn't find myself blown away by the total package of this one, possibly a wrong headspace thing, but creates a phenomenal cast of characters that are all unlikeable snivelling dorks but nonetheless compelling in each their own unique ways. Linton really the model for entire generations of soft boys (and Heathcliff for the brooding pieces of shit out there.) Finds a convincing way out of the wreckage of human jealousy and spite and degradation in the love the cousins find at the end (the Victorians really loved their incest huh). Loved the storytelling gimmick of the house keeper passing down family gossip, helped reveal the delusions and lies of the characters without telling the reader directly.

chaos_charles.title: Chaos: Charles Manson, the CIA, and the Secret History of the Sixties
chaos_charles.author: Tom O'Neill
chaos_charles.review: Both a damning dive into the lies of the American government, from their narrative of the Manson case to MKUltra/CHAOS to JFK, and a descent into obsession and madness on the part of the author (to his own admission). Raises a million questions, gives very few answers, but isn't that one can find 40 years on, with half the players dead and the other half either pushed from the truth or in charge of making sure it doesn't get out. If there's one thing that can be established from this, it's that the official motivation of the Manson murders of attempted race war ignition and music industry intimidation is bullshit and the process to get there was rigged from the start in the government's favor. The gambit of swapping the defense attorney and leaking is remarkable, as is the outright striking of evidence from the record. Of course, there is no judge, no prosecution for them, so it's just interviews of old men denying their lies in front of their face without repercussion. The MKUltra/CHAOS stuff is insane- there's so much missing, and O'Neill gets a tad unfocused, but he's pointing at a few things that are pretty damn revelatory but he cannot prove are true: 1. That Charles Manson was likely an agent of the state, and possibly doing brainwashing/learned brainwashing from government operatives 2. The failure of MKUltra is possibly overstated- the Shaver stuff seems to indicate that they were able to get a man to kill on command with no recollection of doing so, and they were able to drive Jack Ruby into insanity. Hard to tell anyone about without sounding insane, I'll say that much.

the_last.title: The Last London: True Fictions from an Unreal City
the_last.author: Iain Sinclair
the_last.review: Blokecore- can almost hear a man reading this in a British accent at points, that's how strong the voice is. Works not as a comprehensive or statistical study of London but one man on the ground, talking with his friends, seeing how the city has shifted away from him and his generation into the hands of venture capital and a new world. Committed wholly to its psychogeographical nature- when discussing cyclists and rent a bikes, Sinclair does not feel the need to tell you that bikes are better for the environment (you are smart! you already know this!)- but only how it affects the flow of the city, how it has made the city more papered with adverts than ever before, how it has taken the tow path from walkers.

nevada.title: Nevada
nevada.author: Imogen Binnie
nevada.review: A cult classic as 'ground zero for modern trans literature' but also for good reason. Not really a book about the internet but one of the best books about the internet I've read, capturing its positives as a tool of connection to other perspectives and ideas one might never encounter otherwise but also one that allows one to bury the messiness of your own experience in pursuit of a suitable authentic cool self to present to the world and to be perceived as. Also cuts out the rollicking self-mythology that most road novels fall into about drunken adventures and stolen cars and meeting pretty girls and cuts it to a ruthless core- what got you on the road (likely, your own narcissism and emotional problems), and when do you realize that there's no end to it where you find yourself and all your problems are solved and that problems may not be wholly solvable at all. Is also certainly trying to capture the eras of life that Binnie has experienced, life as both a self-loathing closeted eggshell and as an out trans women and drawing the thread between them of constant dissociation and an inability to access let alone express one's own feelings and either living days in a an apathetic haze or grasping clumsily to try to find them. Work stylistically as an exercise in voice above beauty, capturing more of a conversational tone, but it works incredibly well with the subject matter in question.

an_apprenticeship.title: An Apprenticeship or The Book of Pleasures
an_apprenticeship.author: Clarice Lispector
an_apprenticeship.review: Hard to write about; one of my favorite books I've read. Corny in some ways but also wholly committed to the interior life, to living a life rather than sleepwalking through it, and to the process of joining that life with another, and to really dig into that one must venture into corniness. Lispector prose is beautiful, poetic, capturing interior moments of beauty. One I wanted to revisit immediately after finishing it.

endgame_&.title: Endgame & Act Without Words
endgame_&.author: Samuel Beckett
endgame_&.review: The end of life- nothing left but clawing desperately for painkillers that aren't coming, the ghost of your parents in trash cans, and the failing visions of those you failed when you had your chance.

the_disappearance.title: The Disappearance of Rituals: A Topology of the Present
the_disappearance.author: Byung-Chul Han
the_disappearance.review: Some interesting insights, some a little bit eye-rolly (drone strikes are bad because you can't look someone in the eyes when you kill them!), but nothing that blows the mind or really does anything that hasn't been seen in other diagnoses of modern alienation. There's some good high-minded prose here which he substitutes for data. His distaste for the idea of authenticity and personal brands and production of the self, the death of language as a source of play, and the gone rituals as a way of grounding individuals in the purpose of society are the most interesting things at play here. Good as a primer if you haven't read anything on the subject but not sure it's breaking a ton of new ground

psychogeography_disentangling.title: Psychogeography: Disentangling the Modern Conundrum of Psyche and Place
psychogeography_disentangling.author: Will Self
psychogeography_disentangling.review: Very little psychogeography to be found here- more of a travel blog, and not a particularly insightful one at that. Your friend with too much money and no job can give you a comparable experience, although some of the illustrations are cool. The opening chapter of walking New York in quest for meaning with regards to his mother is the highlight, a wander without purpose finding meaning until he can attach her real background to a real address an interesting part of the whole psychogeographical project. Sadly, there's far too little of that and far too much of 'this happening in this foreign city.' Predictably strongest when he's actually on his own home turf of England

bluets.title: Bluets
bluets.author: Maggie Nelson
bluets.review: Don't know if I would've read this if I had known it was the origin of the Instagram story quote of 2018 ('When I was alive, I aimed to be a student not of longing but of light.'), but found this one to be a mostly enjoyable, occasionally frustrating reflection on heartbreak and melancholy and loss and the refracted ways we process them. Shies away from being personal while being incredibly self-centered which is part of the point but also a cause for some of that frustration.

beautiful_world,.title: Beautiful World, Where Are You
beautiful_world,.author: Sally Rooney
beautiful_world,.review:
Is very clearly Rooney grappling with the way international stardom has changed her life and her own purpose as a novelist, particular as one who stays in her lane of small scale, romantic and friendship type novels. At one point she has her author insert character ask the question of what does it matter, these domestic novels about friendship and love and the daily lives of normal people when the world is burning down around us and there's so much suffering in the third world propping up the first. All the while, the style here only leans further in, with plenty of descriptions of the most minute details of the character's life, a glance at a phone or the exact way they scrolled, and the most politically motivated character of the bunch admits that his foremost concern in life is really the two girls involved. In the end she doesn't come to a clear answer other than that is the way things are- one cannot take in the whole world in all its suffering, not all at once, and trying to do so is foolhardy, a path to misery. One's most intimate concerns are still the same: family, friends, love, community, and art that engages that sympathy will exist and be important as long as we have humans around to read it. Alice's answer seems to be that reading can elicit love akin to Jesus, a love with the expectation of nothing in return, a possible force for good, but in doing so acknowledges she cares for no one other than herself despite getting this feeling from literature.

To me, this represents a level-up in the prose as well, as Rooney improves in the sections where she flexes her muscles quite a bit (in particular the wedding scene was fantastic, capturing the beauty of the moment between Eileen and her mom/sister while also capturing the sadness of their arguments and their likely inability to actually reconcile them in spite of a beautiful moment in time) and her dialogue is in her typical cutting way, short words that cut to the core rather than trying to dance with too much of a realistic tone.

As usual, Rooney does a good job with accumulating details, the little resentments that pile up, who visited who, who didn't call who, who refuses to bare their soul and confess any genuine feelings, until they boil over, until the character reach a contradiction that demands resolution. And as it seems to occur in Rooney's novel, it's not always a grand change, but a small one, and an acceptance of the nature of other people, and one's fate in life. Normal People ends in accepting monogamy, in accepting throwing away one's own aspirations in order to be with other people, the ones you love- this one takes it a step forward, accepting monogamy, accepting irrelevance, and in Eileen's case even accepting having a child and raising them in the horrible world that presents her so much anxiety.

duino_elegies.title: Duino Elegies
duino_elegies.author: Rainer Maria Rilke
duino_elegies.review:
Woefully unequipped to review poetry this good so I'll just quote one of my favorite sections:

We- we evaporate in our feelings. We exhale ourselves
and vanish. Our scent grows fainter as it passes
from ember to ember. Someone may say to us:
'Yes. You've gotten into my blood. This room,
the springtime- it's full of you.' But what for?
It can't hold us. We vanish in and around it.
And even those who are beautiful- can anyone keep them
from vanishing? The appearance of beauty
seems fixed in their faces for always, and, always,
it fades. Everything we are evaporates-
like dew from the spring grass, or steam from hot food.
A smile-where does it go! A glance- new, warm,
a gesture of the heart- oh it hurts to say it,
but this what we are! Does the universe taste
of us then, since we spill ourselves into it?
Do the angels really retrieve only what is theirs,
what has spilt from them, or do they at times,
by accident, get a little of our existence mixed in?
-Just a little, mixed in with their features,
like that certain look on the faces of pregnant women
which they don't even notice as they spiral back
into themselves. (And why should they notice?)

earthlings.title: Earthlings
earthlings.author: Sayaka Murata
earthlings.review: Falls firmly in the category of “author rewrites their previous book’s themes and turns focus just slightly different” but the switch in tone from the far more grounded, simple day to day realism of CSW vs. the fantasy filled and depraved darkness of this one is enough that it still feels fresh to me. CSW also felt far more concerned with labor/work expectations with reproduction and marriage as a secondary focus; this one reverses that and adds much more graphic content and taboo. The main character also feels slightly more relatable than Keiko in CSW- while she is still a strange one, much of her alienation is shaped by the trauma inflicted upon her by abusive unlistening parents and a molesting teacher (her mouth literally stops working for taste, as does one of her ears). The idea of sex and desire was with her at one point, and returns at another, but her experience in society leaves her feeling none of it while she is still trying to make her way inside. The “aliens” at the end and their actions feel like Murata expressing a comically exaggerated thesis statement of her fiction; the only way out is to tear down every thought, every preconception, even your participation in society, until all that is left is self preservation, animal instinct and your mind to try to start anew. That this leads to cannibalism and a cathartic exit to a spaceship is either a sign of the narrator’s total break from reality (and the futility of attempting to escape other people/the world at large) , or that in those moments they were finally able to throw off the eyes implanted in them by growing up in the world and were richly rewarded for it, whichever you decide.

waste.title: Waste
waste.author: Andrew F. Sullivan
waste.review:
Despite being about Northern neighbors, captures the very specific emptiness and doomedness of abandoned Rust Belt industrial towns in a way that precious few novels dare attempt (goes up in the canon with Kathe Koja's The Cipher). There is no opportunity, no escape, no path out for the men trapped in the pit of the city- there is only shitty jobs that destroy your body, sleeping in a hovel for the rest of your days, precious few women around to distract from the loneliness and rage and disenfranchisement they experience. Waste is a dark novel, heads smashed in by the bottom of boots and bowling balls, lips melting in flames like wax on a candle, a trail of dead and broken bodies strewn across town, but it never feels unearned, the circumstances and desperation and thwarted masculinity all leading here. The plot of the novel, as much as it can be described, is bumbling, a collection of misunderstandings and mistakes leading only to more pain, more suffering, more rot in Larkhill. This is what happens when industry leaves a town, the jobs and the money flowing out, leaving teens to turn to neo-Nazism in search of any sort of meaning or purpose, a past to connect to, and the adults to turn to the opioids for the wounds they can't get the proper care for.

The closing image- a child gasping for air, trapped trying to take his own jacket off, a crowd of onlookers watching, sitting there, doing nothing, just taking in the spectacle of self destruction- feels apt for the novel, and the cities like Larkhill themselves in relation to the wealthy countries they reside in.

the_nickel.title: The Nickel Boys
the_nickel.author: Colson Whitehead
the_nickel.review: The prose in here can be a tad perfunctory, never anything wrong with it but not wowing you on a sentence level. That being said, it works well enough for the lean devastating package to work its magic, the characters and their struggle for their place in a school and a world that's actively to destroy them so compelling that the tragedy that haunts the entire book and the twist pack an emotional punch on the reader. Whitehead's treading on some well-trod ground thematically, with Elwood the MLK quoting child with the noblest of ideals and actions vs. the more cynical Turner, who's only about survival and making it through the next day standing in for grander ideas of what is a person's role in the midst of injustice and struggle. Whitehead does well to play his cards mostly to his own chest, letting character and narrative and conflict dictate the direction rather than trying to collide headlong into some fortune cookie morsel. A must for your mom who loves historical novels about historic trauma.

revenge_of.title: Revenge of the Lawn / The Abortion / So the Wind Won't Blow it All Away
revenge_of.author: Richard Brautigan
revenge_of.review:
5 stars for Revenge of the Lawn, which breaks free of the trout related constraints of Trout Fishing In America while retaining the episodic, one to two page snippet structure of it and the wit and humor that permeates his other work. Think that's the mode I prefer for Brautigan, as evidenced by the overall 4 stars here- The Abortion starts incredibly promising, with the library of unpublished books that anyone can publish, an ode to amateur artistic creation- the women writing about growing plants in a windowless room was a moving metaphor for that process. However, once it shifts into the titular abortion, I found less to like- nothing wrong, just not terribly compelling. So The Wind Won't Blow It All Away is a little more in keeping with the Brautigan that I like- an ode to a pre televisual America, in all its dangers (as evidenced by the death of the poor kid) and its eccentricities. A family brings its living room to the river, fishing and not eating anything that it fishes, characters whittle their days on porches in mostly solitude and silence, kids run free of parental supervision. The death is Brautigan's tacit admission that this world he longs for was a more dangerous one, but one he felt home in- something weirder, indulgent of the strange ways humans conduct their lives, every individual made to construct their own meaning free from a box pumping them with prefigured purpose, forced to live outside in spaces with each other. Of the river living room couple, he says:

'It looked like a fairy tale functioning happily in the post-World War II gothic of America before television crippled the imagination of America and turned people indoors and away from living out their own fantasies with dignity.'

which may function as a thesis for a lot Brautigan's shtick as whole.

the_fisherman.title: The Fisherman
the_fisherman.author: John  Langan
the_fisherman.review: All Fisherman Have Dead Wives. Definitely one of the better non Lovecraft cosmic horror pieces I've come across, with some harrowing imagery, particularly of the undead sea where all your worst thoughts are spewed out and toxic, and of that not being some otherworldly place, but the true reality, the constructed one we live in just a veil over the curtain just like our outward faces to the world concealing those hideous thoughts. Found most compelling the opening, which was no horror at all but just dudes trying to pick up their lives in the wake of tragedy in the form of a mindless hobby, and the story within the story structure of it, the oral history passed down that feels natural and warps with the teller. Some of the concluding actions and horror of this let it down a little bit but the buildups were good enough to sell even those weaker portions.

barbarian_days.title: Barbarian Days: A Surfing Life
barbarian_days.author: William Finnegan
barbarian_days.review:
Makes you really want to keep a journal. On one hand it is just a great chronicle of being on the cutting edge of surfing, riding spots no one else has ridden before, hopping from exotic country to exotic country and doing all the coolest life shit possible. Read just for that, this is a page turner and works exceptionally well on that level. But I found this far more interesting for its reflection on sport and aging, the sands of the world you were raised in and formed yourself changing around you leaving you either to wither away or do your best to change even if it's not the same and the scene (and your body) isn't as good as it used to be. The reflection in one of the final chapters of having to do exercises to maintain the ability to surf, that his youthful 'any exercise solely for the purpose of bodily maintenance is death; anything chasing something is life' is one I shared exactly and can no longer hold. And in general, Finnegan does a good job threading the needle on reflection, not chiding his young self for the decisions but accepting them and the reasoning behind them, and does a great job reporting the tension between freedom and commitment, chasing fun and excitement versus upholding commitment and fulfilling work/relationships, and how that evolves with time without casting too harsh an eye on his past decisionmaking. The San Francisco section where the old surfer speaks his piece 'against dereliction' is sort of the ethos of this- a commitment to pursuing life and the joy of their sport without abandoning the real world and being sucked into it entirely.

Also contains some of the best reflections on male friendship, and particularly male friendship in close proximity on trips I've seen, the butting of heads, the push and pull, the inevitable irritation with even their most simple habits. The reflections on youthful introductions to violence and how ingrained that was in America as a whole and in his childhood as a whole are detailed, every aspect of his life imperiled with it. One can see his surfing as a way of reconciling himself with that violence that lives inside him, finding harmony with the destructiveness in the waves by taming him on the board, and in some sense taming the testosterone and anger that lives inside of him.

Stylistically, Finnegan does a wonderful job of imparting lingo to the audience without repeating himself and describing the ferocity and grandeur of the ocean without repeating himself or growing tiresome. His tone never reaches too hard for self mockery or deprecation, which I think is what a times irritates me with memoir.

Got me to finally buck up and buy a surfboard, so you know it's good.

empire_of.title: Empire of the Senseless
empire_of.author: Kathy Acker
empire_of.review:
GET RID OF MEANING. YOUR MIND IS A NIGHTMARE THAT HAS BEEN EATING YOU: NOW EAT YOUR MIND.

Feels very of a piece with Acker's Don Quixote, not just in her obvious stylistic trademarks of vulgarity and postmodern flourish, characters wondering the world fucking and fighting and hurting and loving with little narrative sense to their actions, no real arcs to be had, just hurt and demented characters lashing out at each other, loving and hating at the same time. The endings even mirror each other; Acker giving the final sentence to wish for a better world, one where the characters would not be abused and hurt, living on the fringes of society, made to be the outcasts they are.

Don Quixote is zeroed in on the Catholic church for a decent part of the narrative (at least in my years on recollection), where this one is broader, aiming at capitalism, the nuclear family, and of course the patriarchy. But yet even as she critiques the status quo, she prophetically (see: Arab Spring, Occupy, CHAZ, etc.) sees the failings of utopian politics in her Algerian revolution taking France- anger without clear defined purpose, a desire for power with no ideas on how to properly wield, a lack of organization and structure leading to violence and disorder, and, in the end, an inability to shrug off the logic of the present world even presented the chance to build a better world. 20 years before Mark Fisher coined 'capitalist realism,' Acker here has a text that embodies it. She presents no clear solutions, has no answers for what that better future she hopes for is- one almost reads the final chapter as a shrug of the shoulders, her character (as in Don Quixote) finding some semblance of peace but the society around them still the same, nothing but an undying hope in a possible better future to leave the text with. Her idea is to disregard the idea of meaning until one comes out on the other side with something different, but she cannot reach that other side alone, this text itself an experiment on trying to reach for it.

Stylistically, this retains a lot of Acker's punk energy, grotesque sex and violence, character motivations scattered across the board. Still the best instance of this brand of postmodernism I know of (sorry Burroughs, and with hope towards Dennis Cooper's The Sluts at some point in the future)

bright_lights,.title: Bright Lights, Big City
bright_lights,.author: Jay McInerney
bright_lights,.review:
Mommy issues the book- although of course, the mommy issues are well hidden, the narrator’s bravado and party lifestyle and hating his job and heartbreak over his wife leaving him all covering over for himself and for his audience the fact that he’s a small boy who misses his mom. I’m usually not the fondest of 2nd person narration but here it works (at least for me), an indication of someone seeing his life in a lens from the outside rather than living it, running from the person that lives inside his head and living for the dreams implanted in him, living the life he’s supposed to live rather than anything to do with his own desires.

And sure, it is a book about a white dude partying hard because he is sad, and how that partying is so sad, and how having the dream well-paying white collar job at the magazine makes you sad, and how his wife not loving him anymore is sad, and all the same tropes that everyone is sick of. And if that’s not your bag, this one probably isn’t good enough to change your mind. But this one’s contempt for its characters is enough along with the unique voice to make this work for me as a compelling enough spin on the subgenre, especially given the sheer Freudianness of it all, especially when he’s buried at the tit of his ex co worker or crawling out of the metaphorical womb of the night into morning, begging the bread man for bread, a boy trapped in a man’s body, crying out for his mother who has left him alone on the Earth.

the_drowned.title: The Drowned World
the_drowned.author: J.G. Ballard
the_drowned.review:
Ballard's focus in his 2nd novel is the same as it is in his other work I've read, on the evolution of humanity and what paths it will head in the future. Unlike in The Atrocity Exhibition and Crash, however, Ballard is not interested in humanity advancing forward and bending to its new technologies and inventions, but a regression, back to the era of lizard domination and skyrocketing temperatures (timely eh?), man on the run in the jungle as prey rather than at the top of the food chain. Still, he keeps some of his trademark core here- regardless of the direction evolution heads, man's fundamental instinct is self destruction and confusion, as illustrated by our protagonist's unclear attempted suicide/accident buried in the planetarium swamp. Was his attempt at self termination intentional or not? It's a question that permeates the book for a number of chapters, and one that faces humanity as a whole as we head to environmental catastrophe that mirrors the one in The Drowned World.

From a stylistic perspective, interesting to see how decidedly linear and non-experimental the plot is compared to the far more episodic narratives of Crash and Atrocity, and how much Ballard is pulling from Conrad, which is ever present but is far less buried (we even have our Colonel Kurtz!)

gravity’s_rainbow.title: Gravity’s Rainbow
gravity’s_rainbow.author: Thomas Pynchon
gravity’s_rainbow.review:
Brilliant, frustrating, all things all at once, simultaneously sad to leave it behind and excited to put it aside and not look at for years. Casts aside any semblance of resolution or linear plot to follow in favor of randomness, a Poisson distribution of bomb locations that decides whether you live or die, and the paranoia of not knowing whether you're next, not knowing whether They are closing in on you and your journey is over and you'll be left castrated and broken. Perhaps the archetypical postmodern novel, a World War II epic where all historical significance is stripped out, all gravitas of the deaths of millions is excluded, there's no moral at the end of the day, no heroic political figure to cast in brilliant light, just 400 characters groping for pleasure and purpose in the midst of broader historical movements beyond their understanding.
If there's a main thing Gravity's Rainbow seems to be circling, its World War II and its place as the culmination of both technological advancement and the expansion of the modern security state. As far as there is a plot, it is a quest by many different forces to understand and capture the German V-2 rocket, which our 'main' character Tyrone Slothrop is connected to by the locations of his hookups and which other forces hold as a mystical deity. The V-2 brings soundless and sightless Death, it advancing so fast that its victims can not possibly hear it until they are already dead. Meanwhile the security agencies, and particularly the OSS (the precursor to the CIA) is lurking in every corner, conducting experiments on children and adults alike, lurking behind every corner, always in wait to swallow you up and disappear you (or your children, or your lover) from the world without a trace. Both combine to overwhelm the characters, to lean on mystical simplifications or be unable to parse signal from noise, sliding into fantasy or paranoia, the world too complex for anyone to coherent sense of it.
Pynchon's writing is, of course, top tier, drifting seamlessly between characters, finding a brilliant emotional image and exploring it and then moving onto the next one. So many of them can be used to explicate things swirling around the novel; Roger Mexico pissing on Pointsmann's desk and making a joke of a fancy officer dinner perhaps the ultimate encapsulation of a lot of Pynchon's whole deal (scoring a small personal victory over the overwhelming forces that subjugate and control you, but ultimately leaving the world largely unchanged), Byron the never dying lightbulb a sign of a perfect piece of technology too useful and not harmful enough for the world it was born into, forced to go on the run, and Gottfried burning up inside the 00000 rocket, gaping in awe and wonder at the beautiful horrors humanity has unleashed upon the world, his screams unheard and unnoticed, a silent cry and an unknown death in a war and world full of them.
All this, and it also spends an immense amount of time comparing rockets and rainbows to penises. 5 stars. Not my favorite Pynchon, but by far the most Pynchon Pynchon. Excited to spend weeks reading what other people got out of it and all the stuff I missed.

exhalation.title: Exhalation
exhalation.author: Ted Chiang
exhalation.review: Really great humanist sci-fi- Chiang has the art of explaining a sci fi concept quick enough to get the ideas across down to a science, the focus remaining always on the human struggle that comes with the high concept work rather than losing itself in its concepts. Chiang rarely dazzles on a sentence level, but his simple direct prose gives these stories the feeling of something passed down and keeps the focus on the ideas/parts of our lives he's interrogating. Pleasantly surprised by how I enjoyed this.

a_man.title: A Man of Shadows (John Nyquist #1)
a_man.author: Jeff Noon
a_man.review: Really liked a lot of the world built here and found some of the images here compelling (particularly in the climax, Nyquist fumbling through the fog to save the last piece of the world he cares about amidst the horrors of his life) but also found the characterization/emotional stakes here never really clicked with me in a real way. Definitely worth checking out The City and The City is your thing, but doesn't quite match up to Mieville's prose/character/world sadly.

red_harvest.title: Red Harvest (The Continental Op #1)
red_harvest.author: Dashiell Hammett
red_harvest.review: A town and a man cursed by their past and the deals they made, based loosely on the story of Frank Little and the town of Butte (Google if you have the time), which is really the story of 20th century America as a whole: deals with the devil to prevent organized labor from seizing control and paying the consequences from putting the devil in power. Poisonville is a factory town, run by a wealthy industrialist who empowered gangsters to shut down the IWW in his town (interestingly, Hammett was an ex-Pinkerton who claimed he was offered 5 grand to murder Little) and now they exist out of his control- his son seems to be trying to blow the whistle on their corruption when he is murdered in what turns out to be the act of spurned ex lover but points to a broader coverup that cannot be turned from even as the original case closes. What follows is a descent for the town into madness, parties turned into shooting galleries, banks robbed in broad daylight, liquor safe houses burst into flames, ending in the only place that it could end when the town's fragile equilibrium is disturbed: nearly all the major players dead, the institutions of police and media discredited, and a detective who finds himself enjoying the chaos he has thrust the town into, even if only for the taste of righteous comeuppance it provided. All that remains is the wealthy industrialist, inured from the chaos on the streets and in town, with nothing left in his hands but the town and his house on the hill, his son's coffin and the lonely death that awaits him. Soaked in atmosphere, features the toughest of tough guy, know it all detectives, an excellent read, and one that birthed a whole lot of noir novels and movies that followed.

the_plague.title: The Plague
the_plague.author: Albert Camus
the_plague.review: I'll confess that I didn't particularly The Stranger, although that might have been high school bad taste rather than any issue with the book itself. Thankfully, I gave Camus another shot and read this one, primarily because I've had the plague (or Covid) myself for the last week or so. And if one goes into this looking for 'prescient' real-world analogs, they'll find plenty to go nuts over. What I found most interesting though, was this as an allegory for Nazi occupation of France, a seemingly unconquerable evil that one could only do small bits to resist, and the pieces of existential commentary sprinkled throughout, each character making and explaining their actions with the background of the plague forcing them into situations where self preservation conflicts with their morals. Most compelling, I found, was the journalist, a veteran of the utopian Spanish Civil War project, who tries constantly to escape to return to his beloved, proclaiming love the only value worth living for, but when the moment comes of his escape he bails, finding the urge to fight for humanity, finding himself tied to his friends and the common cause of humanity once again. One image, however, stands out above all else: Tarrou and Rieux, bathing in the sea, enjoying the company of each other for the first time due to the constant demands of trying to save the populace, a moment of beauty and solace in the face of endless suffering and wear.

perfume_the.title: Perfume: The Story of a Murderer
perfume_the.author: Patrick Süskind
perfume_the.review: Well done pastiche of another era of French novel. Does more with smell descriptions than most authors can do with far more tangible senses.

the_cipher.title: The Cipher
the_cipher.author: Kathe Koja
the_cipher.review:
Captures all the worst feelings of a Midwest winter, the cold locking you inside and crawling through the floorboards, keeping you constantly on edge, leaving you with nothing to do except for drink and stew in your misery, in your self-pity and self-hatred and resentment of the people around you, even the ones you love, until you find in your apartment building a gaping mystical black hole in which to lock yourself away from anyone and everyone and complete your artistic masterpiece of self-destruction. Koja is from Detroit, and it certainly shows.

The first five or so chapters of this, until Nicholas returns to the site of the Funhole, are so finely sharpened that I was convinced this was a classic in the making. Unfortunately, it was not to be, as everything from the atmosphere to the prose takes a dip when the art group shows up, and while it picks back up at the end it still doesn’t reach the sheer unbridled heights of that beginning. That beginning though, is exquisite, seemingly every line something that could be ripped as a quotable, the monstrosity and allure of the Funhole, the destructive harmfulness (and joy) of Nicholas and Nakota’s relationship all rendered in beautiful detail, sentences that stretch on searching for beauty and horror and nearly always finding it. The rest is slightly more workmanlike and buttoned down, although Koja does return to some of those lengths to generate some of the horror of the ending.

The Funhole is partially Rorshach test of what the reader wants to get out of this particular novel. As for me (and given it’s partially how Koja explains it in the end), it seems to be a manifestation of Nicholas’ self-loathing, a destructive force that cannot function without him and gives him the power and uninhibitedness to express and act on his desire to destroy himself and those around hhim and the loathing he has for everything; his not girlfriend girlfriend, artists in his community, their artwork. In his state at the beginning he is stuck in stasis, ripping up his drunkedly written poems, being used by Nakota but too scared to rock the boat to ask for anything of her, working a dead-end job at a video store, drinking heavily every night. The Funhole gives him the impetus for action, but only on his self-destructive tendencies, the push to turn the coiled negative feelings inside himself into something manifested on the outside, starting as a hole in his hand and slowly turning his body into a slick inhuman skin that throws itself into nearly certain death. There is a lot of Freud/Lacan here, the death drive manifested as the hole that Nicholas and Nakota are helplessly drawn to without understanding why, the lack of desire represented as a literal black hole in the wall.

It’s unfortunate Koja falls to the trap of seemingly half the novels I’ve read in the last year, of spending time with critiques of artists and how annoying they are, because I think this shaved down and edited slightly heavier in the back half has the chance to be a cornerstone of the genre. But the incessant obnoxiousness of the artists takes away from what is the real star of the show, Nicholas and his journey, and while it’s partially self-inflicted of bringing people around even if you don’t actually want them around, that isn’t really used/leaned into heavily enough by Koja, too focused on criticizing some artist likely long-forgotten to get to the real meat of this book. Still, excited to read more of her at some point in the near future.

the_hellbound.title: The Hellbound Heart
the_hellbound.author: Clive Barker
the_hellbound.review:
Starting Spooktober 2021 with a classic short novella which Clive Barker eventually turned into the Hellraiser film franchise.

The opening chapter is a masterclass, and had me convinced this was going to be a 5 star banger- a lurid sensory overload full of plenty of disgusting imagery, occultic mystery, and psychosexual implications. The cenobites are left mostly mysterious, the terrors that await Frank much greater than what already witnessed but left to only the reader's devices.

What follows, then, is a slight disappointment, as it moves to more domestic concerns, an unhappy marriage with a wife never satisfied with anything, a friend who pines for her husband but never has the courage to stand up for herself. Even when the horror kicks back, it stays with the character of Frank, a horrifying reconstruction from semen blood spilled by his illicit lover and his quest to stay in the realm of the flesh by any means necessary, rather than the mystical extra-dimensional hedonist monsters. I can see why Barker did it, but I am slightly disappointed given the promise shown in the first chapter.

Barker's main concern seems to be with character's incapability of being satisfied, a never ending quest for more and more pleasure which leads them into contact with these extradimensional beings who's idea of pleasure is so intermingled with suffering as to be indistinguishable.
