The real treat here though, beyond that central theme, is of the imagery, Frank's sense nightmare, his ejaculate intermingling with spilled blood to form a new being, wearing the skin of his boring bougie brother, the hooks of the cenobites back in him, at last preventing him from making off with his brother's wife and life.

Overall, a classic novella for good reason, and one wouldn't mind revisiting at some point. High 4, and makes me want to rewatch Hellraiser.

eugene_onegin.title: Eugene Onegin
eugene_onegin.author: Alexander Pushkin
eugene_onegin.review:
The ruins brought on by youth and manhood, affected world-weariness and cynicism colliding with youthful idealism and pride to ruin and end everyone around them's lives. A testament to the allure and draw of that pride that Pushkin after writing this ended up meeting the same fate as the poet Lemsky- a slight and an advance to his women drawing him into a fatal duel. Our 'hero' is not at all heroic and Pushkin leaves him on his knees, pathetically appealing to the women he once spurned for her hand as she dismisses him cruelly. Pushkin is making an appeal against his world-weariness, against his cynicism against friends and neighbors, against his disregard for his youth and pleasures of life, against his cruel eye casting down on others around them, only able to recognize the beauty of his would-be lover when she is in the hands of another.

The writing obviously suffers from translation, poetry never able to be captured outside of its native tongue, but in general felt like the translation I got did a solid job of capturing some of the original beauty. There are clunky moments, where it feels like it's stretching to match the rhyme scheme, but in general the move to try to capture the original nature of it is a good one (in contrast to other approaches, such as Nabokov's literal translation). Would love to read this in original form, but not sure I have learning Russian on the slate for my next 5 years. Interesting also that the text itself seems to be grappling with the barrier between languages and poetics, in several cases talking about the difficulty of conveying romantic feelings in Russian vs. French.

Pretty good, and we even get Pushkin doing foot guy stuff and then apologizing for it several chapters later. Fun to read this after doing a bunch of other Russians to see where a lot of the archetypes and influences lie.

been_down.title: Been Down So Long It Looks Like Up to Me
been_down.author: Richard Fariña
been_down.review:
Richard Farina was a contemporary at Cornell with Thomas Pynchon, and it shows, as there is a lot of what eventually defined Pynchon present here- the long lists placed in the middle of prose, the shadowy conspiracies, and a general humorous irreverence. If you squint hard enough, you even see some Doc Sportello in Gnossus, just aged up 20 years in world-weariness and cynicism.

The who influenced who question of two contemporaries and friends is always fraught, and I can't claim to have read enough to say who is who. However, it is always weird seeing someone put their spin on a style that belongs so distinctly (at least in my memory) to someone else, and I think Farina pales in comparison to what Pynchon eventually went on to do with it. That's not to say they're aren't phenomenal sections of writing in here, whether it be party scenes or Gnossus' apocalyptic vision in Chapter 14, but on the whole it did feel partially like a pale imitation.

This is a college novel to the core, although it owes plenty of its lineage to Kerouac and the Beats as it follows the formula of a semi-autobiographical protagonist stumbling his way through a search for greater enlightenment. Gnossus is Immune and Exempt, both in a literal sense (of exemption from the draft) and in a more spiritual sense (of attempted immunity from politics and the petty concerns of mortal beings). He correctly diagnoses the Ivy league university as where the wealthy go to cosplay at freedom and libertinism, but he is trapped- the straight world is even worse (particularly notable is the vision, which portrays the world outside the campus as literally a fiery nuclear apocalypse of the soul), and a draft that would drag him into a war he does not want to fight loom over him if he escapes the cloistered campus.

His friends are a ragtag group, but far more upright and academic than him, and he soon comes to fall in love with the girl with the knee high green socks, Kristen. The school is in a forming uprising, as the administration is making moves to make it harder to sleep with coeds. Gnossus gets dragged into the mess against his will, and what transpires feels like an eerily prophetic vision of what would become of the counterculture. The girl in the knee high green socks has a father advising the President and is secretly in bed (literally) with the dean of the school, who uses the revolt and a death under suspicious circumstances (important to note this was released 3 years after JFK was assassinated) to take power at the school. The mob is involved somehow. The draconian measures are lifted, but nothing of substance changes in relation between student and university. Our free-spirited Gnossus, wracked by an STD passed by Kristen, is forced onto stage as a political figurehead at the climactic rally- all he can do is throw up two middle fingers, which the crowd of course loves. Once he is no longer useful, and power has been seized, he is quite literally disposed of- Kristen marries the dean, and Gnossus is drafted into the military.

While this all sounds like a tragedy, it plays much more like an absurdist comedy, although the scenes turn disturbing towards the end, of Gnossus' friend, a black student without a family at the school on a scholarship, getting gunned down on a trip to Cuba and an off-putting scene where Gnossus injects Kristen with heroin after her betrayal. (It should be noted that there's also two rather offputting sex scenes in this, one of which would definitely fall under assault today as Gnossus pokes holes in a condom, the other of which was hard to read by today's standards.) Gnossus often plays as obnoxious, and it's hard to read if Farina is doing selfowns or not. He definitely plays into the pure of heart searcher that Beats love to put in, but this portrayal is slightly more ambiguous, as evidenced by some scenes of childish behavior and the many scenes of problematic behavior, and the ending, which feels much more like an end to the travails of the beat and a forced transfer into conformity than the typical Kerouac, which usually ends with the hero temporarily defeated but with the search ready to be renewed in another direction.

There is one scene where I think Farina tips his hand slightly, after Gnossus has a vision of an evil spider monkey stalking him, goes to a friend's house, and tries to calm himself by following thats friend's advice, to envision himself as other parts of a life, as a rock, a stream while his friend tries to find a record of the evil spider monkey in a book of spirits. His friend's wife approaches him, tells him that the friend's on a fool errand, as is trying to envision himself as other- that his problems, and the spider monkey, live inside of him, and that he can only address them himself. For a character full of big grandiose statements and displays of Exemption and rebellion, this doesn't quite register, doesn't quite take, but perhaps Farina is pointing towards something Gnossus could relate to in his view of the college itself- that these countercultural displays were often bourgeois dalliances, flights of fancy, and that the path to genuine authenticity and Exemption from the bullshit of the straight world did not come from those displays but introspection, a change in essence harder to coopt.

Farina died two days after this novel was published, and it's a shame it's all we ever got from him, as I think the grounds for a future great novel. For now, I think this stands as one of the more true depictions of the groundswell of counterculture, one that uses some years of removal from its events for artistic license to form a more meaningful narrative. There's issues here, but definitely worth the read for Pynchon heads/Beat fans.

the_ballad.title: The Ballad of Black Tom
the_ballad.author: Victor LaValle
the_ballad.review: Short, satisfying novella that flies by in a few afternoons. Does a really good job of recontextualizing Lovecraft's racism by making him a weird little outsider reporting on things he has no knowledge of, of communities he only judges from the outside, while still keeping the actual spirit and thematic interests of cosmic horror present. The central thesis here, that the cosmic destructive indifference of many of Lovecraft's monsters has an appeal to those who society maliciously destroys, is an interesting one, and gives more flavor to the actual narrative plottings than the typical Lovecraft protagonist.  Have some quibbles with the ending, with LaValle falling into the trap that Piranesi and seemingly much of contemporary sci-fi falling into of explaining the ending rather than letting the reader draws conclusions from the (well-drawn) rest of the work, but there's enough here to satisfy. Overall a satisfying and well-done update to Lovecraftian cosmic horror, even as LaValle updates the prose styling to be more modern and far less antiquated and purple.

stonefish.title: Stonefish
stonefish.author: Scott R. Jones
stonefish.review:
Giving a 5 since this needs more reviews/more eyeballs, but in truth probably measures more as a 4. A lot of intriguing stuff here, but not sure the package comes together into a masterpiece yet, but the author has definitely cemented himself as someone to keep eyes on with this genuinely weird piece of science fiction/cosmic horror.
Stonefish is primarily a work of cosmic nihilism, the novel centering around Den Secord’s experience with tech billionaire Georgios Makarios but really around the gods from another world, the archons who appear on Earth as Sasquatch and are the world’s creator and it’s God, humanity just puppets in its game of shit flinging and experimentation. Our two characters are just pawns in their game, their actions preordained and orchestrated to bring them together in the strange woods home of Stonefish. There, they discover the true nature of the Sasquatch, and that the Earth is a simulation run by them to test different outcomes, this one likely a universe where consumption is at the root of every being’s existence, nothing more than a playground for higher gods to mess around in. The only way out of the archons’ sick game is to drop out, to stop the cycle of consumption, to stop consuming and end one’s life, and that is the choice that confronts Den after the revelations at Stonefish. Pretty heavy stuff, but Jones imbues it with enough absurdity and humor to keep this from feeling like something out of Ligotti or something too dour.
One of Jones’ concerns here is artifice, of falsities, of detachment from the real, whether it be in food or in one’s life. Secord rejects the food provided by the archons that tastes like ingredients long removed from the Earth because it is not real, despite the revelation that his world, in a matter of speaking, is not “real.” But in other cases, he is unable to view his world as real anymore- he is unable to connect with his family of sorts after his return from Stonefish, his experience alienating from the relations that he had. Jones seems to be pointing towards a Lovecraftian type deal here- that the real truth of the universe is such that, if it doesn’t drive you mad, it makes fitting in society impossible, the revelations too shaking. It is not possible to reintegrate, to ground ones self in the real, once that curtain has been pulled. An interesting detour, and another aspect of this, is what the archons consider to be real, what can be latched onto when they bring on what is called the Numpty, an ecological event that blacks out sight and feeling from the world, with the exception of the things that humans have imbued with meaning (in this case, a tree that Makarios has trimmed in honor of his son, who may or may not have been real?). There seems to be a kernel of thought there, that our anchors in a world full of artifice and untruth are not our technology or even basic facts about reality, but about our labors of love, our capacity for creation in the world, the concrete things and people we have attached the meaning of our lives to.
Jones does a good job of threading in the world-building here, very similar to some Phillip K Dick type stuff where enough information is given to make the world feel alien but not enough that the reader’s imagination is stifled, and the horror sequences that are present are unsettling in an off-kilter way, rather than a traditional scare method. The climate change ravaged world and the Internet taking over relations between people doesn’t feel hack or forced because it’s not Jones’ focus, just dressing on the side, details to fill out the world. If I have an issue with Stonefish, it’s the slipping into internet parlance (there’s occasional references to memes, and to ones that are old at the present day, let alone in the future time period this takes place in) both in prose and dialogue that feels out of place for some of the subject matter, and perhaps some structural issues, as this does feel like it may wrap up just slightly too quickly for my tastes.
Overall, a quite enjoyable book, and an author (and a publisher) to keep an eye on. Think the best is yet to come for this author.

the_master.title: The Master and Margarita
the_master.author: Mikhail Bulgakov
the_master.review:
Think I'm a little cooler on this than most, as I found parts of the first book of this to be a tad too caught up in Bulgakov's beefs with the Russian authorities to the point of overindulgence. If I was a Russian in the 30s or even the 60s, I might find this more meaningful, but as it was in the present day it started to drag in parts. There are parts in this half that had me enthralled (namely the magic scene at the theater and the entire opening confrontation between Belioz/Homeless and Woland), but enough depictions of Satan corrupting the foolish and susceptible Russian literary elite and all the names and corruptions start to run together for me. That's not to say it's bad or boring, but it didn't leave me blown away, which I expected from a book of this stature.

However, the second half of this is genuinely phenomenal, a Faustian bargain stretched to its absolute limit. The great ball scene here is phenomenal, the footnotes helping greatly in describing the evils that Satan has assembled, and the scenes of Margarita escaping the drudgery of her life on the broom and in the forest feel genuinely revelatory. The chaos, limited to a single beheading and mostly landing people into institutions, spills over, into burning down of apartments and high class society haunts followed by a storm of epic proportions swallowing Moscow whole as our titular Master and Margarita escape with their devilish friends.

Thematically, this is a tad all over the place (in a good way), but of course any tale of Satanic corruptions and Faustian bargains is going to start with good and evil. Especially in light of the experiment of the Soviet Union with humanity's better side and the outcomes that pervade the first half of the novel (disappearances, secret police, crowded living spaces and the conflict that comes with them) this adds a fresh spin, as the new managers of humanity's best impulses ended up foolish, corrupted, and had easily by the Satanic influences. Bulgakov feels like he's building to more of a generic anti-authoritarianism rather than any specific political ideology, that man cannot be trusted with power, that the enforcement of authority is violence (as Jesus says in his opening confrontation with Pilate), that the pursuit of power and the desire to wield it is a cowardice, the worst of all vices. The use of Jesus in a godless country is a provocative choice, and in part he is illustrating the struggle of the Soviet Union to replace that grounding influence, to make something new in a secular society that does not rely on an otherworldly other to keep man’s nature under check. Pilate's near eternal regret is the price of this power, the idea of a man caught between the moral choice and the only choice allowed by his profession, just wanting to talk philosophy in the garden with a man he sentences to death. On the other side, there is the side of good, conspicuously absent from modern day Moscow in any form. Margarita, in her devotion to the Master, is the closest we get, eschewing her own wishes in order to alleviate the suffering of one of the damned at the ball, and otherwise wholly devoted to her love. Her arc is interesting, though, as she is not the poor saintly women that we see in other Russian literature (i.e. Crime and Punishment), but something different, a member of upper class society bound in a loveless marriage breaking free of confines for the artist she loves.

The damned at the ball represent an interesting aspect of the work given its similarity to a ball thrown in the residence of the US Ambassador that Bulgakov himself attended. That, combined with the use of foreign currency to condemn members in the first book, the representation of Satan as a tourist, and the destruction of the store of fine things for tourists, show that Bulgakov believes that the people of the Union have been at least in some part betrayed by the influence of foreign money, by the need to acquiesce to foreign interests, and that in part the elite’s ability to be corrupted is because of this relationship with foreign influences. His anger seems to burn hottest for this, a betrayal of the stated project of a nation for outside riches.

The iconic quote of the book is “Manuscripts don’t burn,” and it is a popular Russian novel of this era, so of course this has plenty to say about state suppression and censor. The Master’s destruction of his own work parallels Bulgakov burning his own first manuscript of this novel, and Bulgakov seems to believe the only thing preventing him from institutionalization was his lack of showing it to the world, as the Master is destroyed by the press despite his work never been published. The close here, of The Master completing his novel and finding peace by setting Pilate free of his own torment, feels extremely emotional affecting, that the completion of the work and its merit was not just for publication and outside praise but for the spiritual closure of The Master himself and the one that inspired him in Pilate. The character of Ivan Homeless, perhaps the most featured character that isn’t in the title or Satan, functions as a counterpoint, as the outcome of a writer writing to the market that is provided him. He is a poet at the beginning, one who writes under the name homeless given the nobility of the proletariat, but his brush with Satan and the Master makes him realize his work was meaningless, pointless, and give up the pursuit of poetry altogether. The author is clearly angling at something purer, both artistically and in the experience of living, one free of societal constraints and influence that bind us down in expression even if it is unattainable in our feeble fragile human existences.

Wish I had read some Pushkin and Gogol before this, though, as this is dense as hell with references that mostly flew over my head. Definitely one I want to revisit further on down the line.

invisible_cities.title: Invisible Cities
invisible_cities.author: Italo Calvino
invisible_cities.review:
A book that makes much more explicit the implicit contract between author and reader, that half the work is done by you reading the book and what you bring to it. A collection of impressions and descriptions meaningless on their own but made meaningful by your own experiences living in cities and amongst your fellow man and traveling to unfamiliar places. Calvino's most iconic line: that when he travels, all he sees is Venice, all the traveler sees in these great cities is pieces of home, also applies to the text and the act of reading it. A book divorced from the time it takes place in and the time it was published, history and future colliding in one place, architecture and deep humanism mushing into one beautiful compact thing.

The kind of thing you want to read at every stage of your life to see how it reads in that moment.

piranesi.title: Piranesi
piranesi.author: Susanna Clarke
piranesi.review: Finished this one a while back but hadn't had the time to write a proper review and know have forgotten too much to go back and do it. Overall enjoyed it, floated to a high 3 because of an ending I didn't enjoy. A tale so heavily reliant on Borges I'd like to see end in some more ambiguity as this one just sort of wraps itself up cleanly. Some interesting parallels between here and Borges' Library of Babel, the labyrinths containing opposites (Babel the sum of all possible knowledge, this one every possible symbol but nothing concrete and real) and the mystery/thriller aspects of the middle are quite intriguing and hard to put down. A good quick read, just wish it leaned more into mystery and mysticism rather than concreteness.

a_congregation.title: A Congregation of Jackals
a_congregation.author: S. Craig Zahler
a_congregation.review:
Doesn't go anywhere you don't expect based on its premise, but the details are all just right. I see parts of the Cormac McCarthy comps, but at least my experience of his work feels far less human than we see here- McCarthy seems far more interested in the evildoers, in the devil himself, but while Zahler includes a character that fits that in the model with Quinlan, he's far less interested in exploring him- he doesn't appear on page until late, and Zahler is far more concerned with our four men reckoning with the evil they took part in, not the evil itself. (There's also the fact that Zahler is simple not the prose stylist that McCarthy is, and he doesn't try to be- all of this is rather simple, to the point, which benefits the story he's telling, whereas McCarthy is building on a far more epic scale.)

That's not to say there's no evil here, and the brutality depicted is sufficiently extreme for fans who come to his novels after watching Zahler's exceptionally violent Bone Tomahawk and Brawl in Cell Block 99. Between the flashbacks to Quinlan's actions with our four protagonists and their actions at the wedding, the bloody impulse in me was well satisfied, and it builds a feeling of doom and fear that whatever Quinlan has in store will be extreme for everyone.

The thematic thrust is Zahler's desire to interrogate our main four's past, to determine whether one can ever be absolved for atrocities, if their ability to become a good member of their community, a father, a brother, a church-goer can allow them to escape their past. Can't imagine it's spoilers to say so, but the answer presented is clearly a no- Quinlan and his gang present/represent the past as a grotesque force, never to be escaped, waiting around every corner, for a moment that is meaningful enough to you that it's worth it for them to snatch it away and to wreak chaos on everything you love. The only way out is through noble sacrifice, to stamp out the force you allowed to flourish in your past and then gracefully walk your way to the noose to have your neck stamped. Zahler lays on some of the Jesus imagery a little thick at times, but his reframing it as men going to the metaphorical cross for their own sins in service of their wives and daughters as well as women for the sins of their husbands at least puts an interesting spin on it.

Was most shocked by the human spin Zahler puts on this- don't think he's including any beats that are terribly deep, but from reputation he seemed much more misanthropic. There's a lot of moments in here, before and after the shit hits the fan, that are genuinely emotionally affecting, even if they are simplistic, and I would have figured Zahler wouldn't be interested in such moments, but those are the beats that give the whole the punch it has.

babel-17.title: Babel-17
babel-17.author: Samuel R. Delany
babel-17.review:
Read as sort of a test run to see whether the mountain of Dhalgren was worth climbing, and I think Delaney passes the test. Not sure when I'll get to it, but it's on the list for real now. This was either a high 3 or a low 4 and I was feeling generous today.

The genre trappings of this weaken it, at least in my opinion, as a lot of the sci fi dressing of it doesn't add up to a whole helluva lot in theme or really even in plotting that couldn't be achieved through a more grounded environment. Some of it feels worthwhile, or is at least fun, but other aspects just feel like padding to get this to fit into certain genre conventions.

The ideas here are good ones though, as Delaney uses the sci-fi setting to poke at his ideas of linguistics, and namely the Sapir-Whorf hypothesis (which is perhaps more popular now due to Ted Chaing and the movie Arrival; Delaney, for what it's worth, believed it at the time of publication but grew to discard for more complex theories as he aged.) You can feel him feeling out for all its worth, both in the character moments and in the world- one particular treaty agreement mentioned includes a nice Delaney explainer on how to explain 'home' to a culture and a language that has no conception of it due to their reproductive functionings. The character of Rydra Wong is his primary vessel for exploration, her switching in and out of the foreign language Babel-17 to allow her to break down complex systems because of its linguistic efficiency, but the alien nature of the language also taking root in her brain, altering her own actions without her conscious awareness of it. He also hints at the ability to speak and understand multiple languages on a deeper level as a form of telepathy, one that gives greater understanding of human thought and feeling on even a subconscious level. The character of Butcher is Delaney's other vessel for exploring it, a man with the conception of the self stripped out of him (no concept of 'I' or 'you'), leading to some grappling with the source of empathy, the source of our ability to understand the implication of our actions. It's all pretty heady stuff to put into a short book, but it for the most part comes off, with the help of Delaney's willingness to explain things directly in detail and his otherwise efficient but effective prose.

the_three.title: The Three Stigmata of Palmer Eldritch
the_three.author: Philip K. Dick
the_three.review:
Starts as kinda bland futuristic corporate drama with some present day parallels and then melds itself into something for more interesting, a meditation on God, drugs, and corporate power. Wouldn’t be lying if I said the first portion bored me a little bit, but once this thing gets heated up it’s excellent.

The prose here is a little lackluster, as it is Ubik, although like the rest of things it picks up as things progress. In the second half Dick is almost entirely in gonzo weird ideas mode, with potentially diverging timelines, dreams inside of dreams, and other fuckery to make the reader wonder if anything they just read made any sense. The commitment to the ideas is what makes the prose shine, as you can feel Dick’s interest and sophistication increase as he gets into what really is the meat of the novel.

There’s a few different metaphors at work here, mainly in the drugs presented: Can-D and Chew-Z. There’s somewhat of an initial argument about community vs. individualism, as Can-D requires its users to share the hallucination space, to act as one unit in one hallucinated body on Earth, while Chew-Z is a solitary drug, one that allows the user to spend infinite time in a dreamscape catered to their own interests and needs in the blink of an eye. This is all undercut by the fact that the Chew-Z is not really run by the user, but by Palmer Eldritch, the corporate master selling Chew-Z (or at least an alien occupying Palmer Eldritch). The users of Chew-Z filter their imaginations, their dreams through the drug, a powerful metaphor that can stand in for a variety of factors- mass media, social media, ideology, corporate control over art, but in any case serves as a powerful warning to not let these forces control our imaginations, to not let them serve as a filter for our dreams or to use them as an escape from our own earthly problems. Eldritch begins to infect the vision of takers of the drug, appearing as their friends, their family, another indictment of anything with mass control over people that prevents them from seeing the world properly. The dissatisfaction the Mars colonists feel with the Can-D is in part due to their conditions- they labor with no control over their situation, with no hope of escape, and no hope of really succeeding in their labor. The drug is their only escape from a life of drudgery and purposelessness, which ultimately undercuts the community experience inhabiting the hallucination space.

With Palmer Eldritch’s power, there comes the question of Gods and eternal life and the meaning of it. Chew-Z presents the opportunity for eternal life, for humans to never die- does this make him God, or at least, a god? The meaning of this eternal life is also at question, given human’s lack of control over it, given the possible malign influence of Eldritch forever lurking in the shadows of the dream. The novel ends with a possible victory, that humanity has murdered the actual Eldritch and lives in peace, but the visions and his ability to conjure this reality leaves the reader questioning whether this isn’t another hallucination.

Mayorson’s character is the one I found mostly compelling, a man broken by his own cowardice, his own decisions, fighting with whether to return to the hallucinations presented of a possible alternate past or future or return to the reality that he left in shambles for himself. His return to the hallucinations representing the opportunity for Eldritch to serve an attack and continue his mind colonization of the human race is a powerful example of the dangers of escape into these all-consuming filters, be it television or the Internet. The women here are really only partially formed sketches, and the tech CEO isn’t much of a character to me, but as is typical for Dick, the ideas are at the center.

My favorite of the more narrative bending Dicks between this and Ubik, really enjoyed this quite a bit once it got moving.

songs_of.title: Songs of a Dead Dreamer and Grimscribe
songs_of.author: Thomas Ligotti
songs_of.review:
Definitely something I wish I had chewed on slower and broken up rather than something I tried to read like a novel in one go. Loved many parts of this but it is a lot when stacked all together, not just in length but in terms of the level of effort that Ligotti demands from you in each story.

But when it works it's all worth the demand, as Ligotti even here in a formative state has a gift for creeping dread and a horror that surpasses our understanding (some of it leans into Lovecraftian territory, sans the racism). The spaces Ligotti writes are in decay, often with a Rust Belt sensibility of the horrors of deindustrialization and aging made literal. His prose is often the highlight rather than any particular plot movement, creating a sense of dread suggested by the circumstances rather than a literary jump scare of a monster waiting at the end of the tunnel, and it leads to stories that creep under you skin rather than any visceral response. I've heard it only gets better from here, so excited to continue into the Ligottiverse.

Ligotti seems to be primarily interested in two horrors, the first of which is loss of control, that our consciousness' control over our bodies is a fragile thing. To illustrate this Ligotti uses dolls and mannequins frequently, creepy facsimiles that characters are turned into, their minds trapped in a prison with no externalization. In parts this becomes a metaphor for the power the rich exert over the poor, as in 'The Chymist'; in others, it becomes something more personal, of being manipulated at work, as in 'Dream of a Manikin.' The other seems to be the idea that our present world is a veil, a collective illusion/delusion, with something much more evil and menacing lying beneath it. Ligotti's anti-human stance is clear here, the idea that any sort of pleasantness is something that society conspires to create, and that lying just beneath are horrors we can't imagine, that only a few have the eyes to see but all live under, shows the sort of contempt he has for humanity at large, for the structures we have built that hide the grotesque realities of our day to day existence.

Overall, an exciting opening collection, and excited to see where he goes from here, as I've heard it's only up hill from here.

to_the.title: To the Lighthouse
to_the.author: Virginia Woolf
to_the.review:
Probably the most accessible of the Woolf I've read so far (The Waves and Mrs. Dalloway being the others), but probably my least favorite of the bunch as well. That's not to say that I didn't very much like this book, but it didn't inspire the love I have for the other two. Likely a 5 for any other author, but there’s some degree of grading on a curve here. Will probably become the Woolf I recommend to people.

That being said, this still blows the doors off 99% of other writing, contemporary or classic. Woolf on a sentence level is in a different class from basically every other writer, even as she's in a much more restrained mode here. The narrative, scant though it is, is traceable, partially because much of the book takes place over two days, rather than the epic scale of The Waves. Dialogue, chapters, characters responding to each other directly in time are all here, which make it much easier to latch onto than the pure stream of consciousness of The Waves. There’s still plenty of long sentences and internal thoughts here, and Woolf proves herself to be one of the best at one of writing’s preeminent no-nos, the switching of perspectives inside a chapter. The dinner scene particularly is exceptional, capturing unspoken gestures and restrained thoughts from seemingly every perspective at a long dinner table, but nowhere leaves the reader confused on who they are seeing inside of.

What I love about Woolf is she’s capable of blowing up the personal and the interpersonal to the same epic scale as novelists that tackle societal forces or changes or politics. Here is no different, as she tackles on a host of different subjects in various forms and ways. To The Lighthouse seems most focused on the various forces that divide people from each other.

Perhaps most prominent among those is the concept of gender roles and how they make relationships between any set of individuals difficult. The men in this novel are by and large extremely narcissistic and self-important; the father Mr. Ramsey excessively worried about his own legacy, whether he will be remembered, and committed to the idea of the truth rather than any form of emotional harmony. Charles Tansley is incapable of having a conversation about anything other than himself; others are reclusive, not desiring social ties in favor of wanting to lock themselves up and work. The women are constrained and put down; Mrs. Ramsey by the insecurities of her husband, Lily Briscoe by the scores of people telling her that she can’t create, that she must marry. Mrs. Ramsey is a busybody, incapable of letting a moment sit, worry pressing at her at all times, a body needing motion. She also is a much more old-fashioned view of femininity, the mother to countless children, the patient wife, while Lily is a new model, eschewing a husband in pursuit of a husband. All these personality quirks, largely attributable to society’s expectations on these people rather than purely intrinsic instincts, serve to separate them, to annoy each other and prevent from genuine and honest emotional approach to each other. Towards the end, Woolf uses the metaphor of a wagon wheel running over a foot to illustrate this- is it the wheel’s fault for running over the foot? Or was the wheel put on a track it could not deviate from?

Also apparent here is the metaphor of the lighthouse. In the first section it stays a mythical destination, a landmark to be reached for, just out of reach for the young children. In the closing section, they finally reach the destination, and it becomes much more mundane, an artifact rusting and decaying like any else. This applies well to the characters in their dualities as well, Mr. Ramsey the tyrant of the family and the weak, fragile man just trying to connect, Mrs. Ramsey the loving mother and beauty who can’t tell her husband she loves him. All of these characters embody contradictions between these two perceptions, and there are often contradictions in how others perceive them as well. Frequently, characters flip from thoughts of hating someone fervently to thoughts of tenderness and affection in the span of a paragraph or two. These contradictory feelings can be what separate people from each other, but they are also what enable us to connect with those that momentarily irritate us or have done us harm, and Woolf takes those into account in building every stray thought of the characters throughout.

The middle section does feature some textbook Woolf experimentation, as she spans a decade of time with only descriptions of a house in decay and parentheticals of tragedies befalling the Ramsey family. This section is notable for how blunt and crashing the tragedies come down, especially from her- for her to kill off major characters in a parenthetical short sentence feels more stark because of the lengths she just spent on a single day. The house is revitalized; the family returns, and their relationships in some ways seem to heal with the house.

The final section, the day of that return, with the trip to the lighthouse coming, and a family in resentment to each other, is marvelously done. The children soften to their father, and their father at least partially opens himself to them; Lily Briscoe goes back to her painting interrupted a decade prior. Woolf uses the painting as a vessel for delving into the inadequacy of art, and really of our feelings/emotions for processing the human experience. Only 10 years on can she come to grips with her relationship to and the death of Mrs. Ramsey, time being necessary to accomplish so. The painting, when finished, is not perfect, does not capture everything she wants it to capture or everything feels. But it is Lily’s best attempt, and that seems to be the closing mission statement (particularly since this is at least partially autobiographical): art as a means to expressing, accessing, and understanding one’s emotions, our flailing attempts at meaning and purpose and comprehension of the lives we lead and the relationships we share with others, no matter how incomplete it may be, no matter how it may be perceived by others (a clear rebuttal to Mr. Ramsey’s gnawing thoughts about the life of his work after death). It is our attempt to capture each other, on both sides of the lighthouse, both in the myths and best qualities we see in each other and in the ugly mundane inadequacies resentments desperately trying to be hidden but nakedely plain to the eye.

the_name.title: The Name of the Rose
the_name.author: Umberto Eco
the_name.review:
Waffled between the 4 and the 5 but the ending got me to the 5. Read the first probably 100 or so pages of this deep on pain medication, so thoughts may not be as deep as usual. Or at least blame it on that if you think it sucks. Still not sure how this 500+ page deeply Catholic novel is one of the best selling novels of all-time but what do I know.

A book unapologetically up his own ass, The Name of the Rose spends it first 100 pages alienating the reader, intentionally. There’s fun to be had, but it is absolutely a writer on his bullshit- Eco spends what feels like 25 pages (read on Kindle, so not sure the exact quantity) describing the young monk Adso’s reaction to a towering piece of art in the monastery and another lengthy portion on how the mentor William guessed the name of an escaped horse. Not the most engaging or enthralling stuff, but it helps you get on the book’s wavelength: this is a murder mystery, but not one that is trying to string you along with easy to find clues or plot details, one that is very concerned with the world it takes place in and the debates of the time

The book is also at an important crossroads of the Catholic Church, where the debate over the poverty of Christ is actively being debated, heresy is running rampant, and the state is beginning to rebel against the Church’s authority over secular life. The witch hunt is beginning its use as a source of social control, and the church for the first time in a long time is having to fight for its preeminent place in European society. These debates are not just woven into the plot action or the dialogue between characters, but behind themes.
 At its core this novel asks questions about knowledge and power: who does it belong to, and more importantly to whom should it belong? The anti-poverty segment of the church, the monastery that is playing host, clearly sits on one side: that wealth belongs to the church, that these trinkets glorify God, and that knowledge should be carefully managed and restricted to only those with the training and prestige for it. The Franciscan segment believes wealth belongs to the world, and that the church should be poor, serving the poor, and staying out of secular matters. Their views on sharing of old books is more opaque, but as far less hierarchical organization, it’s easy enough to imagine their views. The question of the Church’s role clearly plays a role in the next, oh, 500 years or so European history, so the debates here are historically relevant and a view into the forces that decided much of the world as we know it.

In the end, the resolution gives us Eco’s take- that the concentration of power and knowledge in the hallowed halls rather than amongst the people necessitates violence to preserve its status, as seen through Burgos’ murders to keep Aristotle’s legendary book on laughter out of the hands of the monks. The “protection” of knowledge ultimately quite literally burns the library, and the monastery itself, down, a perhaps not so subtle allusion to the Church burning much of its influence in its cloistered nature and grabs for power. Burgos’ final villainous monologue also proves that these debates aren’t meaningless theology, or debate for debate’s sake: these debates prove the basis for the Church’s power, and their loss would lead to the diminishment of the Church’s influence. This book, according to Burgos, would give intellectual heft and weight to laughter, the lowest of human emotions (according to him), and in doing so give power to the lower classes, to the common man and woman, as well as undermining the tool of the Church for social control, fear. If that occurs, what is the use of intellectual monks and the institution of the Church, who gain power through their interpretation skills, if knowledge and wisdom belong to the common man? From the exaltation of laughter there is a straight line to power residing in the people’s hands.

Eco’s approach to the mystery is quite postmodern; even as our detective manages to logic himself into a solution, he often does so by moments of inspiration rather than a sustained line of thought, and the steps that led him to the solution are shown to be flawed in the last moment of revelation. The belief in a grand narrative of the killings, that they matched a biblical prophecy, led him astray even as his deductions based on that led him in the right direction. As a matter of fact, his belief in this grand narrative is weaponized by the murderer himself, who continues to follow the pattern to obfuscate his identity and intentions. That this is true and instructive in the age of misinformation and conspiracy theories that provide simplistic solutions to the grander problems of the world (be it Q Anon or Russian election interference conspiracies) hardly seems to need to be said. These narratives distract us from the uglier, mundane truth of power grabs and naked disgusting human ambition and evil that often contradicts and opposes itself. That this death to the grand narrative implicates the nonexistence of God is not ignored by the text, either- our noble hero William seems to concede that he cannot reconcile God with the chaos of the world, but he must carry on in the Church so that he can safely express himself. But Eco’s disbelief in the grand narrative does not mean it is useless- as a matter of fact, he finds that they can be used for temporary purposes but ultimately necessary to be discarded. William puts it as such:   “You must throw the ladder away, because you discover that, even if it was useful, it was meaningless.”

Beyond the philosophical implications and the history, there is plenty of other literary pleasures to be found here, including Eco’s labyrinth he plants in the library (the not so subtle nod to Borges in Burgos telegraphs the influence), Adso’s one night stand with a village girl and subsequent ecstasy and regret, and plenty of Eco humorously poking at the hypocrisy of the Catholic Church. Once the first 100 pages are conquered, this actually becomes quite an accessible mystery, with plenty of character, mystery, and philosophical digression to keep the reader hooked.

For the record, Jesus laughed.

caliban_and.title: Caliban and the Witch: Women, the Body and Primitive Accumulation
caliban_and.author: Silvia Federici
caliban_and.review:
The world we live is not natural; it was made. It is a simple truth, but one difficult to internalize and allow to seep into your thought processes. But this thought is at the core of being able to conceive of a world better than the one we live in.

What this book does, then, is take you back to the start, to the pre-capitalist world to find the origins of our present condition, so we can see that things are not rooted in natural forces but were constructed for a specific reason. Federici is mainly concerned with the way misogyny, and especially the witch hunt, was weaponized as a way for mostly male workers to accept the loss of the commons to the ruling class, which was the primary incident in the creation of capitalism.

The argument is this: the process of primitive accumulation (i.e, the consolidation of land and capital into the ruling class’ hands) required the seizure of the land previously held in common by the workers that they used as their livelihood. What came for them in replacement was the advent of waged labor. Workers were, of course, infuriated by their land being taken from them, so the ruling class managed a compromise: the public ownership of land was replaced by the public ownership of women’s bodies, and by making the only labor they could perform reproducing. With this comes a whole host of repressive changes: women being forced out of the workplace (ensuring dependance on men, leading to abuse and degradation), the destruction of contraceptive methods and other healing methods passed down through generations, and, of course, the witch hunt. The witch hunt was an attack on woman’s autonomy, on their bodies; the state dropped all pretense of “causing harm” on the part of the accused witches and attacked anyone outside the bounds of the newly imposed order, primarily as a means of founding the new social order. Women did not take this lying down, but their rebellions lacked the support necessary to overcome, and the threat of excruciating torture, rape, and execution made any resistance risky to muster and doomed to ultimately fail.

The book also looks for the justifications and the reasoning behind the changes. Mercantilism held that the strength of a country was based almost exclusively in the amount of labor power it had, so reproduction must be incentivized at all costs. This leads to many of the changes mentioned above, such as the removal of woman from the workforce and their lack of autonomy, the destruction of contraception, as well as other changes, such as the stigmatization and punishment of homosexuality. At the same time, conceptions of the body that interacted with the emerging capitalist thought saw the body as mechanical, just a tool that needed to be adjusted right to be a labor machine. To get the workforce in a position to be this perfectly honed tool, all elements of spirituality, of frivolity, needed to be stripped, which includes the spiritual practices often associated with witches but also sex for the purpose of pleasure and ultimately friendships and communal relations.

Federici uses the present to show how the process of primitive accumulation has not stopped. In India and in Africa, the witch hunt persists even as the Anglo world has moved on, a sign those societies are being exploited by the West with little recourse other than violence against their own people. The countries themselves may no longer be explicitly colonized and occupied, but the scar tissue of years of control lives on in their culture.

While it details the changes that were made, it also details the conditions beforehand, which were almost always across the board better for women. They could take part in the commons and be self sufficient, they were allowed in various guilds and to be part of the workforce, their friendships with other women were not treated as suspicious, and they had far more bodily autonomy with regards to reproduction. Their lives were not perfect, and misogyny was still present, but the transition from feudalism to capitalist production hit them the hardest and they paid the largest price for it. Their treatment, from the witch hunt to now, is not something natural to the human condition, but something constructed, just as other prejudices are, to divide the working class from itself, to prevent them from realizing the true enemy.

The present condition is not some fundamental part of our nature, not intrinsic to who we are as creatures. Society can be molded, can be shaped in the image of those who choose to do so. What this book does is lift the hood over this image and reveal the work and the act of creation behind it. A must-read if you’re interested in politics or feminism in my opinion.

(Federici has made an apparent TERF turn in recent years, so perhaps better to check this book out at the library rather than give her your money, but this still is worth reading IMO)

ready_player.title: Ready Player Two (Ready Player One, #2)
ready_player.author: Ernest Cline
ready_player.review:
Don't have too much to say about this one that I didn't say about its predecessor, but rest assured, this is somehow even worse than Ready Player One.

I may have had my problems with RP1, but at least there was a vision in it, a driving purpose to it, something that felt like its creator was remotely passionate about. It may have been an artless vision, but there was passion and drive behind it, something that even as I despised much of the content I couldn't help but at least get partially swept up in. This feels more like a cash grab, like Cline's heart is no longer in it, the plot roughly a copy and paste of the first one with some slight variations so it doesn't feel exactly the same. I thought I read somewhere that Cline wrote this in order to make the sequel to the movie happen, and it feels like it.

Some of the criticisms of RP1 as white dude fantasy clearly have rubbed off on our author, as there are plenty of plays at the language of social justice, including critiques of John Hughes movies as lily-white, the addition of a trans woman as a character, and a takedown of the founder character of Halliday as a manipulative misogynist. Unfortunately, these for the most part feel tacked on and forced in, something Cline thought he should put in rather than something he felt wholeheartedly committed to. There's also plenty of signs that for all the effort he's put in to make this feel more inclusive, he hasn't really internalized any of it. Wade secretly stalks his ex-girlfriend in the OASIS after she's broken up with him and is never really made to pay for it or even feel bad about it; instead, he says that watching an orgy porno is much grosser than that, and as a matter of fact stalking her is far better than doing that. I don't need to point out the issue here, do I?

SPOILERS
The end of this is a revelation that we've invented a way to bring back the dead, that we can take their consciousness and upload it to the OASIS and live on forever. It's clear that this is a distinct consciousness from its originator, that is indeed a copy rather than a direct port of someone's consciousness (i.e., not like San Junipero from Black Mirror; there's a copy of Wade living at the same time as actual Wade). Not to get theological here, but there's no question of a soul, of the life itself carrying on- we are all reducible to just the combination of traits we have, to our favorite TV shows and movies, to the way we happen to express ourselves. It's no wonder someone that has such a disdain for humanity as Cline would see it this way, but it's a depressing vision, one lacking an appreciation for people, for the unique life that lies beneath, for what we are beyond just our conscious brains, beyond what can be quantified and programmed. Our author predictably has no thoughts of any of this, as no question of that lives inside of the novel itself.

I'll close this on a quote from the villain of the book, who criticizes the two books far more succinctly than I could:

'Don't you kids ever get tired of picking through the wreckage of a past generation's nostalgia? I mean, look around. The entire OASIS is like one giant graveyard, haunted by the undead pop-culture icons of a bygone era. A crazy old man's shrine to a bunch of pointless crap.'

the_king.title: The King in Yellow
the_king.author: Robert W. Chambers
the_king.review:
Read in part because True Detective Season 1 is the only good television ever made and in part to dive deeper into the history of weird fiction. Didn't know exactly what I was getting into and was relatively stunned to find this was only half weird/horror and the rest a much more traditional literary collection, but found things to love in either end.

HP Lovecraft did not invent the 'I'm totally sane, you can trust me' protagonist, apparently, as the opening story features a guy who was kicked in the horse and sent to the asylum but it was all an error, really, and the rest of the first four stories feature varying degrees of protagonists detailing their own descent into madness. If it were me I would simply not read The King In Yellow and go crazy. Lovecraft is pilfering plenty else here for his own use, which makes for interesting parallels. For writing when he did, ~30 years before Lovecraft, Chambers prose feels more modern, more accessible, but still retains a tinge of the old-timey verbiage and style that helps add to the atmosphere of Lovecraft's best works.

The King in Yellow, an in universe text as well as the title of this collection, hangs over these first four stories, and really the rest of it that does not directly invoke it, a book that drives the reader insane upon reading it, one that brings other worlds, other dimensions into our own realm. The idea of a work driving people mad is not unfamiliar- Infinite Jest features a similar conceit, and anyone who has parents knows the horrors of hearing them talk about 'what they've been reading on Facebook.' This idea can be applied to any variety of texts that bring about real-world terror, whether it be FoxNews or QAnon conspiracy posts or 4Chan edgelord. What Chambers does here, through the first person narration, is capture the appeal to the enraptured while putting you in the outside perspective, the watcher of a friend, a family member driven to these awful lengths. The appeal he captures is many fold through these stories- the promise of power, the appeal of transgression, the feeling of being part of something larger, the fear of a cruel world and mysterious strangers, the desire to reconnect with the lost and dead. The book itself is mysterious, appearing on bookshelves unannounced, unplaced by its owners, attacking those at their weakest and most vulnerable, just like those conspiracies do today. It all makes for a simple, well-crafted metaphor, even if it's not the only thing at play with the horror here, as much of the delight here comes from the supernatural imagery of Carcosa and the masks and the Yellow King and the uncertainty that Chambers leaves in the text with these crazed narrators.

Chambers is writing from the perspective of the 1890s syphillis outbreak in Paris, so it's easy to see what inspired the shorts, but in this construction he transcends them, makes them timeless. There are other tales here too, tales of the dead reaching to the living, transcending time continuums, as well as tales of coming of age in Paris, tales much more of innocence than anything else. Chambers is an American who lived in Paris between his age 21 and 28, and it's easy to see this as a tribute to his time there- the tales of innocence a memorial of his first years in Paris, innocent and falling in love with French girls, the weird tales at the front the tales of the fallout of the free sex of that time. The former is the weak point of the collection and obviously less interesting, but still worthwhile nonetheless. One of my favorite shorts that doesn't fit neatly with the rest is 'The Street of the First Shell'- Chambers atmospheric horror taken to the battlefield creates a waking nightmare that captures the disorientation and chaos of the battlefield in ways that don't come naturally to actual war writers.

my_year.title: My Year of Rest and Relaxation
my_year.author: Ottessa Moshfegh
my_year.review:
Another nearly plotless book in the bag, and also another unnamed woman at its center. Really making me stretch my use of the word 'the narrator,' contemporary literature. Reading this after Ducks, Newburyport was like a breath of fresh air simply for having dialogue and sentences- can only imagine what a pulp novel would do for me at the moment.

Engaging with depression in a novel is difficult because depression, at least as I experience it, is largely boredom. Boredom is self-evidently boring and thus not good fodder for a novel- even though I loved The Pale King, the only novel I'm aware of that even attempts to tackle boredom, I would hesitate to call it entertaining. Moshfegh shortcuts around the boringness of depression by turning this into a farce, the characters overly exaggerated versions of real types of people, their antics giving the entertainment value to get you to sit through 300 pages of depression and anhedonia. Criticisms of these characters as unrealistic strike me as missing the point entirely- you might not like them, and you might find this book off-putting, but if your issue is with the lack of realism than your issue is with the premise and not the execution.

As for its depiction of depression, I found little to fault. I think it captures the headspace of the depressed individual accurately in exaggerated form- the contempt for people trying to be helpful, seeing any attempts at happiness or self-improvement or anything other than wallowing as corny, the desire for closeness with other people while shoving them away when they draw near, the lack of feeling and caring that accompanies you at every stage of your life. The central metaphor of sorts here, what is being literalized in painstaking detail, is that emerging from a deep depression is like waking up from a slumber even if it isn't a literal one, a sequence of days that all feel the same, just ticks on a calendar, and craving the release of unconsciousness whenever you can get one. The person that wakes up (if they can) in many ways does not resemble the one slumbering, their way of seeing and engaging with the world replaced with something new, looking through the world with fresh eyes. The prose, sedate and hemmed-in for much of the runtime, sparkles when she emerges, the feeling of taking in the world with new eyes literalized, the intake of sensory detail suddenly captivating, our friends people we see with sympathy and care even if we recognize their inadequacies.

There's clearly a duality dynamic between the narrator and Reva. The narrator represents what I would consider to be more of the stereotypical zoomer approach to depression/mental illness, obsessed with dissociating and prescription pills and just escaping one's own head to circumvent mental illness. Reva is the flipside of the coin, what I would consider the more millennial mindset caricature, trying to bootstrap your depression, that the key to the happiness is this life hack and getting into shape and embracing 'adulting' and this self-help book called something like 'Dig The Shit Out of Your Ass: How to Fix Your Brain And Win.' Neither is happy and neither is to be admired, and the book is clearly poking fun at them, but I think it does a good job at keeping them relatively sympathetic (or at least Reva sympathetic) even as it laughs at their foibles. Moshfegh is intent on making you understand that their issues are their own but they are coming out of larger forces, whether it be parental relationships and loss or the body expectations placed on women (especially in the year 2000). It is important in the end that our narrator wakes up and chooses to engage with the world, that the haze of pills and detachment from society is a temporary measure. The world does not change around her metamorphosis, but her view of it does- she tells her friend 'I love you' first (her friend doing to her a recurring line earlier) even though none of Reva's underlying issues and annoying habits have changed, she sees people out in public in a different light, etc.

If there's a third side to the coin, it's Dr. Tuttle, the pill-slinging psychologist. She's almost entirely a source of comedy, a reflection of mental health treatment that prescribes medication at every opportunity and cares little for the patient, never pushing back on their desires and not remembering anything about them other than what they pick up from the pharmacist when they leave the office.

People have expanded the scope of this novel to be a critique of millennials or millennial culture, which I don't think is unfounded. But while the critique is rather pointed, I don't think it lacks empathy or sympathy for the characters involved- it just wants them to choose better mindsets and habits, one that avoid the pitfalls of the diseased and decaying society that raised them and formed them into what they are.

Still trying to sort out the ending in my head. Ending on a 9/11 is an edgy provocation and a payoff on some blatant foreshadowing, but what does it actually mean? Is it adding shock value to try to grab attention? This story plays with art and shock value plenty- the artist Ping Xi grabs attention by doing things like freezing dogs and painting with his ejaculate, and while the narrator thinks negatively about it, he is the outside force that enables our narrator to complete her experiment. If it's just provocation, then I guess I can live with that and find it interesting from an author's standpoint, but it doesn't fit the book. Is it a sign that behind the new lease our narrator has on life, she's still the selfish person underneath, nothing really changing underneath? She is using a tragedy as a contextualization for her own personal journey, and the author clearly has a bit of distance/dislike for the narrator and it wouldn't be out of tone to undercut the entire chapter before of her new lease on life. Or it could be undermining the utility of her feelings, that even if she feels better, it doesn't mean the way she treats other people and the way she affects them doesn't change. Is it just a reflection on the coping mechanisms that develop out of recovery from depression, that the moments and thoughts we ascribe meaning to, the ones that are enable us to survive and engage with the world may be fucked up and selfish but ultimately necessary? That ones rings as the most charitable interpretation, but the 9/11 aspect is so quickly tossed in (it's a page-long chapter that covers the event itself and her emotional response to it) that if that's the case, it certainly doesn't feel properly developed. Whatever the case, I think it's more interesting that I think it is good. Seen a lot of people lavish praise on this aspect and I am really curious what they think it means beyond the spectacle of it because I'd be shocked if it didn't at least give people pause.

There's plenty else here- a lot on grief, grieving people that you know you shouldn't, and a lot about the act of creation and the meaning of art. There's also plenty of easy criticisms to place on this, namely that at the end of the day who really cares if a trust fund baby is miserable when she never has to work a day for the life. But I think there's more to the class character here than what it lets on- for one, it makes a year of rest and relaxation possible; for two, I think it helps the isolating of the issues to the mental illness and grief, that her problems are entirely the ones of her own brain rather than ones of economic anxiety or stress.

In summation, I walked away with this pretty impressed. The 4/5 division is a toss-up, but the ending and a little drag in the middle kept this one on the lower end of the two ratings.

ducks,_newburyport.title: Ducks, Newburyport
ducks,_newburyport.author: Lucy Ellmann
ducks,_newburyport.review:
The first of Mike's Big Books 2021. If they all take this long it might be one of only two or three. You never realize how much space paragraph breaks and dialogue take up in a book until you read a book completely lacking them. Also contains very prominent Ohio representation, which we must love and respect in all forms.

An exercise in style first and foremost, this novel with the exception of interludes takes the form of one long sentence, broken up only by 'the fact thats,' consisting mostly of the internal monologue and word associations of an unnamed Ohio housewife. It never plunges into full nonsensical digression like Joyce would, committed to the perspective it inhabits, but there are page long lists of every river they can think of, long digressions on Little House in the Prairie, and enough word association games to make you feel like it might be nonsense anyway. That being said, I found the prose to really work for me, not necessarily because of brilliant individual clauses but because of the way they all flowed together. I am almost always entirely rhythm deaf when it comes to reading (or at least not actively conscious of rhythm), only really noticing it if something's particularly clunky (looking at you, Ernest Cline), but man are there passages of this that flow together beautifully and cohere into much more than sum of the parts because of the way they roll off the tongue (or the brain, in this case). If you can get past the original shock of the way this is written, Ducks, Newburyport is actually pretty easy to slide into and enjoy and will almost certainly enter your own head and monologue at some point.

The interludes themselves are pretty unremarkable, following a mountain lion, but they primarily work as a contrast to the flowing prose of the narrator, a series of quick, terse, to the point page long interruptions. The contrast is simple- the mountain lion is worried about two things, getting her next meal and taking care of her cubs, while our housewife is worried about any number of things at any given time- school shooters, Open Carry guys, whether she is permanently broken by her mother's death, the relationship dynamics of classic movies she watches while she bakes, her own shyness, Trump's relationship with Melania whether she's a good mother, whether she neglected her eldest daughter while she was dating her now husband, the extinction of various species of animals, whether her kid's will inherit her shyness, et cetera et cetera. The point is rather obvious, that the age of information is too overwhelming for any human to process healthily, it all spurting out of us in the form of various neuroses and pet concerns and favorite books and movies through which we see our own lives through the lens of.

The narration doesn't feel real but it does feel true, hyperreal, an exaggerated reflection of our own familiar thought processes, our own inability to handle the waves of information that cascade toward us everyday, the inability to identify any real sort of signal from the noise of modern reality taken to an absurd conclusion. That being said, this is not disrespectful to its narrator (or at least I do not perceive it to be). If anything, it is a celebration of her perspective, one that would usually be perceived as 'boring', especially in the literary world: a housewife, mother of 4, who stays at home all day baking. There are points where this goes from abstract digression about something or another (i.e., what you would stereotypically expect a housewife to do all day) to something emotional from her past that are breathtaking in the way they transition and the amount of emotion they leave the reader with because of the way it breaks up an otherwise mundane part of her existence. This book clearly holds that this perspective, that the internal monologue and the lives of the 'boring,' is as worthy of respect, as interesting a collection of idiosyncrasies and personal tragedies, grand successes and tragic failures, as any other perspective.

At least a part of this is an elevation of domestic labor, on the difficulties of it as well as the dignity of it. Our housewife spends most of her time either baking, cleaning up after her children, or taking care of her children, and it makes you feel and understand the amount of time and effort that goes into managing a household without real help from her husband (her husband is mostly away on work travel throughout this). I spent a number of pages of this wanting to apologize to my mother for not helping around the house more when I was a kid.

All that being said, interpreting this and saying any of it definitively can feel like a bit of a fruitless exercise. This many pages with this much packed in and not much didacticism to be found makes this at least somewhat of a rorschach test for the reader, which can be obnoxious if done poorly but this works well and there's enough there to leave plenty to chew on and wrestle with it.

I did really enjoy it but the 1000 pages is quite intimidating. I was into it for most of its length but there weren't points where I was a little fed up. If I'm being honest, you can probably read the first 150 pages and the last 150 pages and get 85% of the same experience, which makes that probably my recommendation for people not already 100% sold by the description of the novel.

SPOILERS
Still split on the ending of this one. Feels simultaneously like the only way this book could end and also like the author flinching away from their own premise. The latter because this book spends 950 pages dedicated almost entirely to the narrator's interior life, her perspective, the way she sees her day to day life, to the point of basically being a book without a plot, that to end on what is basically an action set piece feels like almost a copout. The former because while nothing really happens, there are a number of small disasters happening throughout the book, and this is a book that primarily finds itself in the narrator's worries it only makes sense that her biggest ones become manifest at the end. The more I think about it the more I lean toward a positive view of the ending. The horrors and atrocities we've inflicted on the natural world are coming quickly for the human one in ways big and small, and the coming awfulness and the excitement that comes with it may be the only thing that breaks our neurotic information-infested existence.

minor_characters.title: Minor Characters: A Beat Memoir
minor_characters.author: Joyce Johnson
minor_characters.review: Enjoyed this one for it's more down to Earth portrayal of the Beats and their art scene, a more sober, reflective view on them rather than the mad-dashing craziness of their own work during the time period. Reveals the Kerouac that you see in his works beyond all of the bluster and ambitions, a man scared of his own desires, afraid to sit still for longer than a few days, never satisfied, never content, a sad man terrified to open himself up in any real way while still maintaining some of his magnetism, his appeal, and his zeal for life. Johnson does a good job portraying all of this and his impact on her without bitterness but with honesty and tenderness. Most prominently focused on Johnson and her own escape from the confines of 1950s womanhood and the home she found in the Beats/New York, even though she was marginalized artistically and treated differently because she was a woman. Overall, a good read for a fan of the Beats to get another perspective other than the main players or for someone interested in womanhood/women in the arts of the time period.

do_androids.title: Do Androids Dream of Electric Sheep?
do_androids.author: Philip K. Dick
do_androids.review:
Finished in one sitting, which I don't really do anymore, so this clearly has a lot going for it.

The prose here is a level up from my first exposure to PKD in Ubik, the barren landscapes and hard-boiled cityscapes finally measuring up to the ideas laden behind them. The paranoia coming off every page is palpable, even when the hunt for the escaped androids isn't front and center in the narrative, as it's not just the hunt that makes these people frightened and untrusting, but the conditions that have made Earth a hellish landscape and the inability to readily distinguish man from machine, to distinguish any sort of true motives. There's some weird dialogue choices here, lots of characters talking about people (or androids) directly in front of them, but that heightens the mood here, the paranoia, the breakdown of basic trust and our social norms in any interaction. The 'fake' police department and the accusations of the other bounty hunter is another instance that builds up the confusion in the reader and makes them distrustful even as the characters themselves move past those moments.

The world of Do Androids Dream? is one of decay, and more specifically man-made decay. The robots with their four year lifespans, Deckard's relationship with his wife, the world itself with any animals and humanity itself choking on dust, the buildings, even our simulacra of those animals, everything in here is falling apart, atrophied, collapsed. Everything is dying, dead, past the point of saving, and the characters here are left to make something out of Earth's last gasps. The accepted response to this decay and collapse being a machine that dictates your brain chemicals and mood and a retreat into television and your apartment feels (almost too) prescient, with antidepressant use on the rise as the contradictions and misery wrought by capitalism wreak havoc on the population and in-home technology isolates people further from one another.

The other central concern here is empathy. The androids don't feel empathy, not towards each other, particularly not towards man. The people apparently do, as dictated by the Empathy test and their interaction with the Mercer machine, where they plug in and feel the pain of a man climbing a hill having rocks chucked at him. The androids can't interact with this machine, and think separating man from this machine, and thus from religion, will make them just like them, cold, calculating, relatively unfeeling. But even as the religion is exposed as a fraud, the people don't seem to care, the literal truth of the religion not mattering beyond what it provides to them, what is denied to the androids, the empathy and community and sharing they feel inside the machine mattering more to them than the literal truth of the matter. And the androids aren't necessarily locked in their true nature, either; Racheal's final motion of destroying his goat in anger and the relationship with Deckard, seems to imply that they may have the capacity for empathy, for something beyond cool calculation, themselves.

the_raw.title: The Raw Shark Texts
the_raw.author: Steven  Hall
the_raw.review:
Found this one quite disappointing. Memento by way of the style of House of Leaves sounds right up my alley, but this one fell quite short of that mark.

The biggest problem is the tonal whiplash- I am on the record as not a fan of Whedon-esque quips, but there are places where they have their use and their function. In my opinion, they do not belong in your horror-adjacent book about a killer theoretical shark that seems to want to ramp up its atmosphere by using ergodic elements but undercuts any tension that they build by quippy dialogue or a look between characters that communicates their desire to fuck. I'm all for authors getting horned up in their work, but there's a time and place where it adds to atmosphere and a time and place where it ruins any tension you've built. This is the latter.

As for the ergodic elements, here it all felt a little tacked on, not as intricate a part of the work as House of Leaves where every single piece relies on the intertextuality and the disorienting assault of footnotes, book flippings, and assorted images associated with the texts. Here it's used sparingly, and most of the moments are downright unnecessary (did I really need the picture of the QWERTY keyboard to illustrate all this?). The 60 page shark attack worked for me, but other than that Hall's experimentations feel more like window dressings, a hook, a gimmick, than something necessary to the text.

That being said, there's interesting ideas here, the idea of our words and ideas and memories having lives beyond our heads, beyond the pages they're written on, this idea of the flow of information and it existing in a metaphysical sense rather than just the physical sense of letters or the Internet or sound waves, and the idea that there are animals/forces beyond our comprehension following this flow seeking to swallow them whole and take them from us. And beyond just the central threat of the shark, there is some interesting theoretical stuff going on here; the dialectical nature of Hall's reflections on memory and the people you hold only in memory, whether they're just a pale shadow of themselves, empty words on the page, not themselves the second you think back or write them down, or if they're living, breathing in your mind, something to interact and guide you even in their literal physical absence. I just wish Hall was more interested in these ideas and developing them further rather than the romance element of the books.
