SPOILERS Even if the romance is essential to the ending here, there's ways to sell this without it feeling like a Marvel movie, in ways that Sanderson reconnecting with the ghost of his dead wife adds to the atmosphere and ideas, not subtracts. END SPOILERS And perhaps he felt his ideas starting to fray, losing the thread of them, their meaning entirely swallowed by a Ludovician if he lingered and exploring them longer, but that leads to a novel that feels at best an experiment that doesn't quite succeed.

Overall, there's things to like here, but there's a 100 page middle section that just drags before rebounding into something more interesting. Without that section, the experience of this book might totally be different, but I can only reflect on the words that made it on the page. In my estimation, he loses sight of what I consider important here (the ideas, the atmosphere, the horror) in favor of things I'm not all that interested in (the characters and their relationships), and that knocks this down a few pegs. Your mileage and experience may vary.

the_city.title: The City & the City
the_city.author: China Miéville
the_city.review:
2021 getting its real start with a bang. This was incredible, going straight into the favorites.

For a work of 'weird' fiction (or at least one by one of the preeminent writers of the 'New Weird'), this is remarkably restrained, both in its prose and its concepts. And to be honest, the novel greatly benefits from it- even as the concepts get a bit more gonzo as it progresses, the levelheaded narration of Inspector Borlu keeps everything in balance, keeps the progression and ideas first. For fans of the more purpley prose or Lovecraftian aspects of the Weird this might come as a disappointment, but keeping everything so in check emphasizes the Kafkaesque nightmare of bureaucracy and invisible walls and borders and the mind games of following the rules regulating what you see, what you hear, your very perception of the world. This is a crime novel first and foremost (or, at least, Mieville says it is), and at least stylistically it strays closer to that than his own past works.

As for the titular cities, Mieville ruthlessly probes the conceit for all its worth, from how it affects tourists, refugees, immigrants, to how it affects chasing criminals. It would be easy for Mieville, a Marxist, to get overtly political/dialetical/revolutionary with this idea of people trained to deny the truth directly in front of their eyes, but that's not what he's interested in here, even if there are plenty of nationalists and Social Democrats to be found here. He's interested in what this denial does to the psyche, what living with that contradiction everyday does, what the maintenance of those beliefs does in a society open to outsiders. And in the end, he finds the truth that everyone who's seen the truth ends up in: once you've seen the contradictions, the two sides of the city, there's no turning back, there's no 'unseeing' ever again. You can choose to work to enforce them, to be coopted into the upholding of the blindess, or you face life outside (some would say in that third city, Orciny), on the run, hunted and ostracized.

As for the plot, it opens up in perfect sync with the concepts, the reader learning more and more about the case as they also learn more about Breach and the dynamics between the cities. There's still enough mystery left in the end to leave readers with some things to cling to in the end, but plenty solved as to not be unsatisfying. SPOILERS The wrap of the case reveals the irrelevance of all these inter country machinations in the face of big business, of extractive capitalism. Whatever politicians are brought to justice and abuses uncovered, the law can no longer fix the economic systems that have overpowered them. Borlu ends up sticking with Breach in spite of its irrelevance and him 'seeing' it; I guess there are certain things you can 'unsee,' when your own livelihood still depends on it. The last chapter implies he's going to liberalize Breach, going to make it more modern, rely less on intimidation and more on tech, which feels almost tongue in cheek from Mieville, as if he's mocking the end result of his own character, that until one can check capitalism machinations there is only endless retooling and variations on the same systems. From any other author, it might feel like a bad or unsatisfying ending, but from Mieville, it feels intentional, an acknowledgement of his own place in the economic system and the powerlessness we all have in changing it. END SPOILERS

ready_player.title: Ready Player One (Ready Player One, #1)
ready_player.author: Ernest Cline
ready_player.review:
Almost said I finished this in 2020 just so it wouldn't be my first book of 2021, but the integrity of the Good Reads Reading Challenge (Sponsored by Amazon!) is far too important for me to dare doing it.

This has the bones of something that would be interesting in the right hands, someone with a techno fetish, someone that could do what JG Ballard did to industrialization and metal and cars to the location of cyberspace and virtual reality. But Cline is too earnest, too unimaginative, too excited by the possibilities he outlines- the truth is, he looks at a world where humanity has failed and there's no stopping climate change and poverty envelops nearly everyone and so everyone has retreated into virtual spaces and he celebrates it, because the world now looks just like him, locked inside, playing video games. He plays at saying that's it bad to live your life virtually in the end, saying the only things that matter are in the real world, but you can feel he doesn't mean it- Wade only internalizes it and accepts it because he has a hot gamer girl waiting at the end of the tunnel (er, Maze that looks just like the one in that one 80s video game!). The rest of this is filled with such contempt for humanity as a whole (Wade at one point gets himself locked up in a techno-slavery camp and within a week is already talking about how much he hates all the other slaves in the camp, and when his actions lead to the death of his aunt and uncle he spends maybe a paragraph lightly mourning) and ideas at world improvement so vague and handwavey (the idea of fixing poverty and the climate and the world is brought up, but the only solution proposed is throwing money at world hunger, and Wade actually wants to just fly off in a spaceship with movies and games and leave the rest of the world behind) that can you feel Cline sighing and saying he needs to put it in there even if he's not interested in any of it. There's a sincere version of this that works that communicates the message that escapes from reality are dangerous and we need to engage with the problems of the day rather than retreating into culture and an ironic, almost satirical version that reveals the ugly innards of a life mediated entirely online, but this falls far short of either of those.

Have to say it, if there's one thing we've learned in the 9 years since Ready Player One, it's that the overly sincere, passionate, devoted nerd fans of major IP aren't opposed to the inhuman profit motivated corporations churning out slop and seeking to destroy it, but actively campaigning for it, advocating for it, harassing anyone who even mentions the fact that what they're producing is garbage. The entire plotline of this of the pure of heart nerds rising up to take down the corporations seeking to profitize your childhood, the things that give you pleasure, feels almost hokey- if anything, they would be celebrating it, defending it, encouraging it along on its path of destruction.

The prose here is obviously dire, reading either like an excited 6th grader telling you about the video game boss he just beat or a SparkNotes summary of itself. There's no life, no sensory detail- as a matter of fact, most of the description is just pointing to a property that's it referencing and saying it looks just like that. No imagination, no feeling, no desire to craft something new. There's plenty of room for pastiche, but spelling out references to every 80s movie isn't pastiche, it's plagiarism. The characters themselves are fairly lifeless and inert, Wade a male gamer self-insert, Artemis the hot gamer chick, the two Japanese samurai guys. One of them has an interesting backstory- a black lesbian woman playing in VR as a white man to escape the oppressions of the real world, but Cline has no interest in exploring that, tossing it aside in favor of more digressions about the virtues of 80s culture, saying her race doesn't really matter at all (although to be fair, I'm not sure anyone needs to hear him try to talk about racism, either).

There is a lengthy section in here that does talk in detail about how all of humanity's greatest accomplishments, from Thomas Edison to Marie Curie, came about because of masturbation, so there's that, too.

neuromancer_(sprawl,.title: Neuromancer (Sprawl, #1)
neuromancer_(sprawl,.author: William Gibson
neuromancer_(sprawl,.review:
Obviously a debut novel in that it's so bursting with ideas that it can sometimes get lost in them (and some of the descriptions that are a little over the top), but given it's only 292 pages that's forgivable. The blueprint of most all science fiction to follow, which can make it almost a trite read 35 years later but Gibson's vision is compelling enough to carry it even if it's been regurgitated at you in bit and pieces of media of varying quality ever since. Even if it doesn't feel original now, it still feels cool, and that's arguably more important.

Gibson's characters are largely hollowed out shells, alienated from the world and each other by a hyper competitive dog kill dog world and increasingly technological spaces that makes human connection undesirable or worse, a weakness. Case's central drive isn't because the quest to free Wintermute means anything to him or he loves Molly or any human consideration- it's simply so he can retain his connection to the matrix, this thrilling alternate world, this 'hallucination.' These people's interests have been reduced to survival, to a job, their relationships transactional, diffuse, 'useful' but not ultimately meaningful. The AI storyline plays almost as side dressing, a question of which corporate master you will serve- Case and the book itself seems to be uncommitted, even uninterested on whether the success or failure of the mission is moral or good, just a changing of hands of power in the increasingly abstracted and less human halls of power, something that may make no difference at all in anyone's material conditions.

Gibson is not afraid to lose you in slang of the world and hyper-complex descriptions, and there will be paragraphs you have to puzzle over, but it's far better than the alternative of overexposition. I've heard people describe the matrix as the closest analog to the Internet because all the details are wrong but the underlying feeling is right, the overwhelming amounts of information flying at you, the feeling of possibility there even as the reality of its place in hypercapitalist society is inescapable. Plus, stick around too long and you'll almost certainly have your brain melted. A true classic.

the_big.title: The Big Sleep (Philip Marlowe, #1)
the_big.author: Raymond Chandler
the_big.review: Phillip Marlowe is apparently the noir detective every other stereotypical noir detective is based off of (good or bad), slapping women, talking tough, and dedicated to every case that comes across his desk. Can't say I got much more out of this than a good time and some laughs from Marlowe's character and the corrupt cast of characters around him but it's short enough and so obviously influential enough that anyone remotely interested in detective/noir stories needs to at least check it out. Chandler's style might not be for everybody (not every character needs their appearance described for a paragraph bud) and if you're looking for homophobia/misogyny there's plenty to be had here, but it's distinctive enough in Chandler's stylings and atmosphere that it's worth the read, even if I think later works do a better job of tying their cases and characters to broader themes/institutional corruption, even if there are traces of that here.

drive_your.title: Drive Your Plow Over the Bones of the Dead
drive_your.author: Olga Tokarczuk
drive_your.review:
Not a fan of astrology and haven't read any Blake so a lot of the meaning on this one may be lost to me, but found it a really good read regardless. A love letter to Nature and Animals and a cry for their protection in a world that still cruelly takes their lives in the name of sport and excess. At the end Tokarczuk also points to an important truth, that a world where Animals aren't valued for anything other than their pelt or their meat it's a natural step to devalue the Oddballs of our own kind, those who fall outside the realm of capitalist production or familial reproduction, and that retributive violence is a potential outlet to attempt to reclaim one's own value and avenge the disregard by those in power. The main character's narration form something of a reflection on the nature of solitude, on the way it attunes one to their surroundings, to an appreciation of the finer details of the people that they do have in their life and to the crowds they find themselves in, and to how it enables one to lean into ones quirks, interests, and causes (even if the cause is murder). The trick of this one- that even as the killer in this murder mystery is narrating the story, and she mentions that no one will suspect her because she's a 'crazy' old lady, you still don't suspect her until late in the game because she's an old lady (or at least I didn't really; I considered it but didn't quite believe it).

A better dog murder revenge story than John Wick.

ubik.title: Ubik
ubik.author: Philip K. Dick
ubik.review: My first Dick, and I quite enjoyed it. He's clearly not the finest prose stylist in the world, but he gets the job done and he doesn't belabor the point, letting the central mystery carry you through the brisk ~200 pages. The closest analog to this I can think of is Inception, but whereas Nolan is interested in highly competent men navigating his only slightly off-kilter dream space, Dick is far more interested into diving into the weirdness and the ambiguity of Ubik's premises, the characters pawns in something larger that they (and really, you, the reader) never fully can grasp onto and understand. The details of the world of Ubik and the asides at the start of each chapter paint a dystopian picture of a commodified world, one where it costs a nickel to open your front door and where the religious can be sold (or used to sell) any product you can imagine. This world's eventual crumble feels eerily familiar, one where time feels like it's rapidly, uncontrollably hurtling forward towards fresh new horrors while simultaneously regressing back into the comforts and trappings of some imagined past, some fake nostalgia, hiding in the times you never lived through. In the end, no matter what humanity does to extend/prolong lifespan, at the end all there is your own inevitable decay, the death of everyone you love, and the mystery of what lies after. Might as well stick around for the people you care about and enjoy the weirdness.

pop._1280.title: Pop. 1280 (Mulholland Classic)
pop._1280.author: Jim Thompson
pop._1280.review: What starts as a fun Sheriff Nick Corey hangout novel (man, all these girls want to sleep with him! He sure does eat a lot! He doesn't enforce the law at all!) ends in him proclaiming himself the resurrected  Christ sent to tempt people into their own destruction as the blood of the (at least) 6 dead bodies he's responsible for accumulates at his feet. Thompson is hilarious, Corey's narration nonchalantly going through adultery, murder, framing others for those murders, and the destruction of others with an aw shucks, nonchalant attitude that reveals no hint of the plans he's made nor the gravity of what he's done. Through Corey, and the inability of the town to punish him, Thompson shows the incompetence of the powerful in holding their own accountable because of their own inequities/stupidity and centers in on the heart of policing and the function of American governance as racism, sexism, protecting the rich, and the maintaining of these stupid men in their positions of power.

in_cold.title: In Cold Blood
in_cold.author: Truman Capote
in_cold.review:
I didn't realize this was all true until halfway through because I'm an idiot.

That being said, felt like this was filled with empathy for everyone involved; people seem to think the Clutter's don't get enough time, but the first chapter (which is like ~25% of the book?) is mostly filled with details of their lives, what they were passionate about, what they meant to the community so that their loss isn't just a footnote to the psychology of the killers but woven into what the act meant to the community at large. A (perhaps unintentional) document of the beginnings of rural America's descent into the hotbed of paranoia and distrust that it has become, from trusting your neighbors and leaving your doors unlocked to frantic distrust, locked into the television screen or the radio rather anything material in the community. The Perry/Dick stuff is not as revolutionary as it probably was upon release (lord knows we've dived into the psychology of killers plenty of times since), but Capote's empathy especially towards Perry and his messed up inner workings means that time spent there is worthwhile and eye-opening
